Clärchen's Ballroom still offers all kinds of dancing. Wednesdays is Swing, then there's ballroom dancing on Thursdays, informal dancing on Fridays and Saturdays, and a tea dance on Sunday afternoons.
column13: Clärchen's Ballroom is still the place to be, as demonstrated in summer 2017 when Britain's Prince William and his wife Kate spent an hour visiting the historic dance hall to learn more about Berlin's creative scene. A royal visit - now that would have been beyond the wildest dreams of Clara and Fritz Bühler!

column8: At SchwuZ, people fight - for tolerance, equality and the best parties!
column11:
Out of the closet and onto the streets!
Melitta Poppe, Chou Chou de Briquette, Pepsi Boston and Melitta Sundström - the icons of Berlin's gay scene were at home in SchwuZ. Short for SchwulenZentrum (gay centre) the club was once a hotbed of the gay rights movement. 

A huge, empty hall. A tiny, scruffy bar and a couple of old mattresses. The smell of stale cigarette smoke hangs in the air. The atmosphere is rancid at Kulmer Straße, where SchwuZ was founded in 1977 by the Homosexual Action West Berlin (HAW). It's one of the few places that gay men can meet in a relaxed atmosphere, at a time when society still views homosexuality as "verboten", "unnatural" and "perverse".  

Driving gay culture underground  

SchwuZ is extremely political. Paragraph 175 entered Germany's Criminal Code during the 1870s, making homosexual acts between men a crime. They were partially decriminalised in 1969, meaning that homosexual acts would go unpunished under certain conditions. But paragraph 175 was still driving gay culture underground - into the 'cottages', the public toilets where gay men meet for anonymous sex.  

That's why, in 1971, Rosa von Praunheim makes the rousing cry "Out of the cottages and onto the streets" in his film It is not the homosexual who is perverse, but the society in which he lives. He calls on gays to come out of the closet and fight actively for equality and tolerance for their way of life.  

The documentary film becomes a vital spark for the lesbian and gay movement. The film's director also provides SchwuZ with its first premises in Dannewitzstraße. It was there, and in Kulmer Straße where you are now standing, that gay culture began to take root. 

Queers and their gear  

The fight for gay rights has its fun side, and SchwuZ hosts some legendary parties. The men's discos held on Saturdays soon become a cult and, decades later, people still remember the amazing drag shows. The drag queens' outfits are a revolt against gender stereotypes, and their shrill performances are consciously and entertainingly crossing a boundary. SchwuZ provides a space for activism. Gay schoolboys gather here and set up their own group. It is the home of the pink telephone initiative, which later becomes a gay counselling service. It's the birthplace of Die Siegessäule, Berlin's gay - now queer - magazine. And SchwuZ activists organised Germany's very first Christopher Street Day back in 1979.  

Three parades and 40 years later, SchwuZ is still a major player in Berlin's cultural and party scene. It's hard to imagine the city without it. It has changed perceptions of how we live and love, to the point where Berlin's former mayor Klaus Wowereit proclaimed during his campaign: "I'm gay - and that's a good thing!" Society has moved on and nowadays some of the clubbers at SchwuZ are not even aware the part it played in the struggle for gay rights.
column13: In 1852, Berlin physician Johann Ludwig Casper published an essay in which, for the first time, he aired the argument that homosexuality is an innate characteristic. In 1869 Rudolf Virchow also called for homosexual acts to be legalised. This was finally achieved when paragraph 175 was annulled on 11 June 1994.

column8: Barbed wire, ruthless border guards, abandoned platforms - 16 stations are turned into a subterranean frontier
column11:
The subterranean frontier
"Last stop in Berlin West". When they hear the tannoy announcement, the commuter train passengers know what it means. The division of Berlin means that the DDR regime has created a border right down the middle of the public transport network. Three subway and commuter rail lines no longer stop at East Berlin's seemingly abandoned stations. 

The West Berliners call them "ghost stations" because the division of Berlin means their platforms stand empty. Now and then it's possible to spot a sentry keeping a watchful eye over the gloom. 

After Berlin's division into sectors, the SED was forced to watch how - of all things - it was the S-Bahn, the commuter rail network owned by East Germany's Deutsche Reichsbahn, that became a popular means of escape. It became a "gateway to the democratic sector". It was not only a gateway for the many cross-border commuters who failed to return to the Eastern sector, but also for illicit goods.  

Closing the gap in the system  

On 13 August 1961, the regime takes action. Today's U-Bahn lines 6 and 8 and the S-Bahn's north-south line (today's S1, S2 and S25) were no longer allowed to stop at the 16 stations in East Berlin. Passengers who got on in the West could only alight in the West. 

East Berlin train lines that are manned by West Berliners but not allowed to stop in the East? The absurdity of such a system sparks an outcry, spearheaded by Berlin's mayor Willy Brandt, who fumes: "It is unacceptable that Western proceeds from the S-Bahn are being used to buy barbed wire." 

And indeed, the border police are equipping the platforms with fences, barbed wire obstacles, walls, beds of nails and guards galore. 

Even the guards are escaping  

Ironically, up to 1966 it was the regime's own people who were taking advantage of this underground escape route. A quick visit to the toilet, a moment without surveillance - and border guards were regularly disappearing through the emergency exits and tunnels. The authorities respond by gradually installing rolling grilles in the tunnels, locking the emergency exits, and in the end they even wall in the sentries. Now only officers can unlock the doors, and the guards have to watch over the platform through small windows - through which they can shoot if necessary. Many civilians try to escape via this route, and at least ten lose their lives in the attempt.   

Today, the former Nordbahnhof ghost station is part of the Berlin Wall Memorial and houses an exhibition entitled "Border Stations and Ghost Stations in Divided Berlin". In addition to the exhibition, aluminium panels on the floor serve as reminders of the barriers that were used to block off the station entrances.
column12: Freely accessible during S-Bahn operating hours
column13: Every successful - or unsuccessful - escape attempt led to security being ramped up at the ghost stations. If the escape involved breaking through a wall, the Reichsbahn installed a second wall on the spot. The Invalidenstraße entrance to Nordbahnhof held the record, with six walls and a steel grille.

column8: Revolution in Berlin! The war is over, the Emperor abdicates - and workers' leader Karl Liebknecht declares Germany a socialist republic
column11:
“The day of freedom has dawned”
Saturday, 9 November 1918. A wave of revolutions across Germany reaches Berlin. In the afternoon, the Lustgarten square fills with packed crowds. The guards at the gateways to the City Palace leave their posts. The police and officers move off. The revolutionaries take over the City Palace, the Prussian centre of power and century-long residence of the Hohenzollern rulers.

On the first floor over the impressive entrance known as Portal IV, a window opens. A red blanket is placed over the balustrade. This is the same window where, on 1 August 1914, Kaiser Wilhelm II announced the start of the war to his cheering subjects. But four years and 16 million dead later, the Kaiser has abdicated. Now, the figure at the window is the workers' leader, Karl Liebknecht, son of the founder of Germany's SPD socialist party and godson of Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels. For Karl Liebknecht, this is the climax of his political career, a moment making the deprivations, imprisonment, and persecution he suffered all worthwhile.                     He shouts out his message to the eager crowds below. The war is over, the day of freedom has come, never again will the Hohenzollern dynasty, the Prussian rulers, walk over this square. From the window, he proclaims the free socialist republic of Germany. The people cheer and wave flags, raising their hands to take an oath in support of the new republic.

A bloody civil war

Liebknecht's triumph is short-lived. The revolution ushers in a civil war, with months of bloody uprisings and street battles. On 15 January 1919, a paramilitary unit of World War I veterans arrest Karl Liebknecht, and summarily execute him together with Rosa Luxemburg. By then, the City Palace's Portal IV - where crowds gathered to celebrate the start and end of the First World War - is already badly damaged, shelled during a skirmish on 24 December 1918 between regular army units and the socialist revolutionary Volksmarinedivision entrenched in the palace.

Berlin City Palace demolished

Portal IV fades into obscurity until 1950, after the end of World War II. The regime in East Germany wants to tear down the shell of the burned-out City Palace, eradicating all traces of this relic of Prussian power. At the last minute, measures are taken to secure the balcony from which Karl Liebknecht reputedly declared Germany a socialist republic. The remains of the portal are put into storage. Finally, ten years later, construction brigades integrate the "Liebknecht Portal", as it is now known, into the façade of East Germany's State Council building.

Humboldt Forum

Today, you can find two Portal IVs. The remains of the original are set prominently in the front façade of the former GDR's State Council official building, now home to a private college. Facing Lustgarten square, a replica of the portal has been set up on the original site as part of the reconstructed façade of the Berlin City Palace - the new Humboldt Forum.
column13: On the second-floor balcony, workers' leader Karl Liebknecht declared Germany a socialist republic - at least, that's how this historical moment is depicted in art or on film. In reality, Liebknecht actually stood at a first-floor window above Portal IV.

column8: A 12-year-old boy who tries to skip school becomes a symbol of the Berliners' desire for freedom.
column11:
An armoured escort to school
It's summer, and the Wall is being built. But 12-year-old Erwin from Eiskeller, an exclave of West Berlin, has other problems. He's feeling upset because his parents have split up and he's having a hard time at school.

So he comes up with a bright idea for getting out of Maths and Latin - he claims the East German police stopped him while he was cycling to school. The only way he can get to Spandau from Eiskeller is to ride 500 metres down a narrow corridor through East German territory. In the 1960s, 20 people live on 3 farms surrounded by barbed wire and the Wall. East German border guards watch over the fields and horses, the scent of freshly cut hay in their nostrils. After all, it would be relatively easy for East German citizens to escape to such a village. 

The threatening environment of the Cold War means that Erwin's story brings the Allies onto the scene. Instead of a couple of days off school, he ends up with an escort - and quite a special one! He is followed to school by a British armoured car manned by five soldiers. To school in the morning, back home in the afternoon - every single day.  

Cycling home through the GDR  

The division of Germany leads to the creation of several exclaves around Berlin. Villages in West Berlin suddenly find they are islands in GDR territory, and areas of East Germany are set adrift in West Berlin. This has an impact on people's daily lives, such as when West Berliners are harassed by East German border guards on their way home, even though they have the necessary permits. Steinstücken is one such exclave. Its 190 inhabitants include Heinrich Lummer, leader of the CDU faction in West Berlin's House of Representatives and later Senator of the Interior. They have no choice but to keep to themselves, as apart from doctors and the fire brigade, only registered inhabitants are allowed to enter Steinstücken. 

The Four Power Agreement of September 1971 ushers in a change to the status quo. It paves the way for an exchange of territory between the West Berlin Senate and the GDR government. There are advantages for both sides, as the West wants free access to its citizens and territories, while the East wants a clearly defined border that is easy to secure.  

A schoolyard hero 

The agreement on the settlement of enclaves through territorial exchange enters into force on 3 June 1972 under the Four Powers Agreement. The GDR receives 15.6 hectares of West Berlin, while the West Berliners gain 17.1 hectares of East Germany, including Steinstücken and improved access to Eiskeller.  

And Erwin? He's a schoolyard hero. A photo of Erwin on his bike followed by the soldiers in their armoured car flies around the world and he becomes a symbol of the Berliners' desire for freedom. Even when he confesses that he was trying to play truant, he still keeps his escort - and his hero status.
column13: Eiskeller regularly sets record temperatures in Berlin. In summer the heat builds up on its open fields, and in winter it's the coldest place in the city. Before the invention of the refrigerator, this was Berlin's ice box. Ice was chipped out of the Falkenhagener See and sold to institutions such as hospitals.

column7: Hochhaus an der Weberwiese residential building
column8: Socialism vs capitalism: who can build higher, faster, further?
column11:
A prototype for socialist architecture
Thud, thud, thud. The sound of the masons' hammers echoes across the tract of land known as the Weberwiese. They reflect the mood of optimism that is sweeping through the German Democratic Republic. Brick by brick, the workers construct the tower that will welcome its first residents in just 6 months' time. The high-rise building on the Weberwiese is a prototype for the new socialist style of architecture.

The entrance to the 35-metre-high building is here at Marchlewskistraße 25. The building was designed jointly by a group of architects, including Hermann Henselmann, Hans Hipp and Richard Paulick. In the early days of the GDR, the regime was looking for a prototype that could be applied to the redevelopment of the area around Stalinallee, which was destroyed during the war and later re-named in honour of Karl Marx. This huge building project is meant to demonstrate the superiority of socialism in the class struggle with capitalism.  

The wedding-cake style dominates the east of the city 

The rulers reject the architects' initial designs as being too modern, sober and functional. At the next presentation, up-and-coming architect Hermann Henselmann stresses how the design has been heavily influenced by the neo-classicist master builder Karl Friedrich Schinkel, who shaped much of Prussian, imperial Berlin in the 19th century. This is enough to convince the Soviet authorities. They want buildings that reflect national and regional building traditions with typical design features. This leads to the development of an architectural style known as Socialist Classicism. This Stalinist wedding-cake style dominates the early years of the GDR. The construction work starts on 12 October 1951.  

Work goes on 24/7 

The East is determined to outdo the capitalist West by building faster, higher, more impressively. The magnificent socialist building is completed in record time. Work on the construction site on the Weberwiese building site never stops; the workers build, saw and hammer around the clock. At night, 20 floodlights illuminate the site. The authorities show little consideration for the workers, expecting them to carry on in wind, rain and freezing temperatures. Countless volunteers are also involved in the project. They are part of the Nationales Aufbauwerk (National Construction Project), called into life as part of efforts to rebuild East German cities destroyed during the war. The government is ruthless about increasing productivity and introduces measures such as longer standard working hours. As a result, the construction boom on Stalinallee, the great socialist boulevard, contributes to the workers' uprising of 17 June 1953 - a first cry for freedom.

But the building on the Weberwiese gets a warm reception. The first tenants move in on 1 May 1952, just six months after construction work began. The apartments are equipped to a high standard with fitted kitchens, telephones, central heating and even a lift - a luxury that the residents of future "workers' palaces" certainly won't get to enjoy. A verse by the playwright Bertolt Brecht is carved in stone in the entrance lobby. It sums up the mood of optimism surrounding this project on the Weberwiese: Friede in unserem Lande, Friede in unserer Stadt, dass sie den gut behause, der sie gebauet hat (Peace in our country, peace in our city, that they may house and protect those who built them").
column12: The Hochhaus is a residential building and not open to the public
column13: A lesson in upcycling - the high-rise block on the Weberwiese is mainly built from materials salvaged from the ruins of the war. The black marble in the entrance lobby comes from Hitler's Chancellery.

column8: Between Frankfurter Tor and Straußberger Platz, today's Karl-Marx-Allee resembles a grand Soviet-style boulevard.
column11:
Boulevard of GDR architecture
Take a journey back in time to the 1950s. After the Second World War, the Große Frankfurter Straße lies in ruins. People desperately need housing - but here other issues are at stake as well. The Cold War leaves the city divided into East and West Berlin. East Germany's ruling SED, the Socialist Unity Party of Germany, wants to prove that the GDR has more to offer workers - not simple flats, but comfortable palaces.

The newly constructed buildings really are luxurious. Instead of cold, cramped and unhygienic conditions in tenement flats, these apartments offer a very different life - up to 145 sq. metres of space, stuccoed ceilings, parquet floors, double windows, rubbish chutes, a bell system as well as central heating and a regular supply of warm water. The blocks also all have elevators.

East Germany's showpiece project

The boulevard between Berlin's Frankfurter Tor and Strausberger Platz is a major arterial road in East Berlin. It is renamed Stalinallee in 1949, and three years later becomes the site of East Berlin's first large-scale socialist prestige building project. This main thoroughfare is further widened to provide the grand setting needed for political rallies and military parades. The prototype apartment house is the 'Hochhaus an der Weberwiese' tower block finished in 1951-52 and designed by Hermann Henselmann, chief architect of the new Stalinallee.

Henselmann took his inspiration from the architecture popular under Stalin - Socialist Classicism and Socialist Realism. Although these styles are also influenced by neoclassicism, in particular by buildings by Prussia's renowned architect Karl Friedrich Schinkel, Stalinallee's main model comes from the residential blocks designed by Arkady Mordvinov in Moscow in the 1930s. Critics deride the monumental architecture of these Socialist Classicist tower blocks as a "wedding cake style".

The Stalinallee project begins on 3 February 1952. Thousands of workers construct the brick-built tower blocks. Newspapers and posters in East Germany never cease to sing the praises of the buildings along Stalinallee and many people hope to move into one of these coveted flats. The GDR film Die neue Wohnung (The New Apartment) featured the catchy Aufbau-Walzer (Reconstruction Waltz), also given generous airtime on radio: "As high as the sky, as bright as the sun / building beautiful houses, now the cranes spin round / We shout: Heave ho! Heave ho! / We put our backs into it, the houses shoot up / Heave ho! Heave ho! For our new Berlin!"

But the propaganda only papers over the dissatisfaction with the economic and political situation in East Germany. In 1952 alone, 182,000 people leave the country. Initially, little changes even after Stalin's death on 5 March 1953. In May 1953, to accelerate the reconstruction of East Germany, the SED Politburo increases work quotas by ten percent - a decision many ordinary people see as the last straw. Across East Germany, crowds gathered to protest, not just calling for economic improvements, but also for free elections and the end of the Soviet-style SED regime.

The protests escalate on 17 June 1953. The SED regime seems helpless as demonstrators take to the streets. After a few hours, Soviet tanks and troops put a violent end to the popular uprising.

A prestige project in decline

Henselmann continues to oversee construction on Stalinallee until 1958. Then the gathering wave of de-Stalinization also sweeps over the architectural sphere as well. Stalin's monumental statue is removed and in 1961 the grand boulevard is renamed Karl-Marx-Allee. Stalinist monumental architecture is now outmoded. The apartments still remain much sought-after, though soon the buildings begin to look dilapidated.
column12:
When you visit Karl-Marx-Allee, you are visiting people's homes.
We would ask you to respect their privacy! Thank you!

For more information on this location, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/stalinallee
column13: The decay of Karl-Marx-Allee is only halted with the fall of the Wall. Today, the street is listed as a heritage site. The complex with nearly 2600 apartments was extensively renovated in the 1990s - a costly affair only made possible by the sale of these former 'workers' palaces' to a private real estate fund.

column8: The Permanent Mission provides a ray of hope and an escape route to the West
column11:
The embassy that isn’t
A sea of hands waving through the slats of the window blind - these are the first pictures of the 55 GDR citizens who fled to West Germany's Permanent Mission (StäV) in East Berlin in June 1984. They are trying to leave East Germany via the de facto embassy that has been providing an unofficial escape hatch since 1974.

It all begins in May 1974 with a thawing of relations between West and East Germany and the signing of the Basic Treaty, which allows for the establishment of permanent missions. These representative offices are like embassies, but this is a term that West Germany is keen to avoid at all costs. It is prepared to recognise the GDR as a sovereign state, but not as a foreign country. In contrast to the two-state theory of the GDR, Germany's political aim is clear: reunification.  

West Germany's Permanent Mission opens in Berlin-Mitte in 1974. It is headed up by SPD politician Günter Gaus. The mission's permanent representatives in East Berlin handle negotiations on transport routes, travel and cultural projects. But alongside their daily work they regularly face a more difficult task: helping East Germans to escape. This West German oasis in the heart of East Berlin represents a ray of hope for many citizens living under the iron fist of the SED. It provides a way for them quietly and discreetly slip into the West, such as by buying their way out. 

A crazy four weeks 

The situation comes to a head on 26 June 1984. 55 East Germans, including 13 children, occupy the mission, which Berliners call the "White House", demanding exit permits. Inge Albrecht was 20 at the time. In 2014 she recalls: "The worst thing was not knowing how long we'd be in this situation (...) and would it even work?" 

For four weeks in 1984, the former Permanent Mission, which you can visit today at Hannoversche Straße 28-30, was bursting at the seams. Conditions quickly deteriorated, as former deputy director Hans Otto Bräutigam recalls: "We cleared out the offices and laid out mattresses on the fifth floor (...) The atmosphere was explosive". For a while, the Mission had to abandon its principle of always being open to visitors.  

The Permanent Mission regularly hits the headlines 

On 16 February 1989, a family crashed their Trabant through the barriers outside the Mission, but they were still allowed to leave. The Mission had to close its doors again on 8 August 1989, when 131 GDR citizens occupied the building.  

Today, a plaque at the former east entrance commemorates the escape route that led people to freedom before 3 October 1990.  

And what about the occupiers in 1984? The story has a happy ending - after tough negotiations between East and West, they were all granted permission to leave in July. Inge Albrecht was one of the last to leave the Permanent Mission.
column13: The Mission had a room that was protected from wiretapping, known as the Laube, the arbour. If staff wanted to leak information, they made sure they talked about it elsewhere in the building. This is what happened when the Mission was occupied in 1984. Hans Otto Bräutigam wanted the GDR to give in so he overdramatised the situation on the phone, knowing that the Stasi would be listening in.

column8: "We want our men back!" - the chant of the courageous women of Rosenstraße
column11:
A courage born of desperation
27 February 1943, a bitterly cold evening. The former Jewish community building is located near Hackescher Markt. Now, the building is in the hands of the Gestapo and SS. A small crowd of women are waiting outside, huddling together to keep warm. To begin with, there is only silence. Then the women start shouting - "Give us back our men!" The shouts grow ever louder: "We want our men back!" Demonstrating without permission is strictly forbidden, but the women remain there waiting. Their husbands are locked up inside.

The Factory Action  

In early 1943, the Nazi authorities launch a large-scale campaign to round up the remaining German Jews and deport them to Auschwitz. The Gestapo and SS close in to haul the men off. In Berlin, they arrest around 8000 Jews at their places of work, taking them directly to a series of designated assembly points. Later, those arrested call this raid the "factory action". Under the Nazi regime's racial laws, 2000 of those arrested are spouses in "mixed marriages" - largely Jewish men married to non-Jewish women. The Gestapo herd the men into the Jewish community building in Rosenstraße. Family members desperately try to contact their loved ones locked inside. The building hardly has any toilet facilities and no places to wash. The stench in the rooms sticks in the throat. In the corridors and rooms, the men can only sit, stand and sleep in turns. 

You are at an advertising pillar in front of the building at Rosenstraße Nr. 2-4. This kind of advertising pillar was also here in 1943. A small girl stands in front of it, looking anxiously upwards. In the bitter cold, her tears freeze as they trickled down her face. There is a man at the window of the third floor - her father Abraham Pisarek, a photographer. He waves to her. He's received the sandwiches that Ruth and her mother manage to give to a guard. Inside the pack of sandwiches, they have hidden a slip of paper with a loving message.  

A courage born of desperation 

Several days go by, and the women are still standing in front of the building in Rosenstraße - and so is the girl. They refuse to move, even when the Gestapo threaten them with guns. After six days, the first men are released. Ruth Pisarek throws her arms around her father. He is thin, unshaved and looks exhausted - but he has an official notice of release.  

Does the women's protest in Rosenstraße lead the Gestapo to release the men? Historians still dispute the demonstration's effect - but no one disputes the women's courage at this difficult time. They risked their lives to save their men. This was the only public demonstration against the deportation of German Jews in wartime Nazi Germany. 

The building used to incarcerate the men is destroyed in the war. Today, the site is a small greened space. If you head for Alexanderplatz square, you'll find a memorial by the sculptor Ingeborg Hunzinger dedicated to the discrimination against Jews and this courageous protest.
column13: At the back of the green space, you can see stones on the grass. This is another memorial recalling Jewish life and culture in Berlin. The stones are the remains of the city's oldest synagogue, inaugurated in 1714 and destroyed in the Second World War.

column8: In 1930, a SA Brownshirt is killed - and becomes a National Socialist martyr
column11:
Propaganda creates martyrs
14 January 1930. The woman renting the little apartment in Große Frankfurter Straße 62 has quarrelled with her lodger again. Now, she's off to the corner pub to get reinforcements. The Communists there know who her lodger is - the "Nazi boss of Alexanderplatz". His real name is Horst Wessel, long a thorn in the side of the Communists. They are only too happy to work him over. When Wessel comes home, a few muscular Communists are waiting with a special greeting. Then, a few shots ring out. Hit by a bullet in the face, Wessel falls to the floor.

The propaganda machine creates a martyr 

The nearest hospital in the working-class district of Friedrichshain is not far from the scene of the shooting. Badly injured, Wessel is rushed through the impressive hospital gateway straight to the operating theatre. His life is saved by an emergency operation, but he dies of blood poisoning on 23 February 1930. Joseph Goebbels jots down three words in his diary, "A new martyr". Immediately, he begins to plan how Wessel's death can best serve the Nazi propaganda machine.  

From pastor's son to confirmed Nazi  

Horst Wessel is the son of the Lutheran pastor at the traditional St Nicholas Church in Berlin. Even as a young man, Wessel joins groups in nationalist 'völkisch' circles. When he is 19, he becomes a member of the NSDAP - the Nazi Party. Quickly gaining the reputation of an effective speaker, he is seen as someone capable of whipping up emotions for the party. Only Joseph Goebbels, Gauleiter (district leader) of Berlin, gives more public speeches in the city. On 1 May 1929, Horst Wessel takes over as head of the SA troop in Friedrichshain - a district well known as a Communist Party stronghold.  

With his brown shirts, Wessel enthusiastically implements a policy of street fights and brawls in pubs and taverns. Wessel sets out to be provocative - and succeeds. His SA troop are always active. They openly march to music through the streets. He also adapts the Communist tradition of workers' songs, and has his SA troop play them on shawms, a piercing wind instrument. Wessel even composes new words to an old traditional melody: "Raise the flag / The ranks tightly closed / The SA marches calm and steady".  

The Communists long to teach Wessel a lesson - and on 14 January 1930, they act. But it remains unclear if the clash with Wessel is just for political reasons, or if there is a private agenda. The Communist newspaper Die Rote Fahne claims Wessel is a pimp, killed in a fight in that milieu. But the German Communist Party (KPD) cannot stop the Nazis turning Horst Wessel into a martyr.  

With the seizure of power on 30 January 1933, Hitler and the Nazi regime raise their hero cult around Horst Wessel to a state cult. A guard of honour is placed at the scene of his shooting, and his death becomes a vehicle for solemn appeals to the public. Streets, squares and schools are named after him - and Friedrichshain is officially renamed Horst-Wessel-Stadt. Die Fahne hoch (Raise the Flag), Wessel's battle song from 1929, becomes the "second German national anthem". 

In October 1933, the hospital in Friedrichshain is named the Horst Wessel Hospital. The building is nearly entirely destroyed in the war. The only original parts remaining today are the impressive entrance and several outbuildings. Otherwise, Vivantes Hospital Friedrichshain is now distinguished by its buildings from a more recent past.
column12:
Opening hours:
Open around the clock
column13: A minute's silence in memory of a martyr for the Nazi regime? Until just a few years ago, that does happen. In 1945, the Soviet Red Army level the grave of Horst Wessel. From then on, Neo-Nazis and right-wing extremists use his father's grave on the St. Nicholas Cemetery as a focus for their hero cult. In 2013, the cemetery management removes the gravestone.

column8: Today's Tempelhof Airport - kite surfing, barbecuing, relaxing
column11:
Tempelhofer Feld – An urban park in a class of its own
30 October 2008. A loud roaring sound echoes across the air field. Not far from where you are now, a Douglas DC-3 takes off. Its silver-coloured wings wiggle slightly, as if waving goodbye. Dubbed a Candy Bomber by locals, the plane evokes the historic Berlin Air Lift. The Douglas DC-3 flies off into the sky over Berlin - the last aircraft to take off from Tempelhof Airport. On this day, the airport is officially decommissioned - and after a flight lasting just a few minutes, the Candy Bomber lands at Schönefeld Airport.

The gateway to the free world 

In the Cold War, Tempelhof Airport stands as a guarantor of freedom. In 1948, the Soviet army seals off the sectors of Berlin under the Western Allies. With only the air route open, the Allies launch an air lift through Tempelhof Airport. As the Candy Bombers bring in relief supplies for West Berlin's residents, Tempelhof Airport becomes the "gateway to the world". It develops into an inner-city transport hub, a place where many travellers would take off and land in years to come. Tempelhof Airport is finally closed on 30 October 2008 - fuelling a protracted debate on what Berlin should to do with the site. The promising project of an urban park is called Tempelhofer Freiheit - "Tempelhof Freedom".  

An urban park for all Berlin 

On 8 May 2010, the new park opens. It is an unforgettable experience - just as it still is today when you step onto the Tempelhofer Feld, as the park is now called. Initially, ten access routes lead into this vast site - one of the world's largest open free spaces in any inner city. The park's size is awesome - 300 hectares, enough space for around 420 football pitches. Or put another way - seven times as large as the Vatican City. Tempelhofer Feld park is open for all. Here (almost) everything is allowed - from skating to strolling, urban gardening, picnicking, chilling, kite surfing, bird watching and much more. Take a look around. The leisure activities are supplemented by a community garden, a bicycle repair shop, and a Theater der Welten theatre project. Today, the striking airport buildings, now with heritage status, regularly host major trade fairs and music events.  

In 2014, a referendum is held on the park's future use. The Berlin Senate wants to allow perimeter developments with apartments, a library and commercial real estate. Many Berlin residents see this as the beginning of the end of their freedom on the spreading Tempelhofer Freiheit park. The referendum leaves no doubt. The Berliners vote overwhelmingly to preserve the entire Tempelhof Feld park - their playground and experimental ground. What the future holds for this vast free space depends on the courage and inventiveness of Berlin's policymakers.
column12:
Freely accessible

Opening hours:
The Tempelhofer Feld's opening times vary seasonally.

For more information on this location, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/tempelhofer-feld-tempelhof-field
column13: Sometimes, freedom has its limits. From April to July, visitors have keep off the meadowland between the old landing and take-off strips. For the endangered skylark to breed, it needs to be undisturbed!

column8: The symbol of Germany's division is no more.  In 1990 a section of the Berlin Wall is transformed into a unique piece of art.
column11:
Test the Best – Painting for freedom
The world's longest open-air gallery is being created in Berlin. It's the first art project to be undertaken by a united Germany since the fall of the Berlin Wall and attracts artists from all over the world. The East Side Gallery opened in Berlin-Friedrichshain on 28 September 1990, and it is still one of the city's most popular sights.

The Wall has gone! Well, almost. The border posts have been torn down, but kilometres of concrete wall are still snaking through the city. East and West Germans and visitors from all over the world descend on Berlin in the hope of taking home a little piece of the Wall. They hack at the monstrous construction with hammers, chisels and pneumatic drills. The GDR's border guards and Bundeswehr take care of the rest. They tear down the Wall, the symbol of Germany's division.  

A symbol of separation becomes a work of art 

Just a few sections of the wall remain, including a long stretch on the banks of the Spree. In spring 1990, this provides the perfect canvas for artists from Germany and around the world.  

West Berliners have been covering the wall with their paintings and graffiti for years, but in the East people were kept away from the border by barbed wire and self-firing weapons. Now they have been given permission to paint by the GDR Council of Ministers.  

For six months, the area between Oberbaumbrücke and Ostbahnhof reeks of paint. 118 artists from 21 nations help to create the open-air gallery. The air is abuzz with different languages. In 1990 Berlin is on the move. Everyone is gripped by a mood of change; the city feels electric. The East Side Gallery provides a space for free expression.  

Freedom, peace, breaking down barriers - the artists immortalise these themes in their fantasy-filled paintings on the remains of the Wall. The concrete canvas stretches for 1.3 kilometres. The monument of terror is transformed into a vibrant work of art. Berlin's residents and visitors look on in amazement - as you are doing now.  

Trabis and fraternal kisses 

There's so much to see, from surreal images to political statements. Dimitri Vrubel depicts a brotherly kiss between Honecker and Brezhnev, while artist Birgit Kinder "makes dreams come true through painting" A Trabant smashes through the wall, symbolising East Germany's Peaceful Revolution of 1989. It's called Test the Best. On its journey to the West, the Trabi discovers the best of this new world. 

But the East Side Gallery quickly begins to crumble, attacked by souvenir hunters, vandals and air pollution. It has been restored regularly over the years. Some works have been sandblasted, others have been repainted and given a special coating. As of 2018, the Berlin Wall Foundation is to take over the maintenance and preservation of the East Side Gallery.
column12:
Freely accessible

For more information on this location, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/east-side-gallery
column13: Despite its protected status, the Gallery is fragile. Over the years, sections have been removed to make way for building projects. One of the figureheads of the ensuing protests is an American TV star: David Hasselhoff returns to Berlin almost 30 years after his legendary appearance at the New Year's Eve party of 1989. Once again, he sings his hit I'm looking for freedom - but this time at the East Side Gallery.

column8: 21GRAMM — NOURISHING ALL-DAY DINING IN SOULFUL SURROUNDINGS
column11: A cemetery perhaps isn’t where you’d expect to find a bustling, cozy eatery. Yet from morning coffee to a nightcap, 21gramm is here to satiate your thirst and hunger throughout the day — pulling off each menu at a consistency that’s rarely seen at its all-day-dining counterparts. We visited one evening in early autumn, and were torn between taking a seat in the charming brick courtyard — complete with string lights and blankets — or in the vaulted interior, which owners and friends Jeremias, Daniel and Tilmann painstakingly renovated, choosing to leave a few gothic-lettered passages of scripture on the walls in honor of the building’s original purpose as a chapel. Whenever you visit, it’s all about the platter here — think creative twists on the classic cheese and meat boards for brunch. From 18-22h, a simple evening menu turns an after-work glass of wine into dinner: Our salad with flambéed goat’s cheese and caramelized walnuts was full of flavor and paired perfectly with a glass of Jülg 2017 Grauburgunder. Oh, and the name? Yes, it references the alleged weight of the soul. (Text: Anna Dorothea Ker / Photos: Pamina Aichhorn)

column8: GO WEST FOR AN ESPRESSO AND AN ART-INFUSED FLAIR AT GIRO
column11: “Fare un giro means “to take a walk” in Italian. “There is no need to do that now, since we make our own giro here, everyday,” says Igor Paasch, former maître of Grill Royal and current owner of the small coffee bar Giro, located between Savigny- and Ernst-Reuter-Platz. At the bar, you can read newspapers, people watch and enjoy your shot of finest espresso. The coffee comes straight from the roastery of Willy Andraschko, former head of the legendary Café Einstein. Paasch himself is an artist; if you look closely, you will find a skull by Damien Hirst in the cafe which he designed together with the English artist. Art students from UdK are not the only customers here however, it has also become a popular place for many West Berliners. When you’re in this part of town, don’t forget to stop by for a little break, perhaps have an avocado panini and a glass of orange-ginger juice followed by, of course, some coffee. (Text: Laura Storfner / Photos: Loris Haller)

column8: GRASS IS THE NEW PINE: ADVENT & BLACK FRIDAY AT MARSANO
column11: This Advent, Marsano is swapping pine needle wreaths and the other usual festive deco suspects for a trans-seasonal concept. Inspired by pastoral German landscapes — as viewed from a train window this long, hot summer just gone: grasses are the hero material in its pre-Christmas offerings this year, some of which were hand collected on Sylt. The grass theme was not only chosen for its delightful aesthetic effect, but also with sustainability in mind: the wreaths last far past December, making for beautiful wall decorations well into the new year. Marsano’s candles abide by the same principle: their high-quality Swiss stumps have a burning time of around 180 hours. Tonight (22.11.2018, 17h) marks the official opening of the Advent exhibition: Now’s the time to nab the most beautiful wreaths (and enjoy a glass of wine). P.S. Should you stop by Friday, you’ll have the chance to take home a bit of non-floral deco, too — thanks to a Black Friday discount of 20% on all non-Christmassy objects, furniture and accessories. (Text: Nina Trippel / Photos: Anna Dorothea Ker)

column8: AGNONA APARTMENT: THE LUXURY ITALIAN LABEL’S FINE NEW HOME
column11: New season, fresh space: after a stint in the Beletage of its desirable Charlottenburg address, Italian fashion house Agnona has moved back into its original apartment on the ground floor — twice the size and fitted out with a new, opulent interior. Custom wall textiles in neutral tones, hand painted with delicate flowers complement Mid Century furniture and low lighting, allowing Agnona’s sartorial offerings room to breathe. The brand, which started out as a purveyor of fine fabrics to haute couturiers like Dior, Balenciaga and Yves Saint Laurent, has since become a prêt-à-porter label, today under the creative direction of Simon Holloway. In its new Berlin store — the “Agnona Apartment” — customers are invited to browse through items on gilded racks, take a seat on elegant low-slung seats to peruse hefty tomes of fashion photography for inspiration, and of course try on new season finds that catch their eye. Agnona’s Spring/Summer 2018 collection is a nod to the pastel world of David Hockney, and pops with vibrant gradients and California-inspired tones joining florals on kimono coats made from the world’s finest “Century Cashmere”, silk crêpe de chine and shiny viscose dresses. The look is relaxed, sensual and made for movement — embodying the kind of summer we want to have. (Text: Anna Dorothea Ker / Photos (clockwise, from left): Pamina Aichhorn, Agnona, Pamina Aichhorn)

column8: ALANNA LAGAMBA RECOMMENDS: LADIDADI WINES
column11: Have you ever walked into a wine shop and felt an instant sense of intimidation? You scan the aisles for a familiar label, walking aimlessly, trying to hide the fact that you know nothing about wine. You grab a bottle for its nice label and get the hell out of there. A quiet corner within the Umspannwerk, however, holds the answer: Ladidadi. Every Friday, this natural wine shop transforms into a tasting room, to which owner Florian Tonello invites winemakers, importers and connoisseurs to share their passion with enthusiasts and drink some awesome natural vino. These intimate events offer the opportunity not only to try a variety of wines, but also to learn more about the funky grape juice direct from the producers themselves. Let these wines guide your journey, maybe even through the rolling hills of Tuscany or Rheinhessen. Follow Ladidadi on Facebook to stay in the loop with who’s up next. (Text: Alanna LaGamba / Photos: Pamina Aichhorn)

column8: ANA NURIA SCHMIDT RECOMMENDS: BAR MARQUÉS
column11: I’m not a bar person. But ever since I went to Marques bar, located in the lower level of Restaurant Marqués (also highly recommended), I can’t think of a nicer way to spend a night than enjoying a couple of drinks here. The dim atmosphere reminds me of a classic hotel bar. The charming mixologistMarcus Wolff virtually reads your lips; there’s no menu and the drinks are custom-made according to the client’spreferences. Based on the idea of a classic cocktail, Wolff uses best quality ingredients including house-made pickled fruits and infused gins, and unites them all into enchanting drinkable masterpieces. Easy on the eyes and the taste buds.
column12: Ana Nuria Schmidt lives in Neukölln, is a fashion designer and also works as an assistant manager at Blush Lingerie.

column8: ANA SANTOS RECOMMENDS: BEKAREI — A BAKERY & CAFÉ
column11: Since I am Portuguese and love a good baked-good, I couldn’t help but fall in love with Bekarei in Prenzlauerberg. This Greek-Portuguese bread-and-sweets café-and-shop is the perfect place to enjoy a tasty Sunday breakfast. Some highlights include their American style pancakes and bacon, German breakfast plate, or Tiropitakia, a spinach cheese pastry. I highly recommend fortifying your morning with their beet root mix, a fruit-and-veggie smoothie. The bright color and the sweet flavor will immediately wake up your taste buds. The café’s charming interior should cheer you up too. In 2007 the two owners, Paula and George, took over a former GDR bakery and kept a touch of its 70’s flair. (Photos: Sasha Kharchenko)

column8: ANN-KATRIN SEIBEL RECOMMENDS: FELLFISCH CAFÉ & JEWELRY
column11: Certain people find areas of Neukölln intimidating; I even have a tote bag that reads “You are scared of Hermannplatz”. On the way to Fellfisch café, it seemed to me like Hermannplatz should be replaced by Hermannstrasse. However, once I had sat down at a beautiful wooden table with a bowl of ripe lemons in front of me, with the speakers humming relaxing background music, I remembered why I came here. It’s a tasty breakfast in the ultimate feel-good atmosphere. The vegan pastes, bread, apricot jam and other toppings are all homemade, and the eggs they serve are cooked to perfection. If you’re looking for a reason to stay after breakfast is finished, then you can browse through the postcards on offer from Paulina Gimpel, or the small jewelry display from owner Eva Fischer, who doubles as a goldsmith. For the lunch, and for the homemade cake, I shall most definitely come back another day. (Text: Ann-Katrin Seibel)

column8: ANN RICHTER RECOMMENDS: BOB’S POGO BAR AT KW
column11: There’s been an enigmatic addition to the Berlin underground scene this year, tucked away into a courtyard cellar at the KW Institute for Contemporary Art. It’s called Bob’s Pogo Bar, though it’s much more than a bar in the classical sense of the word. Bob’s is an installation, salon and theatre stage all at once. Designed by LA-based artist Robert Wilhite as part of the KW’s 2017 artistic program, the bar sees nocturnal animals meet oblique angles and elongated shadows. Opening its doors once a week (usually on a Thursday), Bob’s is taken over by an artist for an evening. The program — compiled by Maurin Dietrich and Cathrin Myer — ranges from sound performances and thematic dinners to short plays and spacial interventions, and is announced seven days in advance on the KW website. This week’s event, which exceptionally takes place on Friday (19.5.17), is a reading of Ishion Hutchinson’s “Trouble on the Road Again”. P.S. KW Friends and KW Lovers get exclusive access to all events taking place at Bob’s. (Text: Ann Richter / Photos (clockwise): Norbert Bayer / Frank Sperling, KW Institute for Contemporary Art)
column12: See program for event details. RSVP required.

column8: ANNA FIEDLER RECOMMENDS: CAFÉ KRAFT
column11: The founders Marco Prüfer and Jarves Drechsler have put a lot of hard work and love into this corner café in Prenzlauer Berg. Café Kraft is not only about the coffee, but also about the people who come here to enjoy it. Since March 2014, they have provided their neighborhood with high quality coffee, home-made cakes and fresh juices, with their motto being that it’s always better to do it yourself. This means that you won’t find a trendy New York cheesecake on the counter, but rather a more traditional German “Käsekuchen” made using an old family recipe. Even the fruits for the Kraft juices are collected by hand and taken to the fruit press directly, and the coffee cups are all self-designed. At the weekend the baristas serve breakfast, and every Sunday there is a new guest espresso in the grinder. If you like a great atmosphere, and a good brew, then you’ve found your next spot to visit this Easter weekend. (Text: Anna Fiedler / Photo: Daniel Farò)

column8: ANNA KÜFNER RECOMMENDS: DRINK NAKED
column11: I enjoy drinking wine, I really do. But, like with food, it’s a one-way-street: once you fall in love with the good stuff, there’s no going back. Since day one I’ve been a big fan of natural wine bar Jaja on Neukölln’s Weserstraße – still one my favorite places for casual drinking – and when their team announced the opening of a wine store in Mitte in May 2017, let’s just say I got quite excited. Drink Nakedcan be found in a small but gorgeous space on Linienstraße. Entering the cozy shop and tasting room with its wooden mid-century wine shelves, you will most likely meet the co-owner/very nice guy, Jeff. In addition to running Drink Naked, Jeff is also the brainchild behind Wine Rush — a fair and market for natural wine importers in Berlin, happening for the fourth time this Saturday (17.12.17). I spend a lot of time in wine stores, often not really knowing what I’m looking for, but I’m always curious to try new things and hear about a wine’s or a winemaker’s story: Maybe that’s the reason I feel at ease at Drink Naked. Jeff will ask you about your taste and opinion on wines you might have bought before, but never gives you the “Oh, they barely know anything about wine” look, making wine shopping and drinking what it should be: fun. (Text: Anna Küfner / Photos: Emilie Wade)

column8: ANTIPODES — NEW ZEALAND STYLE CAFÉ & HOMEMADE FOOD
column11: “Where are you from?”, I asked Jane and Paul. “From the antipodes! The opposite end of the world: Wellington, New Zealand,” they responded while serving a flat white with a big smile. Flat white is my favorite coffee drink here, espresso with only a bit of creamy milk sans deep philosophy or drama – just simply yummy like everything else they offer: avocado toast with lime, all egg dishes with or without bacon, and homemade cakes and cookies. Their yoghurt granola fruit breakfast is absolutely amazing. What else? For one, the stunning view of the Herz-Jesu church, but as for the rest you’ll have to find out for yourself (Text: Milena Kalojanov / Photos:Filine Fink)

column8: A NEW SPECIALTY COFFEE OASIS: % ARABICA COMES TO KREUZBERG
column11: It’s all too easy to walk right past % Arabica: There’s no advertising, no sign, not even a logo to draw attention to the beautiful new café that is tucked away in a Kreuzberg courtyard. A lack of customers is not something this place needs to worry about, however, as the company — originally from Japan — has built up an international reputation for serving an excellent cup of coffee. Founded in 2013 by Kenneth Shoji, % Arabica follows the third wave coffee movement, prioritising quality, taste and fair production conditions. This concept also applies to their small yet fine selection of food. Toasted banana bread with rhubarb compote or crispy granola with homemade yoghurt go great with an Americano, an espresso or a matcha latte. The next time you’re strolling down Reichenberger Straße and pass by number 36, take a peek into the courtyard — your curiosity will be rewarded. (Text: Lisa Staub / Photos: Pamina Aichhorn)
column12: P.S. Ahead of the Berlin Coffee Festival, % Arabica is organizing an espresso martini party on 30.8.2018 (19-21h), including a Ninety Plus Coffee tasting. RSVP by 28.8.2018.

column8: ARTHUR GROENEVELD RECOMMENDS: BIERHOF RÜDERSDORF
column11: You can hear the pumping bass from Berghain blending with the calming sound of a small water fountain at Bierhof Rüdersdorf – a place that is often overlooked, even by locals. Hidden in the surreal industrial surroundings behind Ostbahnhof, in the midst of home improvement center and supermarkets, in the shadow of the infamous Stalinistic Berghain, you’ll find this small oasis designed by the Berlin-based firm Karhard Architektur + Design. A mix of a bygone era and the contemporary, using pre-existing concrete structure with modern materials like stainless steel, Karhard gave this complex a stunning appeal. The Bierhof is completely open to the elements which make it a perfect summer hideaway. Order a beer, sit back and relax on the rooftop lounge chairs or chill out by the fireplace. Sundays attract a rather mixed crowd of families enjoying brunch and Berghain regulars taking a sunny break from the endless dancing. As for me, this is Berlin at it’s best! (Photos: Stefan Wolf Lucks)
column12: Arthur Groeneveld has lived in Kreuzberg since 2013 and runs A Guy Named Arturo, his creative agency and vintage label.

column8: ASTRID BRUCKMANN RECOMMENDS: CAFÉ 9 AT MARKTHALLE NEUN
column11: My heart skipped two beats in a day; first time when I saw this gem of a coffee shop next to Markthalle Neun, then again after trying their coffee with the perfect crema. I had noticed the empty spot long before they opened in August and had envisioned my dream coffee shop there. I never had the courage to realize it but Philipp Reichelt did – and how! He has turned this high-ceilinged room with large windows into one of the finest coffee shops in the vicinity of Oranienstrasse. Not only do they serve wonderfully prepared original blends, but customers are invited to test various blends created by other established baristas or try their special filtered coffee made with hand blown glass brewer. You’ll also conveniently find yummy treats from the Italianbakery by Alfredo Sironi there. (Photos: Aina Estruch Perlas)

column8: AUNT BENNY BAR — DRINKS ON TRAVEPLATZ AS THE SUN SETS
column11: From the beginning, owners Jeremy, Kyla and Alexander wanted Aunt Benny to be a place for locals and non-locals alike. The concept was simple; great coffee, a beautiful interior and an all-inclusive atmosphere. However, seemingly simple concepts are not always so easy to pull off. For Aunt Benny, in their eighth year of business, it’s fair to say they have excelled in this. Now, they want to apply the same concept to their small but perfectly formed bar. The second room was first opened as a dedicated cocktail bar, but after a small overhaul has now become a more friendly neighborhood location. It’s a place where time slows, where drinks are made with care, and where faces take on a soft glow from the hanging bulbs or the last rays of evening sunshine. Order a carefully-crafted cocktail, a simple bottle of wine or a pitcher of local Berliner Berg beer, pair it with a big bowl of nachos or the 13 hour slow-cooked pulled pork sandwich and you’ll have a pretty good night with friends or a partner in the making. There won’t be a better place in Friedrichshain to sit out until the sun goes down this summer. (Text: Chloe Galea / Photo: Daniel Farò)

column8: VIDEO ART, MUSIC AND DRINKS AT DAS GIFT
column11: The wooden interior is proof of the fact that “Das Gift” was once a typical German Eckkneipe (corner pub) that turned into a bar. The clientele has certainly changed since it evolved into “Das Gift”; Now there are lots of hip, arty and English-speaking folks who stop by – which is to no surprise since owners Rachel Burns and her husband Barry are both from Glasgow. Starting tomorrow you’ll find a collaborative video art installation there by Laetitia Ante Delictum, Susu Laroche, Elisabeth Owuor (to name a few), dealing with topics such as life, death, abyss, mythology and mysteries. In viewing works on these essential topics, perhaps you may be inclined to take a look at the drink menu from the bar. Zirndorfer beer, Scottish Ales, Wodka Wanessa (handmade Spelt Vodka from Austria), gin from Scotland or the Williams Ginger Beer sound pretty good to me.
column12: “An Enormous Abyss Opened Up Beneath Our Feet” Opening Fri 21.10, 20h, exhibition runs until 28.10.

column8: BALDON: DINE IN A BRUTALIST OASIS AT WEDDING’S NEW LOBE BLOCK
column11: There’s been a bit of a buzz around Wedding since the opening of Arno Brandlhuber’s mixed-use Lobe Block — a staggered concrete building in a quiet corner of Humboldthain that’s home to ateliers, studios, agencies, and apartments. Its resident restaurant and “platform for creative experiences” is Baldon, founded by Jessica-Joyce Sidon and Caecilia Baldszus (who trained in the kitchen at Forsthaus Strelitz), and currently serving a simple, vegetable-focussed lunch menu and all-day coffee during the week. Think Albatross sourdough with housemade Obatzda, Zwetschge plums, coriander and chili, carrot galette with melon and za’atar, or a pumpkin bowl with spinach, radicchio, dukkah, and tahini. Many elements here support local: Coffee beans come from the nearby Coffee Circle, The light-flooded interior is filled with sleek tables by Tatkraft in Reinickendorf, and two large-scale artworks by Peter Klare, whose studios are located in the Uferhallen, adorn the towering walls. (Text: Anna Dorothea Ker / Photos: Pamina Aichhorn)
column12:
Lunch & bar: Tue-Fri 9-18h
Dinner & bar: Thu from 18.30h
Brunch: Sat 11-16h
Follow on Instagram for updates.

column8: TGIF! EATING, DANCING & DRINKING AT THE NEUE HEIMAT
column11: The project Neue Heimat has been steadily evolving. The latest event series is their so-called Bar & Food Night. Every Friday from 20h, different bars show off their well-honed skills to prove what good drinks are all about. However, Neue Heimat’s own Bloody Mary booth is a haven on its own and the Riesling offered at their wine bar is just as divine. A shot of hazelnut schnaps by Fräulein Brösel is a must and the variations of Negroni created by the Hughel brothers are simply delightful, too. A broad program of music ranging from jazz to electronic beats is offered at the venue, including local talents like Soukie & Windish and Dada Disco; not surprising since the initiators Sebastian Baier, Danny Faber and Andreas Söcknick are the former owners of Bar 25 and Chalet. In terms of food, the pop-up restaurant by Schneeweiss, the Friedrichshain favorite for Alpine dishes, is superb but last time I was there I enjoyed a pastrami sandwich from Mogg & Melzer, seasonal Pieroggi by Pankowalski and visited the oyster bar by Ben Pommers. Eat, drink, dance and let the weekend begin! (Text: Eva Biringer / Photos:(f.l.t.r.) Sasha Kharchenko, Zoe Noble, Thang Dai)
column12: Bars participating tomorrow 29.10.2014: Stagger Lee, Melody Nelson, Booze Bar

column8: BAR ZENTRAL — A NEW NIGHTTIME FAVORITE IN THE WEST
column11: The regulars like to come through the back door, we heard. Well, no matter which entrance at Bar Zentral you choose, you will be standing in front of a huge wooden bar and a backdrop made of sophisticated black shelves – so you won’t have to stare at bottle logos all night long but are invited to concentrate on the lovely person next to you or your fine drink. That’s just one idea design studio Hidden Fortress came up with, who created the refined interior concept, with details that range from metal slats at the bar to the striking wall decoration in the restrooms. The drinks are perfectly mixed and the bartender might seem familiar to you, Max used to work at Würgeengel before. We enjoyed a perfect “Prince of Wales” and a superb “Wodka Collins” and other delicacies from the drinks menu and forgot all about time and space… Bar Zentral run by Torsten Bender and Sebastian Mathow definitely is the most exciting bar addition of 2015 in the West. We’ll be back. Probably through the back door…(Text: Nina Trippel / Photo: Daniel Farò)

column8: BARBARA RUSS RECOMMENDS: KIOSKO IL CALICE
column11: On the eastern edge of Walter Benjamin Platz stands a single chestnut tree, underneath which Enoteca Il Calice has set up a kiosk. Resembling a Parisian newspaper stand, it in fact offers Italian wines and cuisine. Placed around the “kiosko” are wine crate tables and wooden folding chairs. Gazing over the somewhat atypical yet peacefully quiet square, a symmetrical fountain on the west side catches my eye. Following the construction of the colonnades, architect Wolfgang Kil criticised their creators for having “built with great effort nothing more than “industrialized apartment blocks” from living stone”. I’m no specialist, but I do think this hidden part of Berlin provides space for contemplation. That’s why I like to come to Il Calice, read, have a glass of wine and enjoy the sun that bathes the square in light well into the evening. The philosopher Walter Benjamin, alas, had no affiliation to the square, as his family lived further south in Wilmersdorf. But I think he would have liked it. (Text: Barbara Russ / Photos: Il Calice)
column12: Barbara Russ is a freelance journalist and translator. After having lived in Paris, New York and most recently in Düsseldorf, she has (finally) moved back to Berlin and is busy exploring her new Charlottenburg-Wilmersdorf neighborhood.

column8: BREAKFAST AT BARCOMI’S: BAGELS IN THE BACKYARD AND CAKE TO GO
column11: Saturday, nine in the morning. Mitte is still asleep and it’s the best time to have breakfast by yourself at Barcomi’s. You can sit in the sun, have a salmon bagel, read the newspaper and drink some coffee in peace. The rush comes later, when you’re about ready to order a piece of cake to take home. Their selection is huge: everything from apple pie, carrot cake, cheesecake to chocolate marble cake. Before Cynthia Barcomi started baking, she actually wanted to become a dancer, but instead studied drama and philosophy. When Starbucks was still a foreign name in Germany, she decided that drama and brooding over theories are not her thing. So Barcomi opend her first café in 1994 and three years later a second one. She baked muffins and served brownies; and so she does to this day. Additionally she writes cookbooks, roasts her own coffee and has developed her own fine aluminum bakeware line. If you want to pull one of her sweet creations out of the oven, drop by either in the shop or online. (Text: Laura Storfner / Photos: Barcomi’s)

column8: BARETTINO COFFEE & PISTOLS — ITALIAN DELIGHTS IN REUTERKIEZ
column11: Djamila and Maria’s experience in gastronomy adds up to 15 years, they share four letters in their first names and now co-own a café called Barettino. Excellent coffee and Italian treats are served at the bar. The bread comes from an Italian stone oven, the cold cuts are sliced freshly in store, and the coffee beans are from a fair trade non-marketing organization. The interior matches Maria’s sneakers: classic with hints of green and pink, colorful yet comfy. Their menu too has lovely details. The panini sandwiches are named after mythological figures that give you clues as to what kind of flavor you may expect. Sometimes small open air concerts take place on Saturdays in front of the café with neighbors dropping by. People know one another in Neukölln but Barettino’s Facebook page will keep you updated. (Text & photos: Sascha Bente)

column8: BECCA CRAWFORD RECOMMENDS: DSCHUNGEL BAR
column11: Sauntering into Dschungel Bar in Neukölln, one becomes immediately immersed in a room buzzing with an intense jungle energy. On the way to claim a table, you’ll brush past repurposed tree trunks collected from all over the city. Distressed mirror tiles cover the ceiling, infinitely multiplying the expanse of vines and leaves that dangle above. Wallpaper depicts lush, tropical rainforests and if you peer carefully through the crowds, you might glimpse glistening white frogs that swim about in an aquarium. Dschungel’s signature cocktail, the “Nordflügel”, is my favorite, featuring rosemary, lemon, orange juice and beer syrup with an exclusive, small-batch gin crafted by a German distillery. It has laid the groundwork for many seductive summer evenings over the years, and pairs perfectly with the animated, yet relaxed vibes you’ll find at Dschungel. (Text & Photos: Becca Crawford)
column12: Becca Crawford is a photographer and creative content-maker specializing in food and lifestyle imagery. She moved to Kreuzberg from Sydney in 2014 and regularly features her work on her Instagram account.

column8: BELLMAN IN KREUZBERG: THE ALLURE OF THE NO-FRILLS BAR
column11: Bellman Bar is featured in our book Cee Cee Berlin No2. Get the book here.

column8: BERGSCHLOSS — THE HOME OF BERLINER BERG BREWERY
column11: The Rollberg neighborhood was once the center of the Berlin brewing industry. Uli, Finn and Robin have decided to continue this tradition with their brewery Berliner Berg, and in October 2015 opened their bar Bergschloss in Kopfstrasse. Their lovingly restored taproom is built inside the premises of an old lard factory; an impressive building, serving equally impressive drinks. However, the highlight from Berliner Berg will surely be their new brewing facility, scheduled to be completed in summer 2016. In preparation, however, brewer Richie has already created some delicious beers at other local establishments; his pale ale, Irish stout and lager can be tried at either Keith bar or Hopfenreich. Besides these craft beer classics, the Berliner Berg experts want to bring back a genuine Berliner Weisse beer. They will use a special historical recipe which will result in a straw-colored sparkling elixir with a white foam cushion. Prost! (Text: Helen von der Höden / Photo: (top) Daniel Farò)

column8: FINE COFFEE MEETS DELICIOUS CAKE AT FIVE ELEPHANT MITTE
column11: Coffee lovers of Mitte, rejoice! In December 2016, Kris and Sophie Schackman, owners of beloved Kreuzberg coffee roaster Five Elephant, opened a glitzy second branch on Alte Schönhauser Straße. You’d be forgiven, however, for feeling like you’re in Paris or Milan when you step inside its glossy white interior, the crowning glory of which is a custom-designed beige terrazzo counter. Fitted out with brass inlays and decorated with abstract shapes in rich jewel tones, it makes for a highly Instagrammable backdrop for the café’s drool-worthy array of cakes, pastries and whoopie pies. The tangy passionfruit tart pairs perfectly with an espresso or black filter coffee, though you may not want to go past Five Elephant’s beloved cheesecake — here all grown up in a round, not slice, form. For Berliners living or working north of the river, rest assured you no longer have to trek out to Kreuzberg for your top notch caffeine and sugar fix. (Text: Anna Dorothea Ker)

column8: BEYZA’S TEMPLE — A TREASURE TROVE OF ANATOLIAN KILIMS
column11: If you’ve ever dreamed of owning a kilim but don’t know where to start, look no further than Beyza’s Temple. With the aim of sharing the beauty and spirit of Anatolian culture, Beyza opened her store, the brick and mortar incarnation of her project “Wild Heart Free Soul“, in Kollwitzkiez in November 2017. Don’t be fooled by the modest exterior — once you open the door, you’ll step into a haven of vivid colours, patterns and textures. Kilims line the walls and floors while shelves display ceramics, crafts and traditional textiles that Beyza has been collecting during her regular travels to Turkey. The majority date from the mid-20th century and each one has been cleaned and meticulously restored by specialists in Istanbul — the full range is soon to be available via her online shop. Talking to Beyza is a pleasure; her wealth of knowledge is exceeded only by her passion for the craft, which she will happily share over a freshly prepared Turkish tea or coffee. She hosts occasional events in store with chefs, artists and musicians — follow her on Facebook or Instagram for the latest. (Text & Photos: Lucy Thorpe)

column8: BICHOU — FRENCH CLASSICS MADE WITH THE SEASONS
column11: Searching for a certain “Je ne sais quoi” in Berlin? Look no further than Neukölln’s Bichou, a French farmhouse eatery-cum-Parisian bistro that’s filling the area’s lunch gap with delicious, fresh and accessible food. You’ll be able to get acquainted with both owners — chef Thomas working in the open kitchen cooking and Marion greeting guests with a warm smile at the counter. Made with modern French cooking techniques, their caramelized tarte Tatin oozes tradition and their ever-changing quiches leave you wanting more. Marion and Thomas seek out the highest quality ingredients, and make nearly everything they can in house — even rolling their own oats for their granola. Plus, with a zero waste ethos, nearly nothing goes to waste. Similar to another Neukölln favorite, Isla Coffee, Bichou uses milk left from making coffees as a base for their milk jam — a perfect partner to their buttery “brioche à tête.” With a small weekly menu that features salads, soups, sandwiches and quiches, you’ll always be able to sample the season at Bichou. (Text & Photos: Emilie Wade)

column8: BLACK ISLE BAKERY: MINIMAL DESIGN MEETS MODERN PASTRY
column11: The latest doors to open on Mitte’s Linienstraße give way not to a gallery, but to a bakery that fits the contemporary art vibes of the neighborhood. Coming to Berlin by way of London, owner and baker Ruth Barry left her career in contemporary art publishing and started Black Isle Bakery in 2012 — naming it after the peninsula in the Scottish Highlands where she grew up. Over the past few years you may have tasted some of her cakes at cafés like Isla Coffee and Companion Coffee, but Barry always wanted to open her own shop. And that’s exactly what she’s just accomplished. The sleek gallery-like space features custom steel furniture finished with copper, silver and gold, allowing the bakery to literally shine. You’ll find classic sweet favorites like rich chocolate brownies sprinkled with flaky sea salt and Florentine cookies, but it’s the savory goods that will keep us coming back — from plump mushroom buns tinged with tarragon to eye-catching tomato short crust galettes. Expect the counter to change often, as Barry pays mind to both origin and season of her ingredients, making each baked treasure by hand in the open kitchen that she long dreamed of, and brought to life. (Text & Photos: Devan Grimsrud)

column8: BLACK SHEEP — CREATIVE VEGAN BAKING AND INCREDIBLE COFFEE
column11: Arriving at Black Sheep, yawning and sleepy at 8am, I struggle to understand why finding the milk is so difficult. It’s only when Audie, the friendly and talented barista who is one half of the team behind this place, points out the five different plant-based milks on offer (soy, oat, almond, coconut and rice milk) that I remember this café is 100% vegan. The Black Sheep team live and breathe this ethic, and use it as a creative springboard for exceptional food. I chose the almond cappuccino, and was served one of the best coffees I’ve had in Berlin. Audie explains the success of their partnership with The Barn, and how important it is to pair the right roast with the correct alternative milk. The food, created by the innovative and gifted chef Lucy, is just as delicious; from the incredible tempeh “bacon” and avocado bagel, to treats like the moreish snickers slices and the beetroot and almond brownie, and on to bigger and more filling dishes. As the only employees, the founders have worked full time since opening earlier this year, and this tireless dedication has resulted in a truly fantastic new café, which you just can’t miss. (Text: Antonia Harris / Photos: Daniel Farò)

column8: BONANZA COFFEE OPENS NEW KREUZBERG ROASTERY AND CAFÉ
column11: Anyone who has lived in Berlin is sure to know the little café at Oderberger Straße, constantly packed with happily sipping customers; Bonanza Coffee was partially responsible for igniting the third wave coffee hysteria here. It’s understandable, therefore, that for their 10th anniversary, the guys from Bonanza treated themselves to a shiny present: a new roastery and coffee shop located in a peaceful Kreuzberg courtyard. With an interior designed by Marick Baars, the listed metalwork and carpentry building now hosts a small shop area, a counter for ordering drinks and, needless to say, the roastery itself. The bright space is divided in two by a huge glass-panelled wall, allowing customers to peek behind the scenes as the staff roast, test and package their products. Their priority, however, remains the coffee itself, as they work with beans from a network of suppliers in countries such as Ethiopia, Colombia and Honduras. After carefully roasting their beans in a rebuilt 1965 Probat UG22, they serve it with specifically sourced milk in order to make that perfect, creamy flat white. (Text & Photo: Daniel Farò)

column8: BOURBON DOGS: A BAR WHERE HOT DOGS MEET WHISKEY
column11: Limp buns and bland dogs smothered in mustard, mayo, ketchup, and fried onions: in Berlin, the hot dog ekes out a miserable existence in Swedish furniture stores. But now Kreuzberg’s Bourbon Dogs is taking things to the next level – in six different varieties created by Chef Max. Behold: tasty potato buns from Bekarei meet premium sausages from “the sausage man who never sleeps.” There’s Asian, Mexican, and classic Chicago style to name only three, and a fantastic selection of drinks to accompany them, with some darn good rye whiskey at center stage. High-quality products and Max’s enthusiasm assure the high standard of the overall concept. It’s everything you need for a perfect night at the bar. Bourbon Dogs opened in late August 2015 and was only meant to be a pop-up bar, but because of the success luckily it’s now here to stay! (Text: Helen von der Höden / Photo: Laura Droste)

column8: BRUS: TANK-TO-GLASS BREWPUB — NOT JUST FOR BEER NERDS
column11: Situated within a renovated iron foundry on what might just be Copenhagen’s hippest street, find Brus: an eclectic bar with an onsite brewery and a backdrop of oak barrels. The enormous brewpub has a lively and leisurely feel that will make you either sink into its oak-panelled booths, nerd out at the bar with front-row seats to the shiny serving tanks or enjoy the late evening rays on the outdoor beer benches. Less experimental than Mikkeller’s brews but all the more drinkable, Brus’ selection ranges from their refreshing and tart Santa Rabarbera made with Berliner Weisse, rhubarb and mandarin, to malty American Brown Ale, to an imperial carrot cake stout with deep caramel notes and a creamy top hat of foam. A neat extra: The team behind Brus also serves cocktails on tap made with in-house distilled spirits and craft tonic – including the Verbenator made with lemon verbena, apple and vodka – which the team swears by, and so do we. Before you leave, get a souvenir: The shop has a nice selection of guest beers and local talent for the road. (Text: Victoria Pease / Photos: Brus)

column8: BRUTAL 54 FOR TASTY DRINKS IN A LIVELY SETTING — RECOMMENDED BY GEORGIE POPE
column11: Since summer 2019 this cocktail bar has been the talk of the town, or at least Kreuzkölln. Brutal 54 was a previously hidden speakeasy, but its space in the Hobrechtstrasse is now open for all. Co-owners Silvan and Maarten transformed the former Raumfahrer bar into a sleek and concept-strong interior with beautiful lighting. Here, less is more, and the surroundings ooze with as much taste as the cocktail list. As a firm lover of both whisky and sake, one of my favorite concoctions brings these together with real panache, topping it off with a garnish of frozen kaffir lime leaves. Come to Brutal at the weekend and you’ll find the space absolutely buzzing. You can definitely arrive unaccompanied and find a space inside to call your own, settling down with a fresh and potent negroni. If it’s a casual weeknight beer you prefer, the bar seats provide the perfect perch. (Text: Georgie Pope / Photos: Savannah van der Niet)

column7: Bttr (Back to the Roots) — Adaptogenic Drinks
column8: BTTR — BACK TO THE ROOTS: STAY HEALTHY WITH FRESH JUICES, ADAPTOGENS & HOUSE-MADE MYLK
column11: In January 2018, Janne Kaas opened a different kind of café on Kotti. Her mission: Share homemade, healthy drinks, original flavors and bring balance back into your life. Back to the Roots (Bttr) is a café (almost) without coffee or milk, but full of concentrated plant power and passion. In her glass kitchen, Janne produces lovingly made, fresh cold-pressed juice, vitalizing shots and creamy nut mylks enriched by Sun Potion supplements and superfoods, with tonifying herbs, aka adaptogens. Janne has an extensive knowledge of how these different herbs, fruits and vegetables improve well-being, and she’s thrilled to share it with you. A favorite from the menu is a juice with pear, fennel, sage and lemon. Another is the hazelnut mylk, which you can bring home or enjoy in a warm Golden Mylk with turmeric, cardamom, nutmeg and reishi. Or try the Coldbrew Latte with cardamom, coconut sugar and Good Spirits Cold Brew. Let’s get bttr! (Text: Lisa Strube / Fotos: Mina Aichhorn)

column8: READ AND EAT — FINE BAGELS AT SHAKESPEARE AND SONS
column11: The Fine Bagels café was meant to be a small addition to the bookstore Shakespeare and Sons, yet it has become a reason of its own to visit the place. Laurel, the owner of Fine Bagels, uses family recipes to create what she was missing in Berlin: authentic homemade bagels. She makes them NY-style, cold and slow-rising overnight, water-boiled, and then baked fresh every day. There are plenty of options, whether you like sweet or savory, with meat, veggie or vegan toppings. Classics like homemade hummus, peanut butter, avocado or goats cheese feature alongside cream cheese and smoked salmon, with optional vegan cream cheese. Laurel’s personal favorite is called “Lunch for Meshka”, a mix of cream cheese, lox, capers, and red onions. We tried almost every combination at the Cee Cee office and are truly addicted!
