But this afternoon he's due to move across the street - into the Reich Chancellery.

"What does Wilhelmstraße say?" This is the question European diplomats have been asking since the middle of the 19th century. Wilhelmstraße has been synonymous with political power since Bismarck, like Downing Street in London or the Quai d'Orsay in Paris. Wilhelmstraße has been the site of the official residence of the German head of state, the Reich President, since 1919. Now the National Socialists are taking over the Weimar Republic ministries that they so detest. But they don't only want to occupy these historic buildings. The new government is also planning to construct buildings that will reflect its grip on power.  

From democracy to dictatorship - the Wilhelmstraße History Mile 

The new Reich Chancellery, the Ministry of Propaganda, the Ministry of Aviation - three monumental government buildings are built on Wilhelmstraße over the next few years. Wilhelmstraße is now a corridor of power wrapped in red swastika flags. It is like a huge political stage, hosting regular mass rallies and parades. Most days, a crowd of onlookers gathers in the hope of catching a glimpse of Adolf Hitler. They shout up to the balcony of the Reich Chancellery: "Dear Führer, please show yourself at the window!". 

Little is left 

The Ministry of Propaganda and the Ministry of Aviation are the only National Socialist government buildings built after 1933 to survive the war. Most of the older buildings, the palaces and ministerial buildings of the government quarter are destroyed by Allied air raids during the Second World War, by street battles when it ends, and by demolition in the post-war period. 

The Wilhelmstraße History Mile open-air exhibition has 32 information boards providing details about the street's most important buildings. If you stand in Wilhelmplatz, you are approximately half way along the 2,400-metre-long History Mile. From here you really can see how dramatically the street has changed. You will no longer find a square surrounded by buildings. The Topography of Terror exhibition on Wilhelmstraße is close by. A model of the city explains how the apparatuses of power and terror were closely entwined under the Nazi regime.
column13: The building at 54 Wilhelmstraße mirrors the history of Germany since 1899. Post-war Chancellor Konrad Adenauer lived here, as did Adolf Hitler's deputy, Rudolf Heß. In the GDR era it was occupied by students. Today it is used by employees of the Federal Ministry of Food and Agriculture.

column8: In the Bauhaus-Archiv, you can explore the world's largest collection on the history of the Bauhaus.
column11:
The archive of a global art movement
The Bauhaus has gained mythical status - and not only among architecture buffs. The list of names associated with the Bauhaus revolution in architecture, art and design in the twentieth century include such luminaries as Walter Gropius, Ludwig Mies van der Rohe, Wassily Kandinsky, Marcel Breuer, Paul Klee, Johannes Itten, Marianne Brandt and Gunta Stölzl.

At present, the museum is closed. The main building is being refurbished and an annex by architect Volker Staab is under construction. The museum is scheduled to reopen in 2020. Until then, the collection is on show in the temporary Bauhaus-Archiv Museum für Gestaltung Charlottenburg. 

Functional designs for daily use

In 1919, the architect Walter Gropius establishes the Bauhaus in Weimar as a college of art and design. He adopts many of the principles and methods advocated by Henry van de Velde at the School of Arts in Weimar. At the Bauhaus, inspired by the idea of the medieval masons' guild, teachers (known as 'masters') and students (known as 'apprentices') seek to develop a new synthesis of the arts and crafts. In the Bauhaus training, the emphasis is on a new style of architecture, breaking with the historicist revivalist styles dominant in Germany at that time. As in the Deutscher Werkbund association of artisans, designers, artists and architects, the Bauhaus teachers and students create works and designs for production in series. Their goal is to make functional products for daily life affordable for all.

In 1925, with growing political and financial pressure from populist nationalist parties and the local government in Thuringia, the Bauhaus moves to Dessau. But some years after the move, the Bauhaus faces a similar situation again. In 1931, the Nazi Party wins a majority in the Dessau city council and forces through a resolution to close the Bauhaus the following year. In 1932, the Bauhaus moves to Berlin's Lankwitz district. This, though, is just an interlude. After the Nazi Party's seizure of power in early 1933, the political repression culminates in the Bauhaus being forced to close entirely. The dramatic developments in the last phase lead many of the Bauhaus students and teachers to emigrate.

Fast forward to 1955 and the opening of the Academy of Design in Ulm. There, art historian Hans Maria Wingler meets Bauhaus founder Walter Gropius. Wingler is fascinated by the history of the Bauhaus, and avidly collects Bauhaus documents and objects. In 1960, he establishes the Bauhaus-Archiv. Initially, the collection is to be presented in Darmstadt in a dedicated building designed by Gropius in 1964. However, due to lack of funding, this design is never built.

When the state of Berlin offers to host the institution, the Bauhaus-Archiv moves to the city. From 1971, the archive is provisionally housed in Charlottenburg, in the building now home to the Bröhan-Museum for art nouveau, art deco, and functionalism. Berlin had already agreed to finance a new building and provide a site - in Klingelhöferstraße, along the Landwehr Canal in Berlin's Tiergarten district. By then Walter Gropius has died, but his original design is modified for the new site by his former colleague Alexander Cvijanovic.

The Bauhaus-Archiv/Museum für Gestaltung finally opens in 1979. Since then the holdings have steadily grown, but the heart of the collection remains the personal papers and artistic estates, with their draft designs, manuscripts, and letters, originally collected by Hans Maria Wingler. The mission of the Bauhaus-Archiv/Museum für Gestaltung is to locate the history, practices and impact of this avant-garde movement of art, design and architecture in its international context.
column13:
The Bauhaus-Archiv building still retains the memorable silhouette with shed roofs from Walter Gropius's original 1964 design. These distinctive roofs provide lighting inside the building without bright sunlight or hard shadows. The solution is simple and functional. But hardly surprisingly, given its rather futuristic look, Berlin's Bauhaus-Archiv was chosen as a location for filming the American sci-fi movie Æon Flux.
,

column8: A bus stop reminds us about the people who organised the extermination of the Jews
column11:
The home of a Jewish charity becomes Adolf Eichmann's office
Adolf Eichmann is sitting in his second-floor office in Kurfürstenstraße. On 6 March 1942, he is meeting representatives of various state bodies to discuss the forced sterilisation of "half-Jews". In this building, the Office of Jewish Affairs, civil servants are organising and coordinating the murder of Jews throughout Europe.

Every five minutes, a number 100 bus drives past 115/116 Kurfürstenstraße. Bus route 100 is known as the tourist route because it goes past many of Berlin's main sights. But passengers rarely get off at Schillstraße because the attraction is actually the bus stop itself. It's the only bus stop memorial in Berlin. Information boards and photos tell people about the building that stood behind today's bus stop around 1940. 

A hotel was built on the site in the 1960s. The original building was built in 1910 to house a Jewish charity. This acted as a community centre where Jewish people could seek advice on everyday problems and attend plays and concerts. 

First take their freedom, then take their life 

The Nazis confiscate the building in 1939. In 1940 a Gestapo department, the Office of Jewish Affairs, moves into the building on Kurfürstenstraße. It soon becomes known as "Eichmann's office" after the department's head, Adolf Eichmann. 

This is where the Nazis organise the deportation of the Jews. It also issues specific directives affecting Jewish citizens who are still in Germany. The Office of Jewish Affairs orders Jews to wear the Star of David, prohibits them from using public transport and demands that they hand over their bicycles and cameras. Each directive chips away at their lives, removing another piece of their freedom. 

By March 1941, the Office of Jewish Affairs has new objectives. Now Eichmann's office is responsible for organising the annihilation of Europe's Jews. By the end of the war, six million people have been murdered in Nazi concentration and extermination camps. 

Adolf Eichmann's department is involved in every aspect. His staff coordinate the transportation of Europe's Jews to the labour and extermination camps. It is this department that ensures one of the greatest crimes in history runs like clockwork. 

Eichmann's office organises these deportations to the camps until the spring of 1945. After the war Eichmann flees to Argentina. The Israeli secret service track him down in 1950 thanks to the investigative work of Fritz Bauer, the Hesse district attorney. The key organiser of the Holocaust is sentenced to death in Jerusalem. 

The building in Kurfürstenstraße survives the war almost intact but is demolished in the 1960s to make way for the hotel that stands here today.
column13: Harry Kindermann survives thanks to a stroke of luck. Adolf Eichmann needs skilled workmen to build a bunker under his office building. Jews are also conscripted to carry out the work. Harry isn't really a skilled worker, but his father tells them he's a bricklayer. They both escape deportation and survive because they are allowed to work for the Reich Main Security Office.

column7: Ministry of Public Enlightenment and Propaganda
column8: The radio, one of Goebbels' key propaganda channels, calls for final victory even as the regime falls
column11:
Manipulation instead of freedom of thought
9 November 1944. Thousands of locals are heading for Wilhelmplatz square. Some are carrying weapons, most are in civilian clothes. Young and old - grandfathers and grandsons. Many fathers and sons are still fighting on the front. Joseph Goebbels walks out onto the Propaganda Ministry balcony. On Voßstraße, Hitler's massive Reich Chancellery dominates the skyline. A vast banner hangs down the Propaganda Ministry façade. The message it bears is written large: "Our Militia Fights for the Life and Freedom of Greater Germany!" Underneath, Goebbels looks down at the waiting crowds. Then, he walks over to the microphone.

The Third Reich's military defeat has been certain for months. But the Nazi leadership is determined to fight to the last drop of blood. Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels is the "Reich Commissioner for Total War Mobilisation". He calls for unconditional sacrifice from the Volkssturm - the euphemistic name for a national militia comprising an army of badly equipped children and old men. Cannon fodder for Hitler's bloody final stage of the war.

Freedom of opinion in chains 

Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels belongs to the old guard of the Nazi party, joining in the very early years. In 1926, Hitler entrusts Goebbels with a challenging task. Goebbels is appointed Gauleiter (district leader) of Berlin. With the support of the local SA "Brownshirts", he begins to create and expand a Nazi power base in Germany's capital city, known as a left-wing bastion of social democrats and communists. With the Nazi seizure of power in 1933, he achieves his initial goal. Now, Goebbels aspires to a seat in Hitler's cabinet with his own ministry - and becomes head of the Ministry of Public Enlightenment and Propaganda, one of the Nazi regime's key pillars. He can now sway public opinion almost at will.

The ministry's key tasks are the control of the entire German media - the press, broadcasting, visual arts, film and theatre. It is no longer possible to freely form an opinion. Aware of the power of wireless as a propaganda channel, Goebbels makes production of the affordable Volksempfänger ("people's receiver") a priority. In no time, the locals have nicknamed this radio the Goebbelsschnauze, which roughly translates as "Goebbels' gob" - and it lives up to its name with an unbroken stream of propaganda.

Wilhelmplatz square disappears

In 1933, the Propaganda Ministry moves to Wilhelmplatz square into a large town house known as the Ordenspalais - the Palace of the Order of St. John. But with staff numbers rapidly growing, the building soon proves too small. Until shortly after the outbreak of war, architect Karl Reichle oversees a new monumental building with a series of annexes. Wilhelmplatz serves the Nazis as a central destination for their marches. Here, massed crowds also gather to listen to speeches by Goebbels and Hitler.

Towards the end of war, much of the complex is destroyed in bombing raids. The reconstruction has primarily focused on the tract of buildings designed by Reichle. When East Germany is founded, the building houses the National Front of the German Democratic Republic, a satellite party of the ruling SED. This also becomes the official residence of Wilhelm Pieck, the first president of the GDR. Today, the Federal Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs (BMAS) uses the sections of buildings once housing the Nazi Propaganda Ministry. Wilhelmplatz square, as shown on the historic photo, no longer exists.
column12: Federal Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs (BMAS); not open to the public.
column13: Goebbels is also responsible for the film industry - and renowned for his scores of affairs. At Babelsberg Studio, just outside Berlin, the state-controlled UFA company produces many of the movies. Reputedly, hardly any actress there is safe from the "randy old goat of Babelsberg", as Goebbels is nicknamed - at least, until Hitler decides this is harmful to the party, and orders Goebbels to clean up his act.

column8: Once a home to art and scholarship, later a site of Nazi terror and persecution
column11:
The site of Nazi institutions of terror
This is not a site of freedom. This was the location of the central Nazi institutions of terror. From 1933, those brought here, violently taken into custody, had no hope. The site comprises the Gestapo headquarters and Security Service, and later the Reich Security Main Office of the notorious SS. Today, you can explore the history of the site at the Topography of Terror exhibition.

A place of terror  

The area around Wilhelmstraße develops from the eighteenth century. Before 1933, it can boast elaborate town residences, the ethnological museum, an Arts and Crafts College and the exclusive Hotel Prinz Albrecht. Prussia's renowned architect Karl Friedrich Schinkel and landscaper Peter Joseph Lenné design the adjacent square.  

On 8 November 1934, Reich SS Leader Heinrich Himmler takes over the Hotel Prinz Albrecht with his personal command staff. Himmler also moves the SS Administrative Main Office here as well as the SS Central Office and the SS Personnel Main Office. The Prinz Albrecht complex, as it is called, is home to the Gestapo headquarters, the SS Security Service and later the SS Reich Security Main Office. Himmler is a leading figure in the Nazi hierarchy. He systematically fights all those critical of the Nazi regime. As Reich SS Leader and Chief of the German Police, Himmler plays a key role in supporting Hitler's machinery of power. From here, with its system of concentration camps, the Nazi regime implements its policies of the persecution and extermination of political and "racial" opponents in the German Reich and occupied territories. Here too, plans are forged for the mass murder of European Jews and the war of ideologies and extermination in eastern and south-eastern Europe. 

Today, no buildings are left on the site from the pre-war period. Instead, the site is home to an exhibition and a Documentation Center. Go through the main entrance to the Topography of Terror exhibition next to the Martin-Gropius-Bau building, and walk down the steps. You are now standing in the former Prinz-Albrecht-Palais basement. Almost as soon as Hitler seizes power, these cells are packed with political prisoners. The Gestapo have 38 solitary cells and one communal cell in their headquarters, and often use brutal torture methods to interrogate the prisoners. In the twelve years of the Nazi regime, over 15,000 prisoners pass through these cells. After interrogation, many of the prisoners are sent to the concentration camps. 

The traces of the past 

Take a look behind the Martin-Gropius-Bau building. Here too there are traces of Berlin's history. You can see the remains of former buildings on the site and the prison walls. At the end of the little used path through a copse of locust trees, you can find the remains of two monumental structures for the Reich Security Main Office.
column12:
Opening hours: 
Monday to Sunday 10am - 5pm

For more information on this location, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/topography-terror
column13: In the 1970s, the wind of freedom blows across this site of terror. Especially for car drivers wanting to practice - with or without a licence. Harry Toste, a real Berlin eccentric nicknamed "Straps Harry" (roughly "Harry the Garters"), uses the site for his Autodrom driving track. The narrow-paved roads through the copse of trees date from his day. And for wannabe drivers looking for a break from the track, Harry could offer a visit to his "Dream Boys Lachbühne", his own drag theatre. Just another example of Berlin freedom.

column8: In the face of death, people retain their dignity, steadfastly facing Nazi despotism
column11:
Arbitrary proceedings and open terror
The plenary hall ceiling is decorated with symbols of truth, justice and freedom. But justice and freedom are not on the agenda today in the plenary hall of the Court of Appeal at Kleistpark. The People's Court meets here on 21 August 1944. The accused are said to be conspirators in an attempt to assassinate Hitler on 20 July. Roland Freisler, President of the People's Court, raises his arm in a Nazi salute. Ulrich Wilhelm Count Schwerin von Schwanenfeld, one of the accused, is led into the room. The trial begins.

The Volksgerichtshof (People's Court) 

In 1934, the Nazi regime establishes a "People's Court" to "combat the enemies of the state". The court is set up in the wake of the Reichstag fire trial in late 1933. There, the presiding judge in the Reichtsgericht, the highest German court, acquits four of the five accused. Hitler is furious, and decrees that future cases of treason can only be heard by the People's Court - a new political court. At first, the court is housed in the Prussian state parliament building. In 1935, it moves to a former school building at Potsdamer Platz. But in July 1944, Roland Freisler, President of the People's Court, asks for a prestigious building as a showplace for the trials of those involved in the plot against Hitler's life. The building at Kleistpark housing the Court of Appeal dates from the Wilhelmine period. The entrance is daunting, a symbol of authority. The main hall is resplendent and large.  

Hitler has no doubts about Roland Freisler, who is well-known as a "hanging judge". He will "...make sure it all goes smoothly." After all, Hitler's loyal rabble-rouser has been President of the People's Court since 1942, mercilessly passing down the sentences Hitler wants. For the trial against the conspirators in the assassination attempt, the Nazis come up with a special idea - a camera secretly filming the trial through a small hole in the swastika flag behind Freisler. The film material shows Freisler screaming at the accused, mocking and humiliating them.  

For freedom - with composure and dignity 

When Count Schwerin von Schwanenfeld tries to explain the reasons for his actions, Roland Freisler screams at him, "You really are a low scoundrel!". The film material is never released. Goebbels and the Nazi propaganda machine want scenes of the accused breaking down under Freisler's merciless contempt and ridicule. Yet despite Freisler's vitriolic performance, they seek to retain their composure and dignity.  

The People's Court also sentences Count Schwerin von Schwanenfeld to death. Between 1934 and 1945, the People's Court hands down sentences in 18,000 cases. The court's horrific record includes around 5,000 death sentences. One perversion of justice after another by the Nazis supported by lawyers and judges sympathetic to their cause creates a regime of open terror. 

Freisler dies during an air raid on 3 February 1945. The court house in Bellevuestraße is hit, and he is buried under falling masonry. The building is totally destroyed and never rebuilt. Today, the site is marked by a memorial plaque in the ground commemorating the victims of the People's Court.  

The Court of Appeal at Kleistpark survives the bombing raids. Initially, the Russian army liberating the city uses the building as a pigsty. Soon afterwards, it provides the setting for the constituent meeting of the International Military Tribunal of the Nuremberg trials. It also becomes the seat of the Allied Control Council until 1948. Today, it is once again home to the Berlin Court of Appeal.
column13: Selected civilians and soldiers are allowed to watch the trial of the accused in the assassination attempt against Hitler. On 7 September 1944, those present include Helmut Schmidt, later West German Chancellor. Shocked by Freisler's tirades, Schmidt asks his commanding officer to be relieved of his position as trial observer.

column8: A U-boat commander becomes a pastor and Hitler's personal prisoner
column11:
Hitler’s personal prisoner
The Gestapo are standing in his living room. On the fateful morning of 1 July 1937, Father Martin Niemöller, one of the founders of the Confessing Church, has no choice but to go with the Gestapo. He is taken to Moabit remand prison. "Now crush him so that he can't hear or see. Never let him go", says propaganda minister Goebbels. Six months later Niemöller is on trial for sedition.

Martin Niemöller's life has been full of twists and turns. The son of a Protestant pastor, he became a U-boat commander in the First World War. In 1931 he was appointed pastor of Dahlem, a suburb of Berlin. At first he welcomes the Nazi's accession to power in 1933, but later objects to their interference in church affairs. Together with Dietrich Bonhoeffer and other pastors, Niemöller sets up the Pfarrernotbund, an organisation of pastors to combat discrimination against Christians and Jews. They also establish the Confessing Church, a Protestant group that opposed the Nazification of Germany's Protestant churches. As Christians, they are opposed to totalitarianism, the appropriation of the Gospel for political purposes, and the Nazis' racial ideology. Niemöller is a threat to Hitler, so he's arrested and put on trial. 

On 2 March 1938, he is sentenced to seven months in prison, but his time at the remand prison is taken into account, so he is free to go. Hitler is furious. Niemöller's family are waiting for him outside the prison gates, but the Gestapo smuggle him out of the back and take him to Sachsenhausen concentration camp. 

Martin Niemöller becomes a "personal prisoner of the Führer". But he's better off than most of the other prisoners. Joseph Goebbels says: "Niemöller should eat well and get fat so no-one can continue to call him a martyr. But he is not to be let loose on mankind." 

Thousands of protest letters are sent to the Chancellery, but the Nazis won't let him go. In 1941 Niemöller is transferred to Dachau, where he is liberated by American soldiers shortly before the end of the war. 

Martin Niemöller has become a pacifist. He criticises the establishment of the Federal Republic of Germany and opposes rearmament. In the USA, school children learn the now famous words of Pastor Niemöller: "First the Nazis came for the Communists and I did not speak out, because I wasn't a Communist. Then they locked up the Social Democrats and I did not speak out, because I wasn't a Social Democrat. Then they came for the trade unionists and I did not speak out, because I was not a trade unionist. Then they came for me - and there was no one left to speak for me." 

You are standing in front of Martin Niemöller's parsonage in Dahlem. It hardly changed since it was built in 1910. It reopened in June 2018 after renovations. In the 1980s it was turned into a centre for peace and education.  

Today, the historic building is a place of learning and a memorial to the Protestants who resisted the Nazis. Along with St Anne's Church, the churchyard and the parish hall, the parsonage is a tangible reminder of dark days in German history.
column12:
No regular opening hours
Visits by arrangement
column13: In 1980, Rudi Dutschke's widow was desperately looking for a grave for her husband. After several refusals, Gretchen Dutschke approaches St Anne's Church cemetery in Dahlem. Only one grave is free, but it's reserved - for Reverend Martin Niemöller himself. But he willingly gives it up. Niemöller is buried in his native Westphalia in 1984.

column8: In an impressive lakeside villa, the Nazis plan the genocide of the European Jews
column11:
Organising the genocide of the European Jews
We are in front of one of the magnificent villas along the Wannsee lake. It is Tuesday, 20 January 1942 - and very cold. With temperatures around minus 13 Celsius, the lake is frozen. The garden is covered in a white layer of snow. From here, you have a view over the water to the bathing beach on the opposite shore. The smell of freshly-brewed coffee wafts over from the mansion's kitchen. There is fine cognac and cigars waiting for the guests. But first, there is work to be done. The letter of invitation is for "a meeting, to be followed by lunch". The meeting, planned for 90 minutes, is to coordinate policies on the destruction of the European Jews.

This meeting goes down in history as the Wannsee Conference. The host is Reinhard Heydrich, Head of the Security Police and Security Service. The lakeside villa is originally owned by an industrialist. In 1941, Heydrich arranges for it to be bought and turned into a guest house for the SS. On 20 January 1942, Heydrich is waiting for 15 high-ranking civil servants, State Secretaries and SS functionaries. Heydrich opens the meeting at noon. He begins by announcing his appointment as "Plenipotentiary for the Preparation of the Final Solution of the European Jewish Question". All the points on the agenda deal with the "Final Solution", the genocide of the European Jews. But that genocide is not decided at this meeting - it is already in full swing. 

The machinery of death is running flat out. Here, Heydrich's aim is to perfect the organisation and coordination of the "Final Solution" under his leadership. During the meeting, the participants clarify responsibilities for deportations and the procedures in the occupied territories. They discuss what to do with the estimated eleven million Jews across Europe, both in countries occupied by the German forces as well as those not yet invaded.  

The minutes of the Wannsee Conference leave no doubt about the fate of the Jews. They are to be "utilized for work in the East in an expedient manner", primarily for building roads. During that time, a "large proportion will no doubt drop out through natural reduction". The "remnant [...] will require suitable treatment; because it will without doubt represent the most [physically] resistant part". 

The meeting ends after 90 minutes. Later, Adolf Eichmann reported that it was conducted very quietly and with much courtesy, with much friendliness - nicely and politely. Eichmann is head of the Department of Jewish Affairs in the Gestapo, and takes the minutes of the meeting. Now, the meeting is over and it's time for the meal and a cigar.  

The key document  

The 15-page minutes of the meeting are on show in the dining room of the villa, today the House of the Wannsee Conference, Memorial and Educational Site. Eichmann's minutes are a key document on the organisation of the genocide of the European Jews - but one very nearly denied to posterity. Thirty copies of the minutes are prepared, all bearing a stamp reading "Secret Reich Matter", the equivalent of "Top Secret". Shortly before the end of the war, those responsible decide to destroy these incriminating documents. Just one copy survives - given to Martin Luther, who represented the Foreign Office at the Wannsee Conference. Luther falls from grace and, from 1943, is interned in the Sachsenhausen concentration camp. His documents are confiscated to prepare the case against him - which is why they survive. Today, the original copy of the minutes is in the Foreign Office archive, in the vaults of the former Reichsbank.
column12:
Opening hours:
Monday to Sunday 10am - 6pm

For more information on this location, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/house-wannsee-conference
column13: The Wannsee Conference has been filmed twice, once as Die Wannseekonferenz (1984), a German TV production, and once as Conspiracy (2001), an American-British co-production. Filmed at the original location, both productions keep to a length of almost exactly 90 minutes, the actual time taken for the Wannsee Conference meeting.

column8: The last free speech in the Reichstag is a courageous challenge to the Nazi dictatorship
column11:
Democrats by conviction
23 March 1933. SA and SS troops march through the main hall of the Kroll Opera House. After the Reichstag building burns down on 27 February, the German parliament is moved just a few hundred metres to this former theatre and opera house. Swastika flags hang from the ceiling, the sound of marching boots resounds through the hall. The inaugural meeting of the newly elected German parliament is about to start.

In this meeting, the Reichstag members strip themselves of their powers. Some have already fled the Nazis, others are arrested. The governing coalition of Hitler's National Socialists and the German National People's Party, the Centre Party, Bavarian People's Party and the German State Party all vote for the Enabling Act. This act, officially entitled "Law to Remedy the Distress of People and Reich", suspends the democratic constitution of 1920s Germany. It grants Hitler and his government extensive power and is the basis for all the Nazi regime's legislation. 

The last free speech in the Reichstag parliament 

Shortly before 6 pm, Otto Wels, leader of the Social Democratic Party (SPD), stands up to speak. "You can take our lives and freedom, but you cannot take our honour." It is the last free speech in the Reichstag. His words are applauded by the few SPD representatives in the hall. In this difficult hour, they fight for their democratic convictions. From the rows of the Nazi party delegates, the only sound is derisive laughter. The SPD is the only party that refuses to vote for the Enabling Act. The Communists would also have voted against Hitler, but many are already arrested. They have been stripped of their seats in parliament "by decree". Almost immediately after the Enabling Act is passed, the SPD is banned. 

After his courageous speech, Otto Wels flees to France. The Enabling Act marks the end of a democratic constitution under the rule of law. For many elected representatives of the democratic parties, especially in the SPD and the Communist party, it ushers in long years of suffering through persecution and suppression under the Nazi regime.  

Democrats against Hitler 

As the Second World War enters its final phase, the Nazi regime wants to settle old scores with all its opponents on the German political scene. There is a new wave of arrests. This time only a few survive imprisonment. Most of the former parliamentarians die in the Sachsenhausen and Buchenwald concentration camps. 

Rudolf Breitscheid is one of the most prominent SPD politicians also incarcerated in these camps. His supporters applauded him for his speeches and policy of reconciliation with France - exactly why the Nazis hate him.  

In March 1933, Breitscheid emigrates to France. On 10 May 1940, the German forces invade. The Gestapo arrest Rudolf Breitscheid in February 1941, deporting him and his wife to the Sachsenhausen and Buchenwald concentration camps. In August 1944, Rudolf Breitscheid dies during an American air raid. Today, many are unaware of his fate, but his name is still well known, commemorated in the name of the Breitscheidplatz square next to the Kaiser Wilhelm Memorial Church.  

Today, when you approach the visitors' entrance of the Reichstag building from Tiergarten Park, you'll notice 96 cast iron plates set in the pavement. The plates, rather reminiscent of gravestones, bear the names and dates of 9 women and 87 men, together with the name of their political party. This memorial, inaugurated in 1992, commemorates the murdered members of the Reichstag.
column12:
Opening hours:
Accessible to the public 24/7
column13: Louise Schröder, Kurt Schumacher, and Paul Löbe - these three SPD parliamentarians miraculously survive the Nazi regime's prisons and concentration camps. After the war, they put their unflagging energies into building a new and democratic Germany. Today, there are many streets, squares and buildings that bear their names.

column8: A magnetic attraction - in 1989, Ku`damm boulevard symbolises the lure of the West.
column11:
Queuing for a little bit of freedom
Once the Wall falls, many people in the GDR have one wish — to stand on Berlin's legendary Ku'damm boulevard! Renowned as the 'West's shop window', here they can find everything they've dreamt of over the last 28 years. And so for many East Germans, their first visit to the West begins with a traffic jam.

On 10 November 1989, the entire boulevard is packed with East German Trabbis. The colourful shop windows and neon adverts contrast sharply with the Trabbi cars in matte bali yellow, reed green and dolphin grey. Everywhere, there are throngs of people, all come to experience the wonder of western consumer goods for themselves.

Shopping? First - a coffee!

In the days after the Wall falls, Kurfürstendamm's "Kranzler Eck" corner is buzzing - far more than for ages. For many older people in the crowds, a coffee and piece of cake in the historic Café Kranzler is a journey into the past. For the younger ones, just standing on Ku'damm boulevard feels like being at the centre of the world. Suddenly, people from East and West start to dance, free and elated, to the loud music blasting from Joes Bierhaus (since 2011 the Alt Berliner Biersalon). Even those not yet able to collect their DM 100 "welcome money" can join in, paid for by friends or strangers in the surrounding bars and restaurants. From the sales staff in the KaDeWe department store to West Berlin students - many happily slip a DM 5 note to someone who needs it or buy them a little something, soon shared with others. On a day like this, no one is left out.

Between euphoria and disenchantment

The crowds of people shift and flow from one queue to the next. The Ku'damm shops quickly adapt to their new customers. Everywhere, improvised signs offer special actions and discount for people from East Germany - and closing times suddenly become very flexible. The day's fave raves turn out to be sweets, with records and clothes also high up the rankings. Everyone has their own experience with capitalism - from the first burger in a fast food chain to looking at erotic lingerie and sex toys in the Beate Uhse shop. And even those queuing for hours in vain at the bank can at least take a look around. Here and there, you also hear some critical voices. After all, the prices leave no doubts - the GDR currency is too weak for people from East Germany to fulfil their big dreams.
column12:
Opening hours:
freely accessible, individual shop opening hours

For more information on this location, events and tickets, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/kurfurstendamm
column13: The "welcome money" scheme also attracts scamsters. With the banks packed, they first collect "welcome money" from one bank with their passport and then do the same at another with their ID card. But many collecting double "welcome money" had a bad conscience. By Christmas 1989, no less than DM 677,000 had been returned.

column8: The world's first museum for contemporary urban art is in Berlin. In this world of free spirits, admission is also free
column11:
The museum that shouldn’t exist
Some street artists are fiercely opposed to the Urban Nation Museum in Berlin, vowing to never set foot in it. For them, urban art belongs in the street, not in specially created exhibition spaces. Are they missing out? Yes - on what is perhaps the capital's coolest and most unusual art gallery.

Even as you walk up to the museum's entrance, you can tell it's not like a normal art gallery. As you approach Urban Nation you encounter your first pieces of art on the walls of Bülowstraße in Berlin's Schöneberg district. Then you find yourself in front of the massive, distinctive facade of the museum itself.  

A museum without a museum director   

It's just as unusual when you step inside. Admission is free (always and for everyone). The museum floor is asphalted like the city streets that normally provide the setting for tape art, street art and graffiti. And you are actively encouraged to take photos. Yasha Young is not the Museum Director but, in true advertising agency style, introduces herself on the website as Executive Creative Director.  

"The museum is an information hub that is truly one of a kind". This is how she describes her selection of contemporary urban art. Young has spent many years in New York and now her focus is on "conducting a public conversation". 

The museum aims to exhibit, explain, preserve and classify graffiti and street art so that it can shake off its reputation for being mere vandalism. Alongside the exhibition, Young is achieving this through projects with students, young artists, the neighbouring church and a local care home.  

But above all, Urban Nation wants to astonish its visitors. This begins with the elaborately remodelled Wilhelminian-style building in Schöneberg. Architect Thomas Willemeit has created rooms with "insanely high ceilings", perfect for such large-format works of art. Bridges have been suspended so that you can walk diagonally across the rooms and get up close to the artworks. This exciting "parkour" provides all kinds of different perspectives.  

Massive, changing images on the building's facade  

But the piece de resistance of Willemeit and his team is the museum's modular, interchangeable facade. At regular intervals, street artists transform the whole facade into a gigantic mural. These huge works are later dismantled and stored in the archives. Inside, there is room for some 150 works. Most of the exhibits are by the greats of the street art scene, but up-and-coming artists are also commissioned to create works specially for Urban Nation.  

It is no surprise that the first official Museum for Urban Contemporary Art should open its doors in Berlin. The former "anti-fascist barrier" is world famous as a work of graffiti art, and the city has a long tradition of decorating facades and firewalls in the many gaps between its buildings.  

With an ironic nod to the fact that the street is the natural environment of urban art, Young's museum calls itself the museum that shouldn't exist.
column12: For more information, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/urban-nation-museum-urban-contemporary-art
column13: So far, no-one has crept out with a spray can under cover of darkness and painted over the changing face of Urban Nation's facade. Should this ever happen, the artist can decide whether to repair or welcome the creative interference in their work - then it automatically becomes part of the piece.

column8: Commissioned by Wilhelm I, King of Prussia - unveiled by Wilhelm I, Emperor of Germany
column11:
Three victories, one nation state
Fireworks exploding and the smell of acrid, black powder. Snorting horses, beating drums, and marching soldiers. All part of a magnificent military parade to celebrate the greatness of Prussia and the German Empire.

2 September 1873 - the third anniversary of the decisive Battle of Sedan in the Franco-Prussian War. In Berlin, a day to remember - not only to commemorate winning the war, but also its part in founding the German Empire. Today, in the presence of Emperor Wilhelm I, the Victory Column is ceremonially unveiled - a memorial he commissioned in 1864 as the then King of Prussia.

Celebrations at a different site

To be present at this unveiling of the Victory Column in 1873, you'd have to be just over 1.5 km away to the north east. When first built, the column stood on Königsplatz square, a former army exercise ground, today's Platz der Republik. On Königsplatz square, the monument, nearly 60 meters high, is framed by the Kroll Opera House and Count Raczyński's luxurious town mansion - a few years later, the site of the Reichstag Parliament building.

Originally, the column's crowning statue of the goddess of victory, a symbol of Prussia's striving for power, has a view across the later Siegesallee, a broad boulevard linking Königsplatz, close to the Reichstag, and Kemperplatz, near Potsdamer Platz. The column's then three blocks of sandstone are decorated with gilded canon barrels captured as war booty. Just like the base with its bronze reliefs and the mosaic frieze in the columned entrance, they recall the three Wars of German Unification. Between 1864 and 1871, Prussian forces are victorious in the Danish-Prussian War, the Austro-Prussian War and the Franco-Prussian War - successes resulting in Wilhelm I, King of Prussia, being proclaimed German Emperor in 1871 in the Hall of Mirrors at the Palace of Versailles.

Where the crème de la crème meets

The new Victory Column's unveiling ceremony offers a perfect insight into Prussian court etiquette, which follows a military hierarchy. Dressed in his full regalia and on horseback, Prince Otto von Bismarck, the Iron Chancellor, gives the command to unveil the monument. Meanwhile, the official guests are gathered in three separate groups. First, the imperial and royal court in a festive pavilion facing the Victory Column; then, on their own dedicated stand, the army generals and the rulers of the principalities and states who fought alongside Prussia in the Wars of German Unification. Finally, at a suitable distance, representatives of the Reichstag and the city of Berlin - including the liberal mayor of the city. The common people are free to celebrate the new Victory Column as they wish at another location in the evening.

After the third anniversary of the Battle of Sedan, the Victory Column stands on the same site for another 65 years - until the Nazi regime decrees that the memorial is in the way of their planned world capital Germania. In 1938, Albert Speer, Hitler's main architect, has the column moved to where you can now look up and see the golden goddess of victory.
column12:
Opening hours:
Open daily (except 24 December)
April-October Monday - Friday 9.30am-6.30pm, Saturday & Sunday 9.30am-7pm
November-Marz Monday - Friday 9.30am - 5.30pm, Saturday & Sunday 9.30am-5.30pm

For more information on this location, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/siegessaule
column13: In 1901, the Siegesallee (Victory Avenue) leading away from the Victory Column is finished. The boulevard is lined with 32 marble figures depicting all the Margraves, Electors of Brandenburg and Kings of Prussia between 1157 and 1888. Each ruler is framed by two portrait busts of his most important advisors. The locals are not so impressed, nicknaming it "Puppet Avenue".

column8: In June 1948, the drone of bombers echoes over Berlin again. This time, though, they are not bringing death, but candy bars.
column11:
When freedom tastes of candy bars
The Candy Bombers are coming! For the first time since the end of the war, here where you are now standing, airplane engines again roar over the heads of people in Berlin.

Just three years earlier, bombs were raining down from the skies. But this time the Allies are transporting a different, a valuable load - urgently needed relief supplies for a beleaguered city. 

On 24 June 1948, Stalin orders power to be cut off to the western sectors of Berlin. Just a little later, the road, rail and water routes to the divided city are blocked. People in the streets are just as alarmed as the western Allies. This is more than Soviet sabre-rattling. This is a threat to freedom, striking at the heart of over 2,200,000 people trapped in the city. Within just a few hours, confidence has turned to fear - how long can we survive like this?  

Will we fall into the hands of the Russians?  

Not if American Military Governor General L. D. Clay has anything to do with it! He isn't planning a military counterstrike, but a remarkable logistical feat - an airlift using all available Allied military planes from across the world. Under the Nazis, Tempelhof Airport was a place of forced labourers and armaments production, an architectural symbol of the regime's claim to power. Now, it quickly develops into a place of hope. Clay's "Operation Vittles" achieves the seemingly impossible - forging allies from victors and the defeated, fighting side by side to save Berlin. 

Turning enemies into friends  

Every day, 1500 tons of food are flown in to West Berlin. At the busiest times, planes land and take off every three minutes, not only bringing tinned goods, coal, and so on, but also a belief in the goodness of humanity. Thousands of the pilots also pack in candy bars and chewing gum tied into bundles on tiny parachutes. As they approach the runway, they throw the little bundles out of the cockpit window. As they sail down to the ground, these sweet gifts capture the hearts of the waiting children. In total, the airlift flies in nearly one and a half million tons of coal, and almost half a million tons of food. 

On the night of 12 May 1949, after 322 days, the Soviets finally lift the blockade - West Berlin is saved. 

On the trail of the Candy Bomber 

Today, the Airlift Memorial commemorates Berlin's friendship with the Allies and the 79 people who lost their lives in the course of the operation. If you stand with your back to the airport building's former main entrance, you can't miss the memorial, twenty metres high and made of reinforced concrete. For the locals, the memorial also has a nickname, ironically dubbed the "Hungerharke" (literally "hunger rake"). The three struts pointing west symbolise the three air corridors open to the planes. Originally, architect Eduard Ludwig plans an installation in light alloy, but it does not meet the building regulations. He also wants it to be a unique piece, but there too he will be disappointed. His second design is accepted and built - followed by a replica in Frankfurt am Main in 1985 and a third memorial in 1988 in Celle, both locations where Candy Bombers once took off for Berlin. 

Probably the most impressive testament to the airlift is a real Candy Bomber, a Douglas C-47 B Skytrain, set on the roof of the newly constructed terrace of the German Museum of Technology not far from Potsdamer Platz.
column12:
Opening hours:
The airfield and memorial are freely accessible

For more information on this location and guided tours, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/flughafen-tempelhof-tempelhof-airport
column13: The tight airlift schedule only allows each pilot one attempt at landing. If there are problems, pilots have to abort the landing and fly back to their home airport, still with their load on board.

column8: 9 November 1938: A police lieutenant stands up to the Nazi mob
column11:
A policeman stands up for his beliefs
Dense smoke belches from the anteroom of the New Synagogue on Oranienburger Straße. Torah scrolls fly out the door. Window panes shatter, chandeliers lie on the floor in smithereens. It's the night of November 9th. Jewish places of worship are being set alight all over Berlin, and the New Synagogue is no exception. Germany's largest synagogue is in flames, but the head of the local police is not prepared to stand by while the brownshirts burn it to the ground. He draws his pistol.

The New Synagogue is the embodiment of Jewish life in Berlin. With its gleaming golden dome, its Moorish architecture is reminiscent the Thousand And One Nights. It is destined to be one of the Nazis' main targets on the night of 9 November 1938. 

Ordnung muss sein - Order must prevail! 

Wilhelm Krützfeld, the head of the local police precinct, confronts the brownshirts. In one hand he clutches his pistol. In the other he holds an even more powerful weapon - a document from the imperial era showing that the monument is a protected historical landmark. Krützfeld calls the fire brigade and ensures they can access the building. He throws out the rioters and arsonists, and the SA mob is forced to disperse. On this night of terror that is later dubbed Kristallnacht (Night of Broken Glass), the New Synagogue is one of the few synagogues in the whole of Germany to sustain only minimal damage.  

The brownshirts didn't reckon with someone like Krützfeld. On that fateful night, he is one of the few people who is prepared to stand up to them. The police officer is determined to maintain public order. As a Prussian official, he is conscientious with a sense of justice. But this means he is at odds with his nation's Nazi rulers. The next day, Berlin's police commissioner calls Krützfeld into his office, but allows him to return to work with a verbal reprimand. 

Correctness becomes courage 

This is not the only time that Krützfeld and his colleagues take a moral stand. Krützfeld stamps forged identity cards and warns Jewish residents in his neighbourhood when raids are imminent. The police lieutenant retires in 1943 and returns to his native Schleswig-Holstein. 

He is memorialised in Heinz Knobloch Krützfeld's book Der beherzte Reviervorsteher (The Valiant Precinct Chief). To the right of the synagogue entrance you can see a plaque commemorating Wilhelm Krützfeld. It was donated by the Berlin police.
column12:
Opening hours: 
October to April:
Sunday to Thursday, 10am to 6pm
Friday 10 am to 3pm
(seasonal opening hours apply)

The memorial is freely accessible  

The Neue Synagoge
column13: Flames shoot from the dome of the New Synagogue. It's a dramatic picture that finds its way into newspapers and textbooks. But it's fake news. No photos exist of that night.

column8: The Wertheim brothers set new standards in shopping. In 1927, their department store on Leipziger Platz was ranked as the largest in Europe.
column11:
Department store with a private tunnel to the tube station
In 1928, the Wertheim chain of department stores convinces the city of Berlin to change the route of its newly-planned U8 tube line. For a payment of 5 million Reichsmark (around €20 million today), the department store is given a private pedestrian tunnel to the tube station at Moritzplatz. Here, Wertheim follows the example of the Karstadt department store at Berlin's Hermannplatz where the advantage of direct access to the tube platform attracts growing numbers of shoppers.

The Wertheim department store's paramount principle is free entry without the psychological pressure to buy. In an approach just as innovative, it offers a broad range of products all on display with fixed prices payable only in cash. As if that wasn't enough, the store also offers customers a right to return or exchange goods - and, as the cherry on the cake, holds irresistible end-of-season sales.

In Wertheim, buying is designed to be a delight and a pleasure. Industrial magnate (later German foreign minister) Gustav Stresemann notes that "civil servants' wives from the west of the city surrender themselves to this hustle and bustle just as willingly as workers' wives from eastern Berlin, always wearing their good dress [... when they go to Wertheim]."

The story of the Wertheim family of entrepreneurs begins in Stralsund, on the Baltic coast. In 1885, they open their first small branch in Berlin. In 1893/94, they have their first real department store custom-built at Oranienstraße 53/54, designed by architect Alfred Messel. With the store's rapid rise to fame, the premises are soon too cramped for their growing selection of tempting goods. Wertheim has to leave, and the building then becomes Café Moritzplatz.

Wertheim's new building, its second venue in Berlin, is directly on Moritzplatz and designed by Eugen Schmohl (1880-1926) in the new modernist style. The new department store stretches from Prinzenstraße to Oranienstraße with a floor space of 4,535 square metres. The architecture and layout reflects the Wertheim brothers' vision - as much sales space as possible with the customers' route through the store as pleasant as possible. The design, height and furnishings not only provide the requisite light and air, but are also informed by the styles in display architecture at that time.

In 1934, a year after the Nazi Party's seizure of power, the Wertheim company is forced to adopt the Nazi policy of "Aryanisation". To avoid the worst, Georg Wertheim hands over his entire assets to his wife Ursula, who was not classified as a Jew under the Nazi racial laws. Nonetheless, in 1935 the Nazis still categorise the Wertheim company as "purely Jewish". Two years later the shareholders are expropriated, and the important and highly successful Wertheim group renamed the AWAG (Allgemeine Warenhaus AG).

The Wertheim building was badly damaged in air raids during the Second World War. Until finally demolished in the early 1950s, the burnt-out shell of the building could still be seen on the corner plot of Moritzplatz.

The Wertheim name managed to survive the war. In wartime advertising, the name is only mentioned as an afterthought - "AWAG formerly Wertheim". But after the war, a new department store is opened on Schloßstraße in Steglitz. As early as 1952, it bears the store's traditional name - Wertheim.
column13: Since 2009, this Moritzplatz site of the former Wertheim department store has been home to the Princess Gardens urban gardening project. On the former waste land between Prinzenstraße and Oranienstraße, an enthusiastic group of volunteers have set up an urban communal mobile garden on an area of around 5800 square metres - roughly the size of a football pitch. Unfortunately, the project is facing an uncertain future.

column8: A favourite haunt of Berlin's bohemian set - the café close to the Memorial Church is a breeding ground for artistic talent
column11:
“A breeding ground for talent” (1)
Journalist Egon Erwin Kisch and art dealer Alfred Flechtheim meet at the Romanisches Café. On the marble table in front of Kisch is a copy of Karl Marx's Das Kapital. With a grin, Flechtheim says: "Finally, someone who can explain the difference between capital and work!" That's easy, says Kisch. "If you lend me a thousand marks now, I have capital. The effort you have to make to get your money back is work." 

A place for networking 

In the Twenties, the Romanisches Café is a magnet for artists. The café can tell many stories about its free-spirited guests - and their chronic financial problems. But the coffee house is not exactly attractive. Its ambience is reminiscent of a station concourse, the food is bad, the floor is filthy and the air smoky. There's also a strict hierarchy. A distinction is made between the Schwimmerbassin (swimmers' pool), which is frequented by the regulars, and the Nichtschwimmerbecken (non-swimmers' pool), where strangers are allowed to sit.  

But people are attracted by the fact that they can sit for hours over a single cup of coffee. It's a place for making contacts and building networks, drawing in established artists and aspiring hopefuls. It's a breeding ground for new projects, exciting new ideas and artistic inspiration. 

A celebrity hang-out  

The cafe has a long list of famous patrons. Artists flock to sit with Impressionist painter Max Slevogt, whose table is occasionally graced by the presence of Max Liebermann. Journalists and critics meet up here, though the influential critic Alfred Kerr rarely shows up because his reviews have usually upset one or other of the regulars. It's a regular haunt of actress Carola Neher and her husband, the poet known as Klabund. Gabriele Tergit describes the cafe in her novel Käsebier erobert den Kurfürstendamm. Director and screenwriter Robert Siodmak recalls how the cafe sparked the idea for his film Menschen am Sonntag.  

For some guests, the coffee house is a way of life. Bohemian artist John Höxter is part of the furniture, spending his days scrounging from table to table. The Romanisches Cafe inspires many of its guests, and its regulars extol it in books, poems and songs, including a revue by the famous composer Friedrich Hollaender. 

The spot where swimmers and non-swimmers vied for attention back in the Twenties is now the site of the World Fountain on Breitscheidplatz.
column13: The Romanisches Café is just one of several artists' haunts around Kurfürstendamm in the 1920s. Other favourite meeting places are Restaurant Schlichter and the Schwanneke wine bar. Joseph Roth prefers to write at the Mampe, while Erich Kästner is a fan of Café Leon.

column8: Aeroplanes once droned over the fields that are now home to Berlin's best-known community garden
column11:
Gardening for all at Tempelhofer Feld
Members of the Allmende Kontor community garden have organised a big picnic. A new face shows up, and she's clearly enjoying eating and drinking with the other gardeners. She then makes an emotional confession to the organisers - she's lived in the neighbourhood for 40 years, but this is the most contact she's ever had with other locals. 

It's stories like this that highlight the true spirit of the community garden at Tempelhofer Feld. It's not just about growing flowers and vegetables. "The main thing is its multicultural aspect"  ,explains garden activist Elisabeth Meyer-Renschhausen. It is particularly important for families, migrants and senior citizens to have access to multi-purpose public spaces close to their homes. They provide opportunities to chat to other people, learn from each other and help each other. Such spaces also help refugees to play an active, meaningful role in their new home.   

Build it and they will come   

In 2011, 13 keen gardeners start using a small part of the 380-hectare open space at the former airport. The project quickly takes off and people are keen to join in. Tourists and journalists turn up to see what's going on. The waiting list starts to grow. Elisabeth Meyer-Renschhausen has little time for gardening these days because she has so many questions to answer. The Allmende Kontor has certainly helped to fuel the urban gardening trend in Berlin. 

When you visit, it's easy to see why. Berlin's best-known community garden is packed with fascinating features. There are bee-keeping and composting groups, workshops on organic pest control and occasional, unplanned lectures. "Turkish women come along to grow their vegetables, and they're appalled when they realise that today's youngsters haven't a clue. They feel compelled to show them how to do it.", says Kontor member Severin Halder. 

Unplanned lectures   

The focus of the Allmende founders has always been on sowing the seeds of inspiration. They are keen to arouse people's curiosity and motivate them to start a "real" garden of their own somewhere in the city.  

"I think what visitors love most is the space, the freedom" says another activist. Let your gaze wander across the vast expanse of the Tempelhofer Feld recreation area and you'll understand why. No other major city has such an incredible panorama right at its heart.  

Then there's the attractive, alternative atmosphere of the Kontor garden. Raised beds made with scraps of wood, lots of bright colours, just about everything has been improvised. The garden has a certain drop-out charm, but it looks like it's here to stay - the owner has regularly extended the lease since 2011.
column13: Everything in the Allmende-Kontor garden is grown in raised beds. Permanent plots are not allowed on the Tempelhofer Feld because the authorities are worried about unexploded World War II bombs and soil pollution. But the gardeners believe this is just an excuse to make sure their garden remains "mobile". It makes it easier to move them on if there are ever plans to develop the site.

column7: The Eimer – a legendary underground club
column8: A squat with a ripped-out cellar ceiling and 100 decibels blasting out of the sound system - that's punk!
column11:
A squat comes alive
Renovated period building with hardwood floors and large terrace overlooking inner courtyard. This is how 68 Rosenthaler Straße was recently described in an estate agent's advert - a far cry from how the building looked in 1990. At that time it was surrounded by rubble with empty lots on either side. Yet the place was alive and kicking as the bass-heavy beats of a punk band boomed out into the street.

The GDR is not a good place to be a punk. Pogoing and mohicans don't exactly fit in with the political system. But when the Wall comes down, everything changes. New spaces are suddenly opening up because so many buildings have been abandoned. 68 Rosenthaler Straße is just one of many forgotten properties in East Berlin. On 17 January 1990 the first squatters move into the dilapidated building. The cellar ceiling seems to be on the verge of collapse, so the squatters simply rip it out. This involves shifting bucket after bucket of rubble - which is how the building gets its new name: the Eimer, the German word for bucket.  

The building soon fills up. More and more squatters are discovering that East Berlin is largely operating outside of the law. West Berlin's police don't feel they are responsible, and East Germany's Volkspolizei no longer feel an incentive to get their fingers burned. This power vacuum provides a hotbed for East Berlin's punk movement, and artists also start moving in from the West.  

Alternative versus mainstream  

The basement with its open cellar soon becomes a leading underground club. It attracts two types of people - those who are looking for somewhere to try out new ideas, and those who have ideas for making money out of them. East Berlin bands like Freygang, DieFirma, Ich-Funktion and Teutonic Death Fun Core and legendary punks such as Speiche play here and declare war on commercialism. Cigarette machines? Forget it. Slot machines? Rip-off. Here you get alternative music and beer for next to nothing.  

Politics and pogoing are poor bedfellows  

The Eimer manages to remain generally apolitical, despite the fact that the squatter scene is very left-wing. "Freedom is more than being left-wing" says one of the first squatters to move in. That's what the Eimer is all about - freedom from the mainstream, freedom from convention, being open to new things. When the occupants discover that two members of the band Freygang were once Stasi informants, they are immediately banished from the building. You don't mess with the Eimer. 

Unfortunately, their tenacity is no match for the authorities when the building is raided by trade licensing officers in 2001. They claim that the old electric cables constitute a major fire hazard, and the last squat in East Berlin is shut down. Despite setting up a "Save the Eimer" campaign, the residents are forced to leave. The building is renovated and converted into a shop and apartments.
column13: The Eimer had a pool table right to the end. The residents wanted to chuck it out of the window when they cleared out the cigarette machine and slot machine. But the window was too small so it ended up staying.

column8: Pushing cars at Dreilinden - the adventure of crossing Germany's internal border
column11:
Taking liberties at the border crossing
The East German border guards understand how to instil fear. They know every psychological trick in the book when it comes to harassing people, making them feel helpless, stoking their fear. But the West Berliners dare to take a few liberties.

It's a hot summer's day in the mid-1980s. At the Dreilinden-Drewitz border crossing, known as Checkpoint Bravo to the Western Allies, traffic is backing up as it waits to transit the GDR. Although it's forbidden, people switch off their engines, get out of their stuffy cars and stretch their legs on the motorway. 

They chat and kill time while the GDR's border guards carry out their stringent checks on the people in front. As the queue inches forwards, the drivers simply push their cars a couple of metres. At least they're protecting the environment! At communist Germany's border with the West, the atmosphere is as threatening as ever. But after more than 20 years, the West Berliners are used to it.  

It's hard to imagine now, but every resident of West Berlin who wanted to go on holiday, visit another part of West Germany or enter East Germany had to endure these interminable procedures. The transit route on what is now the A115 leads to Hanover and on to Germany's south west. Dreilinden-Drewitz is the bottleneck through which people reach freedom.  

Same route, same rituals  

Travelling from West to East, you pass the lines of hitchhikers at the Dreilinden service station and head directly beneath the West's control bridge. A few metres further on you come to another bridge. This is where you see the divided city's most famous warning, painted in white letters spanning the motorway: "You are leaving the American Sector". You have to slow down to 40 kph as you pass the Soviet tank monument and approach the dreaded GDR checkpoint at Drewitz. Journalist Sven Felix Kellerhoff remembers the buzz he used to feel. His father would tell him and his brother not to whinge, wriggle or crack jokes while the GDR's border guards were at work. 

Today, little remains of this formidable checkpoint, though you can visit the old command tower if you stop in Kleinmachnow. Back then, the procedures were the same at every checkpoint. 

First the occupants of the car have to hand over their passports and vehicle documents, which are transported to the actual checkpoint via a conveyor belt. You're left sitting in your car without a passport - in no man's land everyone has to feel like a nobody. You just sit there while the civilian staff, customs officers and border police all check your papers. It might take 20 minutes, or an hour, or even five hours if relations between the two Germanys have worsened. If you want to enter or leave the GDR you simply have to put up with it. If you're just transiting, you'll be dealt with relatively quickly. Once the barrier has been lifted, you embark on a monotonous journey down a hermetically sealed road until you reach the free part of Germany at the next border crossing.
column13: Radioactive rays - at the first inspection bridge, caesium 137 is used to illuminate the vehicles as they pass through. This radioactive alkali metal produces images like X-rays. As far as the Stasi are concerned, the means justifies the end when it comes to detecting people trying to flee the GDR.

column8: When the police move in on the land west of the Wall, the occupiers simply climb over to the East
column11:
Escaping to the East
On this exact spot, just after 5am, 196 people fled over the Wall to East Berlin. This was in response to the aggressive evictions being carried out by West Berlin's police. They gained jurisdiction of this area of no man's land at midnight and immediately began clearing out the squatters.

Ever since the squatters moved in, the Lenné Triangle has become an untouchable corner of no man's land. Although it lies to the west of the Wall, the triangle between Lennéstraße, Bellevuestraße and Ebertstraße actually belongs to the Soviet sector. But when the Wall is built, it is decided to keep it in a straight line so that the border guards have a clear view. It's off-limits to the West Berlin police, and the East Berlin authorities have little interest in this scrap of land. 

Welcome to the Free Republic of Kubat 

This all changes on 26 May 1988, when it provides a stage for some extraordinary developments. The protagonists include eco-warriors seeking to protect the environment, squatters who have discovered a new space, and curious onlookers. The audience is the GDR border guards, who look on in disbelief. And it's quite a show. The occupiers build shacks, move in their pets, set up a communal kitchen. Music blares across the encampment. 

Norbert Kubat is unaware of all this. After being arrested for breach of the peace by plain-clothes policemen in Kreuzberg, he commits suicide in custody on 26 May. His death makes him a martyr for everyone who is fighting for freedom in the face of state oppression. His name becomes a symbol of resistance and the Lenné Triangle encampment is dubbed the Free Republic of Kubat.   

Police clampdown on Checkpoint Norbi 

On 1 July, jurisdiction over the Lenné Triangle is passed to West Berlin. At 5am, the police storm the area known as Checkpoint Norbi. Anyone caught sleeping is arrested. But 196 protesters have other plans. They use a ladder to scale the Wall, where they are awaited by the East German authorities. This is a major PR coup for the GDR regime. They give the escapees breakfast and provide a shuttle service to the nearest border crossing, even throwing in a free train ticket. The first Berliners to flee en masse to the East are back in the West.
column12: The outdoor area is freely accessible
column13: The West Berlin Senate buys several pieces of land from the GDR, at a total cost of 76 million marks. The Lenné Triangle is part of the 9.4 hectares of territory gained by West Germany in 1988.

column8: The Wall behind and a high-tech mixing desk in front - that's how great songs are made
column11:
The sound of Berlin resonates around the world
The guitar riff rings out, the drums join in - followed by the voice of David Bowie. He is composing one of his greatest songs. We can be heroes, just for one day - words full of hope in the midst of the Cold War. It's 1977, and West Berlin is a magnet for artists from all over the world. Hansa Studios is the place to be for musicians like Iggy Pop, Bowie and Depeche Mode.

The Meisel brothers bought the dilapidated building on Köthener Strasse in 1976 to convert it into recording studios. It still bears the number 38, which is a little superfluous, as only two buildings on the street have survived the war. Hansa Studios is surrounded by no-man's-land - and the Wall.  

Inspiration in the shadow of the Wall  

The international artists are both fascinated and bewildered when they see the border between the two Germanys. The Wall leaves no one cold - except the border guards, who stoically endure their class enemy's music as it drifts through the open windows. In the 1970s, a trip on the S-Bahn through empty ghost stations inspires Iggy Pop to write his song Passenger. The musicians have not only fallen for the run-down charms of this divided city, but they also love the mix of old school and high tech on offer at Hansa Studios. At its heart is the Meistersaal, a huge room with a wood-panelled ceiling, parquet floors and unique acoustics. Bowie is bowled over the moment he sets foot in it, exclaiming: "A big hall by the Wall!". 

From Heroes to Achtung Baby!  

In the 1980s, a local band called the Einstürzende Neubauten transforms the hall into an experimental cellar with instruments made from old shopping trolleys and bits of scrap metal. One day Martin Gore of Depeche Mode can be found sitting naked at the piano in the Meistersaal composing Somebody. This is where U2 reunite after tensions in the band to record their album Achtung Baby! Between 1976 and 1990 it feels like anything is possible in West Berlin. We can still hear this sense of freedom in the songs of that time: "We can be heroes, just for one day."
column13: One evening David Bowie and Tony Visconti are standing at the studio window. As a joke, the German sound engineer swivels a lamp towards the East and sticks his tongue out at the border guards. Bowie and Visconti dive for cover, afraid of being shot. The sound engineer falls about laughing.

column8: In pre-Berghain Berlin - a night out in a forgotten entertainment district
column11:
A pub crawl in the name of the Lord
One winter evening in 1925, theology student Hans Rückert sets out on a secret mission. Joined by a fellow student, his task is to travel deep into Friedrichshain, the working-class district in the east of Berlin. On behalf of their professor, the two students, dressed as workers, explore pubs and taverns along Fruchtstraße - today's Straße der Pariser Kommune.

In those days, the area has a very dubious reputation. Solidly working class, apartment blocks are set around dark courtyards, and innumerable pubs and taverns line the street. The professor and his students hope to wean the workers from alcohol, and inspire them to practice the Christian faith. First, though, they need an undercover look at the neighbourhood's licentious amusements.  

A walk along the entertainment district 

Just under one kilometre long, the street has 32 pubs. On one evening, in the space of six hours, Hans Rückert and his friend visit over half of them. They count nearly 300 people drinking there, mostly men escaping the cramped conditions at home. But they also meet cases for concern - young men in various states of drunkenness, some totally wasted.  

In the Eldorado-Diele pub, the students can hardly believe their eyes. As the red light at the entrance clearly indicates, this is a pub with hostesses. They watch two hostesses encouraging guests to have one drink after another. Pushy and persistent, the women beg cigarettes and drinks - and one guest actually lets them wheedle him out of the incredible sum of 90 Reichsmark. In Berlin, as a hotbed of vice, unlimited freedom also leaves you free to follow the path to ruin. As far as we know, the two students' visit to this twilight world had no further consequences - but unfortunately, no records exist on the outcome of their expedition.  

Extraordinary entertainment for ordinary folk 

The pubs are not the only nightlife venues in this working-class neighbourhood. Exactly on this site, where today you can see the Neues Deutschland publishing house, the Plaza variety theatre opens 1 February 1929. In a former station building converted into a vast theatre, the Plaza is under the same management as Schöneberg's renowned Scala variety theatre. The free-standing balcony with 820 seats is a sensation. The Plaza can seat a total of 3000 people to experience, as the theatre programme promises, "the biggest line-up of the highest artistry at the lowest prices".

In the Plaza, such stars as popular entertainer and singer Claire Waldoff plays to huge audiences. In the meantime, the working class in Friedrichshain has more leisure and a little more money and can afford such pleasures. But in autumn 1929, the financial world is shaken to its roots. On Black Friday, Berlin is also sucked into the maelstrom of the global economic crisis. The Plaza is forced to close temporarily, and reopens as an operetta theatre. The Nazi regime dispossesses the Jewish owners, and later turns the theatre into a venue for their own Kraft durch Freude (Strength through Joy) leisure organisation. Now, the amusements in the neighbourhood are directed to war preparations.
column13: Today, all the pubs have vanished from the Straße der Pariser Kommune. Back then, the street had more pubs than today's Simon-Dach-Straße in Friedrichshain.

column8: In the summer of anarchy, a dilapidated old building becomes the first alternative cultural centre
column11:
A bitter housing shortage has a sweet solution
Chocolate? It's a long time since the former Zar Chocolate factory smelt of chocolate. Nowadays it's the sweet smell of freedom that wafts through the building, which has been occupied by squatters since 1990. The old building is also proof that perseverance pays off.

By the time 20 young people move into the former factory complex, the building has already had a chequered history. It's been a stonemason's workshop, a chocolate factory, a Hitler Youth base, a horse stables, a commodities warehouse and finally a derelict building. Toilets and bathrooms? Nope. Heating that works? Not really.  

Summer of anarchy  

The building might be crumbling, but it still seems like a good place to set up a squat. After all, it's the brief summer of anarchy. Everything is up for grabs because the authorities and East Germany's Volkspolizei are no longer bothered about squats, and West Berlin's police and politicians will only take over responsibility once the Unification Treaty has been signed. It's still East Berlin, but the power vacuum means freedom is breaking out.

The empty properties also exercise their charm on West Berliners and soon a diverse mix of people are bringing the former chocolate factory back to life. Artists flock there to open studios and workshops, theatres and clubs. The Schoko-Laden quickly becomes the first alternative cultural centre. It's a place where people can live and work together far removed from the day-to-day reality of exploitation and political borders.  

Cooperation is the key  

The squatters are keen to find a way to make their centre work. They set up a culture and housing association known as Schokoladen e.V. While some shared housing projects are forcibly shut down, the Schokoladen has better luck. Its residents manage to convert the squat into legal tenancies, while still retaining a degree of self-determination. Later on, they successfully fend off attempts to evict them. The unique atmosphere of this non-commercial microcosm provides a rich breeding ground for unusual ideas. There's room for everything and everyone, from cello punk to the Club of Polish Losers.
column12:
Opening hours:
Monday from 9pm, Tuesday from 8.30pm, Wednesday - Saturday from 8pm, Sunday from 8pm
column13: As one door closes, another one opens - the bar at the Schoko-Laden opens right on time to mark the official end of the GDR. It pulls its very first beer on 1 October 1990.

column8: Even a tunnel can offer a little luxury. The tunnel between the Hotel Excelsior and Anhalter station is quite a sensation
column11:
An underground gateway to the world
Its construction caused a sensation. Right here beneath your feet, the Excelsior tunnel was opened on 15 March 1928. It connected the city's biggest railway station with the continent's biggest hotel. So it's hardly surprising that the Hotel Excelsior dubbed the 80-metre-long tunnel from the station to its door "the longest hotel tunnel in the world". It's all about the power of superlatives.

From waiter to hotel manager 

It was Curt Elschner who came up with the idea of the tunnel. He had worked his way up from lowly waiter to famous hotel manager. He bought the Hotel Excelsior in 1919.
