Today, a supermarket stands where its entrance used to be. Elschner decides to focus on attracting the masses rather than the upper classes. He gradually expands the hotel until it has 600 rooms and 750 beds.  

The hotel's main draw is its proximity to Anhalter railway station across the road. Every day, 14,000 long-distance travellers pass through the station. He has the tunnel built so that it is even easier for guests to get to the hotel from the station. Gold-plated elevators whisk guests into the tunnel from the station concourse and hotel lobby. Elschner invested one million Reichsmarks of his own money in the project - a huge sum at the time. He also has to pay 10,000 Reichsmarks to the Reichsbahn, which operates the station.  

A gateway to the world 

The tunnel is first and foremost a publicity stunt. It receives extensive coverage in the Berlin dailies. The Vossische Zeitung points out that there is a ticket office at the entrance to the tunnel. This means hotel guests can buy their train tickets without having to set foot on Berlin's crowded streets. Then they can not only travel to the Free State of Anhalt, but also to Paris or Naples, as 120 long-distance trains pass through the station every day Its three sweeping arches provide a gateway to the world.  

But the tunnel is an economic disaster, as only 100 people use the underpass each day. The shops in the tunnel are operated by KaDeWe, but they prove difficult to let. Elschner fights for a discount, writing to the Reichsbahn: "Unfortunately, the tunnel itself can be described as a failure as its use is virtually non-existent."   

Anhalter station is damaged during the war and comes to a complete standstill after 1945. It is eventually demolished, apart from the central portion of its facade. Allied bombers also reduce the Hotel Excelsior to a burning ruin. It is finally replaced by a 17-storey tower block, the Excelsiorhaus, which has nothing to do with the hotel apart from its name. The tunnel fades into oblivion until it is uncovered during construction works on Stresemannstraße in 1985. It is filled in and, with that, the last vestige of Twenties glamour disappears at Anhalter station.
column13: Curt Elschner makes an enemy of the Nazis because he refuses to let Adolf Hitler stay at the Excelsior.

column8: West Berlin's answer to the construction boom in the East? A field of rubble becomes an architects' playground
column11:
The city of tomorrow
In 1957, the West Berlin Senate decides to create a new landmark in the Tiergarten area that will be visible the eastern part of the city. The result is the building you see in front of you. Because of its height and colour, this high-rise building in the Hansaviertel district is known as the Giraffe. It is 53 metres high and has 164 studio apartments over 17 floors.

The International Building Exhibition (INTERBAU) in 1957 proves to be a stroke of luck for architects Klaus Müller-Rehm and Gerhard Siegmann. Not only do they get to work with other top international architects on the designs for a whole new quarter, but they are also picked to draw up the plans for its tallest building.  

From rubble to modernist minimalism 

The original plan is for a single high-rise building to be built on a vast expanse of rubble. West Berlin Senate's Building Director Ludwig Lemmer thinks the project is too big for Müller-Rehm to handle on his own, so he brings in Gerhard Siegmann. The latter is also an advocate of minimalism and is experienced in making the most of scarce building materials. They make a strong team, but the Giraffe project still has its share of challenges. Money problems mean the completion date is pushed back several times.  

A response to Moscow-style socialist boulevards 

West Berlin's Senate is determined that the prestigious INTERBAU project must not fail. It has to be a response to the "wedding-cake" socialist architecture of Karl-Marx-Allee on the other side of the Wall. The GDR regime commissioned architect Hermann Henselmann to build "workers' palaces" on the first socialist boulevard. Now it is the turn of top architects such as Alvar Aalto, Walter Gropius, Oscar Niemeyer, Pierre Vago, Luciano Baldessari, Max Taut and Le Corbusier to give West Berlin its own new architectural apparel. While Le Corbusier's planned building has to be moved closer to the Olympic Stadium, the other architects get to realise their visions in the Hansaviertel. But not without compromises. Building regulations take their toll. Indeed, they cause so many problems that most of the international architects take down their nameplates.

Fortunately, the tower block is spared these problems. It earns the nickname Giraffe because of its colour and the restaurant of the same name on the ground floor. It is the first building to go up in the Hansaviertel.
column12:
Outdoor exhibition, freely accessible 

For more information on this location, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/hansaviertel
column13: The tower block houses 164 studio apartments, most of which are designed to be bachelor pads with cupboard kitchens instead of kitchenettes. But it soon becomes clear that single women and couples are also moving in. A clause that bans married couples from living there means they are forced to "live in sin".

column8: The USA gives West Berliners the unique sound of freedom
column11:
A bell rings out for freedom
Half a million Berliners are waiting excitedly for the bell to toll. On 24 October 1960, a huge crowd has gathered at Schöneberg Town Hall, the former city hall of West Berlin. They are joined by Konrad Adenauer and US General Lucius D. Clay, who is about to make the replica of the famous Liberty Bell chime for the very first time. At 12 noon precisely, General Clay throws the switch. Everyone looks up in anticipation - but nothing happens.

A gift from the USA 

The Freedom Bell has made a long journey to get here. In early 1950, Lucius D. Clay - known as the "Father of the Berlin Airlift" - makes a proposal to the new National Committee for a Free Europe. He suggests making a replica of the famous Liberty Bell so that West Berlin has its own symbol of freedom.  

16 million Americans donate money so that the bell can be cast and sign the following declaration of freedom: "I believe in the sacredness and dignity of the individual. / I believe that all men derive the right to freedom equally from God. / I pledge to resist aggression and tyranny wherever they appear on earth." 

The bell cast in London is called the Freedom Bell. It acts as a reminder of all the people who are unable to live their lives in freedom. Clay initiates a Crusade for Freedom - the ten-tonne bronze bell travels right across the USA before reaching its final destination at Schöneberg Town Hall on 21 October 1950.   

When you stand on Rathausplatz, where John F. Kennedy spoke those famous words "Ich bin ein Berliner" in 1963, it's hard to grasp the true scale of the Freedom Bell. High up in the 70-metre bell tower, it weighs 10,206 kilograms and measures 2.6 metres across.  

From the Town Hall tower to the world  

General Lucius D. Clay must have had quite a shock when the bell didn't ring - but fortunately this hasn't been repeated. Right on cue, the Freedom Bell rings out for two minutes at 12 noon every day. It also chimes at midnight on 1 May, Christmas Eve and New Year's Eve, and marks major political events, such as the reunification of Germany on 3 October 1990. Two days after the 9/11 attacks, the bell tolled for 7 minutes in memory of the victims.  

So what was the problem on 24 October 1950? It was nothing serious - when General Clay threw the switch, he blew the fuses in the improvised electrical system. Fortunately, some workers up in the bell tower started physically pushing the bell - and the Freedom Bell began to chime.  

Its premiere was broadcast by 2,000 radio stations around the world. From then on, the bells and the declaration of freedom were broadcast at noon every Sunday on RIAS radio, a station set up by the US military administration in West Berlin. 

Today, the Freedom Bell is the biggest non-church bell in Berlin. When it rings out at noon every day, it reminds us of something very precious: our freedom.
column13: The signatures of the 16 million Americans who donated money to make the bell are stored in the tower at Schöneberg Town Hall. Still in their original packaging, they are kept in a special document chamber.

column8: As early as 1931, the SA are on the rampage on the Ku'damm - armed with knuckledusters, cudgels and revolvers
column11:
SA terror on Berlin's famous boulevard
It's 12 September 1931, a Saturday evening. Outside Café Reimann, people are sipping coffee and enjoying one of the last warm days of summer. But a peaceful evening on the Kurfürstendamm turns into a dreadful night of violence and terror.

Around 9 o'clock they hear shouts coming from nearby Fasanenstraße: "Juda verrecke, Deutschland erwache!" ("Perish Judah, Germany awaken!") Groups of young men appear, all dressed in brown shirts. They are members of the Sturmabteilung (SA), the Nazi's paramilitary wing, which has been terrorising Berlin for years.  

Panic at Café Reimann 

The brownshirts pile into the cafe, smashing furniture, shattering windows, beating up the customers. Panic breaks out when an SA man takes out his revolver and fires two bullets into the ceiling. Groups of brownshirts roam the Kurfürstendamm, on the look-out for anyone who looks vaguely Jewish, even laying into a German nationalist, the journalist Peter Derichsweiler.  Shopkeepers rush to lower their shutters, but the people on the street have no such protection against the attackers. 

Attack on Jewish New Year  

This is no spontaneous attack by the SA. By 7.30pm, around a thousand brownshirts have gathered at the Memorial Church. They head en masse to the synagogue on Fasanenstraße and hang around outside, waiting for the worshippers to emerge. Their choice of day is also not random - it's Rosh Hashana, Jewish New Year. But the SA men are too late, and the synagogue has already emptied. So they switch their attention to the Kurfürstendamm.  

Their attacks are highly organised. Two of the SA's leaders, Karl Ernst and Wolf-Heinrich Graf von Helldorff, drive around in open-top cabs giving out orders. Behind the scenes, Goebbels has a clear strategy. The Ku'damm is too "Jewish" for his liking, so over the years he has been sending his men here to hand out leaflets and threaten Jews.  

The police are too late, the courts are too weak 

The police are nowhere to be seen. For nearly an hour, the SA are left to wreak havoc. And when the police finally turn up, their attempts to stop the violence are lukewarm at best. By eleven o'clock, the violence is continuing unabated on nearby Nollendorfplatz. 50 men are arrested, but only 22 remain in custody.  

The defendants are given short prison sentences, and these sentences are reduced still further on appeal in February 1932. Graf von Helldorff and Karl Ernst are actually acquitted, and Helldorff goes on to pursue his own career in the police force. In 1933, the Nazis appoint him police chief of Potsdam and Berlin.
column13: In the wake of the attacks, the international press asks whether it is safe to visit Berlin. The Prime Minister and Foreign Minister of France are due to make a state visit. Chancellor Heinrich Brüning resorts to a dirty deal: Graf von Helldorff gets a new judge for his trial and, in return, Goebbels promises the SA will not disrupt the visit.

column8: Loads of publicity and loud fanfares - that's how the stars of the 1920s celebrate their glitzy film premieres.
column11:
Palatial cinemas and glitzy premieres
Fanfares echo around Hardenbergstraße as the guests arrive for the gala performance. It's 23 October 1931 - the German premiere of the film Der Kongress tanzt at the Ufa-Palast am Zoo cinema. This musical comedy directed by Erik Charell is one of the very first films with sound. Production costs have run into the millions, and it features lavish costumes and sets. Thousands flock to the Berlin premiere, only to be disappointed when they are turned away.

The world premiere was held a few days earlier in Vienna - the film is, after all, about the Congress of Vienna - and it flopped. To prevent such a fiasco from happening again in Berlin, Ufa spends 30,000 Reichsmarks on advertising. The two leads, Lilian Harvey and Willy Fritsch, are also invited to appear at the gala performance. Ufa's strategy pays off and the glamorous premiere is a glittering success. 

Illuminated organs and air conditioning, neo-Romanesque and Baroque 

The Ufa-Palast am Zoo cinema stood on approximately the same site as the present Zoo Palast cinema, which opened in 1957. The exterior of the old Ufa-Palast was anything but modern. Forming part of the square that is sometimes called the "Romanesque Forum", it was built in a similar neo-Romanesque style to the Memorial Church. Behind the medieval-looking façade was an auditorium that could accommodate over 2,000 guests. The visual splendour was enhanced by a golden curtain and an illuminated organ, which projected coloured lights into the auditorium. 

The Ufa-Palast is the flagship premiere cinema owned by Universum Film AG, or Ufa for short. But it is not the only grand cinema in the vicinity. The Capitol cinema opened in 1925, right next to the Ufa-Palast, on the spot where the Bikinihaus building stands today. Hans Poelzig's new building had a simple, modern exterior and a colourful interior with air conditioning to ensure the comfort of cinemagoers. 

1926 saw the opening of another cinema, the Gloria-Palast. It was located next to the Memorial Church, on the site of the new Upper West skyscraper that opened in 2017. Like the Ufa-Palast, the exterior was neo-Romanesque, while the auditorium reminded the journalist Eugen Szatmari "more of an intimate little court theatre of the Baroque era than a 1927 cinema".  The premiere of The Blue Angel with Marlene Dietrich and Emil Jannings in the lead roles was held here in April 1930. 

Costume drama with catchy tunes 

The popularity of Der Kongress tanzt continued after its premiere and it became the most successful film of 1931.The story of the Russian Tsar who courts a glove saleswoman clearly appealed to filmgoers. The film was shot three times ¬- in German, English and French - because dubbing hadn't yet been invented. Lilian Harvey appears in all the different versions, whereas Willy Fritsch can only be seen in the German version, as he can't speak any other languages. The film is still remembered to this day, mainly because of the song Das gibt's nur einmal.
column13: Fritz Lang's Metropolis premieres at the Ufa-Palast am Zoo in 1927. Production takes over two years and expectations are high. Many celebrities turn up for the gala performance. Metropolis is aesthetically pleasing, but many people find the story too kitschy and the length of the film is somewhat challenging - the original version is more than two-and-a-half hours long.

column8: A Cold War escape route - the Glienicke Bridge is where the US and the USSR exchange their spies
column11:
The secret route to freedom
The morning of 10 February 1962 dawns cold and clear over Potsdam. At precisely 8.44am, a man steps onto the Glienicke Bridge. He walks slowly across the river Havel towards Berlin. He is the American pilot Francis Gary Powers - and when he reaches the halfway point, he knows he is finally free.

Six minutes later, KGB Colonel Rudolf Ivanovich Abel crosses the bridge in the opposite direction. The first exchange of spies on German soil between the United States and the Soviet Union has gone without a hitch. The exchange is top secret, but information still leaks out to the public. Glienicke Bridge in Berlin's south west hits the headlines and becomes famous around the world at the "Bridge of Spies". 

The perfect bridge for secret operations   

It's no coincidence that the US and USSR want to use this particular location for their top-secret exchanges. This steel construction first opened in 1907 as the Kaiser Wilhelm Bridge. Ironically, the GDR government later changes its name to the Bridge of Unity. It turns out to be the perfect place for conducting intelligence missions.  

Unlike the checkpoints in the city, traffic is light. In winter, the bridge disappears into the mist that hangs over the Havel. It's easy for representatives of the two superpowers to reach the bridge from Berlin and simple to monitor and secure the surroundings. So it's hardly surprising that, after the successful premiere, the Iron Curtain rises twice more to allow real or supposed agents to walk free.  

But we have to wait 20 years for the sequel. After years of intense negotiation, on the morning of 12 June 1985 the normally deserted bridge is a hive of activity. A bus is waiting on the Potsdam side of the bridge. It contains East Germans, Poles and an Austrian. Some of them have been in prison for years on suspicion of spying for the CIA. Limousines and minibuses approach the bridge from the West Berlin side. They are bringing four former spies from Warsaw Pact countries.  

23 US agents for 4 Soviet spies  

This exchange of prisoners has been mediated by Wolfgang Vogel, the GDR's famous negotiator. Once again he has done a good job: as the clock strikes noon, 23 US spies and 4 Soviet agents cross the border over the Havel. This time the agents are driven to the white border post in the middle of the bridge, where they simply swap vehicles.  

The third and last spy exchange on the Glienicke Bridge also goes smoothly. On 11 February 1986, four prisoners from the East are exchanged for five from the West. After German reunification, this wormhole between the two superpowers reverts to being a normal transport link. But the Bridge of Spies has never lost its fascination. In 2015, director Steven Spielberg visits this original location to shoot his film of the same name starring Tom Hanks.
column13: At the third prisoner exchange on the Glienicke Bridge, the USSR hands over Soviet dissident Anatoly Sharanski to the West. But the KGB agents still do their best to embarrass him by making him walk across the bridge in oversized trousers without a belt. He is forced to hold up his pants in front of the TV cameras.

column8: By the grace of the Emperor: Berlin tries to build a Protestant St. Peter's
column11:
Emperor and Church – a demonstration of power
Cold February skies hang heavy over Berlin as the dignitaries gather in the Lustgarten park. Kaiser Wilhelm II wanted the construction of the cathedral to be finished five years ago. But come what may, it will be consecrated today, on His Majesty's 24th wedding anniversary.

Wilhelm II is not too concerned about the fact that a few bronze doors are still missing and the painting above his personal box is not destined to be completed for many years. After all, he has to take the blame for some of the construction delays. No-one was given the freedom to turn their plans into reality without the Emperor's approval. Wilhelm II repeatedly made his architect, Julius Carl Raschdorff, revise his plans for the cathedral. The Emperor also had the final say on every single element of the cathedral's interior.  

A monument to Church and Emperor  

When you stand on the steps of the cathedral and look up at the richly decorated façade, you feel almost overwhelmed by its grandeur. This is exactly what Wilhelm II intended - for his imperial greatness to be reflected in this divine, monumental building. With the Lustgarten and Altes Museum to the rear and the Hohenzollern City Palace to the right, the new cathedral is the final piece in a complex designed to underline the monarchy's absolute power and the divine right of kings. Commoners and penitents feel very small when they stand before the 114-metre-high church. So it's fitting that the 10 million Reichsmark building costs were considered to be astronomical.  

On this February morning, the grand opening ceremony begins on the dot of 11. Their majesties are given a military welcome, then the head of the cathedral building committee presents Wilhelm II with the key. He hands it to his court chaplain, Ernst Dryander, who ceremoniously opens the cathedral doors. The imperial couple and congregation enter the church to the strains of Handel's Messiah. "The Empress wears a kindly expression; the Emperor is very stiff and dignified". This is how the newspapers describe the imperial couple the next day. 

Incongruous splendour  

The magnificent interior of what is now Germany's most important Protestant church takes your breath away. Wilhelm II specifically wants it to rival the mighty Cologne Cathedral. As you stand beneath the magnificent dome, surrounded by gold, marble, mosaics and columns, you could be in a Catholic cathedral. The design of the cathedral is very much to the Kaiser's taste, but the mishmash of architectural styles came under fire long before the building was completed. But now the congregation sings Now Thank We All Our God as the bells of all the Protestant churches in Berlin ring out in honour of the Almighty and his new cathedral.
column12:
Opening hours:
1 April to 30 September: daily from 9am to 8pm
1 October to 31 March: daily from 9am to 7pm

For more information on this location, events and tickets, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/berlin-cathedral
column13: Court chaplain Ernst Dryander plays an important role in the lives of the royal family. He oversees Crown Prince Wilhelm's confirmation and is with Empress Auguste Viktoria when the monarchy is overthrown. On 14 November 1918, Dryander officiates at the final church service before the imperial family leaves the New Palace in Potsdam. In 1921 he presides over the Empress's funeral.

column8: AEG turbine factory in Moabit: A machine cathedral of steel and glass from the early 1900s.
column11:
An icon of Berlin’s industrial heritage
In Berlin's Moabit district, Huttenstraße is home to a pivotal development in architectural history. In designing the new AEG Turbine Factory, lead architect Peter Behrens and civil engineer Karl Bernhard create the first formal vocabulary for industrial buildings. The Turbine Factory also employs a mix of modern materials - combining primarily steel components and glass with the more traditional stone.

In the early 1900s, AEG is a leading German manufacturer of electrical equipment. To expand its operations, it decides to move into steam turbine production. But for its new division, AEG needs a new large facility, reflecting the global demand for this sector. After all, steam turbines are far more efficient as a source of power than the classic steam engine.

Avant-garde architecture

The commission for the new production hall is awarded to Peter Behrens, an architect and designer who studied at art colleges in Hamburg, Karlsruhe and Düsseldorf. With his strong background in design, he is also employed by AEG as an artistic consultant. Behrens works on product designs, graphics and the company logo - essentially creating AEG's corporate design long before such a term even existed.

Peter Behrens first came to public notice in 1901, with the design of his house in the Darmstadt Artists' Colony. In 1907, he was also a founder member of the Deutscher Werkbund, an association bringing together artists, architects and designers with politicians and industrialists to drive forward the production of high-quality goods. While initially the association drew its inspiration from the English arts and crafts movement, it increasingly turned to focus on architecture.

In the Germany of those days, there is no dedicated architectural style for industrial buildings. Instead, industrial facades simply tend to follow the historicist revivalist styles dominant during those years. In 1908, Behrens' innovative design for the new AEG turbine production hall creates a prototype for modern industrial architecture. The factory hall is constructed with a steel skeleton. The large glass windows filling much of the façade surfaces ensure the interior is light and transparent. The bright, natural light is also seen as a means of increasing productivity.

Visible function

Start by looking at the front façade with its massive stone elements, recalling an Egyptian temple. Set on either side of the large glass window, the stone creates an impression of grandeur, yet neither of these elements are load bearing. They are just for show, merely external cladding. But contemporaries were quick to pick up Behrens' reference to sacral space and soon dubbed the factory hall a machinery cathedral.

In contrast, with visible steel trusses and joints, the side façade in Berlichingenstraße looks very modern - just as Karl Bernhard, the project's civil engineer, intended. In this way, rather than concealed behind a pseudo-historical façade, the industrial building's function as a production site is clearly inscribed in its design.

Even today, Bernhard's role is often underestimated. Far from solely making Behrens's ingenious design a reality, he plays a significant part in its creation. Nonetheless, Behrens, as the famous artist architect, has always outshone Karl Bernhard as a civil engineer. The architects in Peter Behrens' architectural practice include not only Walter Gropius and Ludwig Mies van der Rohe, both later renowned figures at the Bauhaus, but also Le Corbusier. Mies van der Rohe even drew the design for the side hall of the AEG Turbine Factory.
column13: The AEG Turbine Factory survived the Second World War largely unscathed. Since 1977, it has belonged to the Siemens complex. AEG only exists now as a brand. Nonetheless, the factory building is still in use - today, producing Siemens gas turbines, a new generation of the turbines produced there in 1909. So even if the technology has constantly developed, the Turbine Factory is still aptly named!

column8: The Badewanne Jazz Club starts putting on shows in the cellar - and makes cabaret history
column11:
Biting wit, prickly satire
You're standing in front of one of Berlin's longest and most beautiful façades. The Femina-Palast is an extraordinary testimony to the Roaring Twenties. With its long, 185-metre-long strips of windows, brass door frames and walls clad in travertine, the result is an attractive blend of Bauhaus and Art Deco.

What happens behind the façade is also a source of pride. Jazz greats like Ella Fitzgerald and Duke Ellington perform in the Badewanne, the jazz club in the basement. And on 29 October 1949, it writes a new chapter in political satire when it premieres a cabaret troupe called Die Stachelschweine (The Porcupines). Their first show is retrospectively named Alles irrsinnig komisch (Everything Is Hilarious), and it goes on to be staged every Tuesday and Friday.  

How does humour work in the new democracy? Thierry, whose real name is Dieter Koch, writes the shows with cabaret founder Rolf Ulrich. He comes up with the name Die Stachelschweine because they want to be prickly, pointed and push the envelope of post-war, post-Nazi Germany. Alexander Welbat, Klaus Becker and Joachim Teege are some of the troupe's first freewheeling performers, alongside future TV stars such as Günter Pfitzmann.  

The second show, called per-speck-tiefen, opens up new horizons for the young ensemble. At the Badewanne, conflicts with another cabaret troupe lead to a change of venue. The Stachelschweine move to the Burgkeller restaurant at Kurfürstendamm 12 in February 1950. Their involuntary tour continues via the Nürnberger Trichter restaurant to the Ewige Lampe at Rankestraße 9, where the ensemble stays for twelve years.  

Straight-talking, Berlin style 

Over the years, the Stachelschweine has included numerous witty, sharp-tongued cabaret artists who have shaped the cabaret genre in Berlin. Achim Strietzel is so good at imitating Governing Mayor Willy Brandt that people stop him in the street and ask him to "Do Willy". Then there's fast-talking Wolfgang Gruber; Wolfgang Neuss, whose famous catchphrase is available today as a fridge magnet; and Berlin's own Edith Hancke, who began her long career with the Stachelschweine in the Fifties. When she died, Berlin's newspaper Der Tagesspiegel simply headlined her obituary: "The eternal brat". 

They all turn the politics of reconstruction and economic miracle into satire - and some of the audience find their laughter sticks in their throats. Subversive and enigmatic, the Stachelschweine turn the spotlight on the Nazi heritage, the grotesqueness of two German states and the neuroses that develop in a front-line city like Berlin. The troupe survived the division of Germany and still play seven nights a week at the Europa-Center.
column13: The Stachelschweine celebrate their 5th, 10th and 15th anniversaries with a run of special sold-out shows at Berlin Sports Palace, which was demolished in 1973. This venue is also known as the site of Joseph Goebbels' propaganda speech about "total war", given in 1943.

column8: Where they burn books, they will ultimately burn people. Opernplatz in the heart of Berlin
column11:
The sunken library
The evening of 10 May 1933. It's pouring with rain. A huge bonfire has been built in the centre of the square known as Opernplatz. The logs have been placed on top of piles of sand to protect the old cobblestones. 5,000 students from Berlin University show up to watch the ritual burning. Many of them are wearing the brown and black shirts of the SA and SS.

Burning torches held aloft, hundreds of Brownshirts are on the march from Gendarmenmarkt to Opernplatz. Some are carrying banners with the words "Against the Un-German Spirit".  Several trucks pull up on the square. They are loaded with around 300,000 books, pillaged from the surrounding libraries. 

This impressive spectacle has been organised by the National Socialist German Student Association. They have drawn up blacklists containing the names of 130 authors, including Heinrich, Thomas and Klaus Mann, Kurt Tucholsky, Heinrich Heine, Franz Kafka and Bertolt Brecht. In the jargon of the National Socialists, their works are "undesirable, decadent, un-German literature". 

"Fire oaths" and a carnival atmosphere  

A large crowd is gathering on the square. It includes students, teaching staff and curious onlookers. The smell of wood and bratwurst is in the air. A brass band strikes up. There's a real carnival atmosphere. The Deutsche Wochenschau newsreel team are filming, and their spotlights bathe the square in a harsh light.  

The students throw the first books onto the fire, but it struggles to get going. It's raining so hard that the flames keep going out. The square fills with smoke. The fire brigade arrives and pours petrol on the flames. Finally, the books begin to burn. Young men hurl piles of books into the flames, while the loudspeakers blare out "fire oaths": "Against class struggle and materialism, for national community and idealistic lifestyle! I consign the works of Marx and Kautsky to the flames." They trumpet the names of another 15 authors. That night, many writers' works go up in smoke.  

Minister of Propaganda Joseph Goebbels arrives around midnight. He did not order the book burning, but he's delighted that the students have taken the initiative. He climbs onto a pedestal and gives an incendiary speech, railing against the "un-German spirit".   

The sunken library 

Today, Opernplatz is called Bebelplatz. When you stroll across the square, you often come across people looking at a particular spot on the ground. When you get closer, you see a glass plate set into the paving stones. Below is an underground room with empty bookshelves - with space to hold around 20,000 books. This sunken library is a memorial created by Israeli artist Micha Ullman. A bronze plate set into the ground bears Heinrich Heine's warning from 1820: "...where they burn books, they will ultimately burn people".
column12:
Freely accessible

For more information on this location, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/book-burning-memorial-bebelplatz
column13: Reviled and persecuted, many writers fled Germany before 1933. But not Erich Kästner. On this particular evening, the popular children's author happens to be crossing Opernplatz on his way home. Aghast, he stares at the fanatical crowd around the fire. Then he hears one of the students scream: "Against decadence and moral decay! For discipline and decency in family and state! I consign the works of Heinrich Mann, Ernst Glaeser and Erich Kästner to the flames."  Kästner realises free speech is a thing of the past. After the book burning, the National Socialists ban him from publishing any more books. Later, Kästner writes in his diary: "Funeral weather hung over the city."

column8: Nazi visions of a "world capital" called Germania sink into the sandy soil
column11:
Planning and experimenting for Germania
Adolf Hitler is clearly impressed by the four-metre-high model of a triumphal arch. It's a present for his 50th birthday. General Building Inspector Albert Speer is pleased with his choice of gift. Years earlier, Hitler had given him a sketch of a triumphal arch that he had drawn himself. Now it is to be the centrepiece of the new imperial capital of Germania. The arch never gets built, but Berlin still bears the traces of this gigantic building project.

The sheer size of the world's biggest triumphal arch Is hard to grasp. The Arc de Triomphe in Paris would fit into it several times. But that's also a worry for Albert Speer - is it actually structurally possible to build such an arch?  

Sandy Berlin  

The General Building Inspector has a problem. Unlike other major European cities, Berlin is not built on rock, but on sand. That presents something of a challenge for his building plans. To be on the safe side, Speer orders the construction of a test load structure. 

You are now standing on a viewing platform on General-Pape-Strasse. If you look to the north, you will see a huge grey cylinder sticking out of the ground between the trees. This is the structure now known as the Heavy Load-Bearing Body. Its only function was to simulate the weight of the planned triumphal arch and the pressure it would exert on Berlin's sandy substrata. Is it possible for the marshy, sandy ground to support such a building? Now look behind you, to the south, and you are looking at the spot where the triumphal arch was due to soar to the heavens as a memorial to the fallen soldiers of the First World War.  

With typical Prussian thoroughness, engineers examine the impression made by the 12,650-tonne concrete block and take measurements in the soil. They find it has sunk by 19.4 centimetres, more than expected. But the engineers don't give up hope. They believe the triumphal arch can still be built if they stabilise the soil. Fortunately, it never comes to that.   

During opening hours, you can also look around the inside of the structure. Below ground, the building is 18 metres deep and there are places where you can look all the way down. 

Germania needs space 

The Heavy Load-Bearing Body is, quite literally, a concrete reminder of the planning carried out by the General Building Inspector. But traces of these plans can be found in other parts of the city. The one thing Speer needs for his massive buildings is space, and lots of it. The Victory Column stands in the way of his plans to build the world's largest domed building, the Hall of the People. So he has the column moved from its spot in front of the Reichstag building to the centre of the Great Star road intersection.  

Speer is even more radical when it comes to residential buildings. Tens of thousands of them will need to be demolished. But what about the people who lose their homes? Some of them can be accommodated in new settlements on the outskirts of the city. The Jewish population is also affected by the Nazis' plans, but they are simply forced to leave without legal justification or compensation for the loss of their homes. At least Speer's monstrous architectural vision never becomes reality.
column12:
Opening hours: 
April to October:
Tuesday and Wednesday, 2pm - 6pm
Thursday, 10am - 6pm
Sunday, 1pm - 6pm
November to March:
Winter break (group tours by appointment only)

For more information on this location, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/schwerbelastungskorper-heavy-load-bearing-body
column13: Speer plans to remove the Heavy Load-Bearing Body at a later date. The site will be filled in and covered by a new road that is yet another part of his grandiose plans. The Heavy Load-Bearing Body was not demolished with explosives after the war because of its residential location. Therefore, to this day, it stands as a silent reminder of the Nazis' monstrous plans for Germania.

column8: Anarchy and techno: when the Wall comes down, the strobes light up
column11:
The birthplace of Berlin’s club scene
The Mall of Berlin on Leipziger Platz stands on the site of a legendary club. In 1990, Dimitri Hegemann stepped into the basement of the former Wertheim department store. He was engulfed by a wave of cold, musty air as he entered a rusting steel chamber - the vault of the former Globus Reisebank.

"The first time we went in, we had no idea what to expect. We used a cigarette lighter to see where we were going. There were white tiles everywhere. Then suddenly there was another room, a steel door, we saw the safety deposit boxes, the window bars, and we were speechless. We immediately knew this place was something special." Three months later Hegemann opens Tresor, Berlin's first techno club, in the vault.  

A touch of anarchy 

So how do you stumble upon an abandoned bank vault in the centre of Berlin? When the Wall comes down, the city is left in limbo. The GDR's laws no longer apply, and no new rules have been made. Squatters move into empty buildings, the East German police are at a loss and simply ignored, illegal clubs spring up. A breath of anarchy is blowing through the formerly divided city.  

This chaotic situation combines with the euphoria of Berlin's reunited citizens. All over the city, they are celebrating their new-found freedom: in former factories and overground bunkers, on car park roofs, in abandoned cellars. Many of the new clubs are named after their previous function, and suddenly E-Werk, Tresor, and Bunker are throbbing to one beat - techno. It's the soundtrack to the fall of the Wall.   

"Like a good wine, a good club gets better with age" 

The techno clubs of the Nineties attract clubbers from all over the world. Dimitri Hegemann plays a key role in this, flying in top international DJs like Jeff Mills and Juan Atkins. Tresor still exists today. In an interview in 2016, Hegemann suggests than an unusual location is the key to lasting success: "The club wouldn't have been as popular if we hadn't set it up in its old location, that rusting vault under the former Wertheim building on Leipziger Platz." 

He adds that a good club is like good wine - it gets better with age. When the former Wertheim department store is demolished in 2007, Tresor moves to Köpenicker Strasse. But its success continues. Every weekend, people still flock to Berlin to party in Hegemann's Tresor - surrounded by barred windows and safety deposit boxes.
column13: When Dimitri Hegemann first visits the old vault, he discovers more than a home for his legendary techno club. The vault also contains dusty GDR insignia from the 1951 World Festival of Youth - and 6,000 East German marks in cash.

column8: Angry East German citizens storm the Stasi headquarters, but the secret service can also claim a victory.
column11:
The fall of the grey fortress
On 15 January 1990, a peaceful demonstration at the Stasi headquarters turned into a furious attack on the secret service's grey fortress. But most agents had already left the complex. 

It is early evening on 15 January 1990. Pastor and civil rights activist Martin Montag from Thuringia can hardly believe what is happening. He is standing at the Stasi headquarters in Berlin-Lichtenberg, trying to persuade demonstrators not to storm the Ministry of State Security. 

How come a clergyman who is opposed to the regime is attempting to protect East Germany's hated secret police from an angry mob? 

This unlikely situation has come about because, all day long, the Ministry has been haunted by its political opponents. At midday on 15 January 1990, civil rights groups led by Martin Montag "occupied" the building during a peaceful visit to negotiate the dissolution of this organisation. 

Protesters bring radical change   

At this point, nobody imagines that a public demonstration which, by chance, has been planned for the same day will radically alter the course of events.  

A small crowd is expected, but in facts tens of thousands of East German citizens show up, all bursting with anger and indignation about being spied upon for the last 40 years. They force their way into the once impenetrable Stasi headquarters, opening up the gates from the inside. Overwhelmed, the police can do nothing to hold back the angry mob. Even Martin Montag has to stand back. 

Go through the main gate and enter the complex on Normannenstraße. Take a left - towards Building 18 - and you are following the exact route taken by those protesters 28 years ago. Today it's very peaceful, but at that time your ears would have been ringing. Thousands of voices chanting "Down with the Stasi!". A placard depicting Erich Honecker dressed as a convict. Glass flying around as windows are shattered.  But for some protesters, their sense of triumph at storming the building mingles with a sense of unease. What if they are attacked by the Stasi? 

The Prime Minister's appeals for calm fall on deaf ears     

But where are all the Stasi agents? It seems they have given up their supposedly impenetrable fortress without a fight. But that's hardly surprising, as they had already begun shredding files back in October 1989. 

The rioters soon realise there's nothing to find. In their fury they break windows, smash office equipment, ransack a hair salon, plunder a storeroom and refuse to be placated by the words of Prime Minister Hans Modrow, who has rushed to the scene. 

The demonstrators rampage unhindered around Building 18, but in fact they marched straight past the Stasi's true centre of power right at the start. 

But one thing is clear - on the evening of 15 January 1990 the people of East Germany liberated themselves from the hated secret police. However, their victory was largely symbolic, as even the secret service had grounds for feeling they had come out on top. Ultimately, the people's rage only led to modest amounts of damage to an ancillary building. And the protesters failed to get their hands on a single important file.
column12:
Opening hours:
Mon - Fri 10am - 6pm
Sat, Sun 11am - 6pm
Public holidays 11am - 6pm
Closed on 24 and 31 December

For more information on this location, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/stasi-museum
column13: When the Stasi began destroying their secret files in October 1989 they soon came up against a logistical hurdle - the executive offices had very few electric shredders. So shredding thousands of sheets of paper proved to be a hugely painstaking task.

column8: The Nazis force a compulsory sale of the Kempinski business and murder one of the owners
column11:
The Kempinski Restaurant’s Aryanisation
31 January 1939. We are in the Kempinski Restaurant on Kurfürstendamm boulevard. The setting is elegant and luxurious - marble, mahogany, and ivory. As always, the restaurant is bustling. The waiters hurry from table to table. The smell of fried steak fills the room. Several SS officers in uniform are waiting for their order. At the same time, Walter Unger is sitting at a table in a neighbouring room, gaunt and pale, his suit now far too big for his emaciated body. Unger is co-owner of Kempinski, brought here especially from Sachsenhausen concentration camp - but only to agree to the further Aryanisation of his business.

Cosmopolitan flair on Ku'damm boulevard 

In 1926, the doors of the Kempinski Restaurant open. The guests stream into this new culinary palace, dedicated to good food. Every day, the restaurant is packed. The open-air terrace is especially popular with locals. The cars roar past, and women with bobbed hair and men in frock coats stroll the boulevard. And inside? The local Berliner Zeitung newspaper enthuses: "A marvel of architecture ...  sophisticated and welcoming, yet as the Berliner would say, really cosy". Business is booming. For the Kempinski family business, their Kurfürstendamm restaurant is the jewel in the crown in a chain of fine hotels and restaurants.  

In 1863, Berthold Kempinski, a Jewish businessman from Posen in today's Poland, founds a wine merchant shop. In 1872, he opens a branch in Berlin's Friedrichstraße, followed by restaurants in Leipziger Strasse and on Kurfürstendamm. In 1928, the Kempinski business takes over the Hotel Vaterland at Potsdamer Platz.  

The golden years end in 1933. Across Germany, the Nazi regime organises boycotts of Jewish shops and businesses - a campaign also affecting the restaurant. At the same time, they start the "Aryanisation" - the compulsory sale - of Jewish firms. Large companies like Kempinski are not initially targeted - they are too important for the German economy.  

A tragic end 

In 1937, Richard Unger, Berthold Kempinski's son-in-law, has to negotiate the forced sale of the Kempinski group. Aschinger, one of Europe's largest hotel and restaurant companies, is keen to take it over. Aschinger promises "top quality at the lowest prices" - and has strong business links with the Nazi regime.  

On 29 April 1937, after protracted negotiations, the Kempinski business becomes a limited company, a subsidiary of Aschinger. The Kempinski family no longer have a say in the business. Nearly all the family members leave Germany. Walter Unger, the son of the main shareholder, remains in Germany to wind up the business. He hopes to save parts of it - a vain hope.  

In 1938, Walter Unger is arrested and taken to Sachsenhausen concentration camp. In January 1939, he is brought back to the Kempinski Restaurant once more, for the final renegotiation. Four years later, Walter Unger is deported as number 014387 to Theresienstadt concentration camp. In 1944, he is murdered in Auschwitz.
column13: Richard Tauber is a celebrated opera star. In 1933, he spends his last evening in Germany in the Kempinski Restaurant. When Tauber wants to enter the restaurant, he is assaulted by the SA Brownshirts. "Jewish lout! Get out of Germany!", they yell at him, punching him several times in his face. The same night Tauber leaves Germany forever.

column8: Tempelhofer Feld is closely connected with the history of aviation - and delays have always been a part of flying
column11:
Miss Columbia and the dream of flight
On 6 June 1927, 150,000 people stream onto the Tempelhofer Feld. Only the fortunate few can realise the dream of flight, but wherever planes touch down, they quickly draw huge crowds. On Tempelhofer Feld, these aviation enthusiasts are waiting to welcome Clarence Chamberlin. His planned non-stop flight from New York to Berlin is front-page news. Accompanied by millionaire Charles Levine, Chamberlin hopes to break Lindbergh's record transatlantic flight just a few days before. But just short of Magdeburg, Chamberlin runs out of fuel. His single engine Wright-Bellanca WB-2, christened the Columbia, has to land near Eisleben. The massed crowd in Berlin waits in vain for the record-breaking plane.

After refuelling the next day, Chamberlin manages to miss Berlin. He stops over in Cottbus and finally lands on Tempelhofer Feld to a rapturous reception. Sirens announce Chamberlin's imminent arrival. The crowd roars out a welcome when Miss Columbia, as the plane is nicknamed, appears on the horizon flanked by other aircraft. Two years later, the road past the Tempelhofer Feld is officially named Columbiadamm in honour of Chamberlin's plane.

The new airport

Today, when you stand on the Tempelhofer Feld, you are on a vast park called the Tempelhofer Freiheit - "Tempelhof Freedom". Here, in the heart of the city, you can look out across kilometres of this former airfield, now open parkland. There are just a few trees standing in the centre. Today, hardly anyone knows that this exact spot is the site of first Tempelhof Airport. Here, aviation history was written. For two hundred years, the Prussian Army uses this vast area as an exercise ground. In the early 1900s, aviation pioneers give their flying displays here. Then, on 8 October 1923, Tempelhofer Feld airport opens.

In those early years, it's a modest operation with only a few hangers for planes. During the airport's first year, just 150 passengers fly out from the Tempelhofer Feld. No planes are allowed to start or land on Sundays, and since the aircraft are not heated, no passenger planes fly in winter.

Just a few years later, the world looks a very different place. The Deutsche Luft Hansa Aktiengesellschaft (German Air Hansa Company) makes Tempelhof its home airport. Finally, the airfield can boast a dark-red brick airport building. The signature feature is two red-and-white radio towers. Despite the paint, they still look remarkably like the Funkturm Radio Tower at Berlin's fairs and exhibitions ground - which is no surprise as they are designed by the same architect, Heinrich Straumer.

Always against the wind

In 1929, the airport building is finished - already much too small for the volume of air traffic. Plans are already made for a new building, later built under the Nazi regime. After the war, the first airport building disappears almost without trace. Today, only the Tempelhofer Freiheit park's round shape recalls the old airport. With these early aircraft always having to start into the wind, the first airfield only has a circular grassed area and not concrete runways. In this way, these light propeller aircraft were free to start in any direction - a tradition of freedom still thriving on today's Tempelhofer Freiheit park.
column12: For more information on events and tickets, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/flughafen-tempelhof-tempelhof-airport
column13: In 1909, the Wright brothers, the world's first pilots of heavier-than-air aircraft, took off on Tempelhofer Feld and flew thirty metres - at that time, quite an achievement.

column8: When big banks fail - the financial crisis of 1931 unleashes a frightening scenario
column11:
Death of a bank
Imagine that it's Monday morning and you're on your way to work. You walk past Danatbank, a branch of Germany's second-largest bank here on Nollendorfplatz. People have gathered around a notice saying Danatbank is temporarily closed, but all savings deposits are safe as the government will guarantee these deposits and maintain business as usual.

The notice is meant to be reassuring, but unfortunately it has quite the opposite effect. Now you're thinking you're glad your account is with the Sparkasse, not Danatbank. But you still rush round there to withdraw your money, just in case. You find yourself standing in a long queue at the Sparkasse. The run on the banks has begun. By 11.30 on the morning of 13 July 1931, the banks can no longer cope with the stampede of customers. Berliner Sparkasse alone has to pay out seven million Reichsmark. Bank holidays are declared to keep the banking system from total collapse. "Holidays" sounds harmless enough, but these prove to be dark days for the financial sector. Nobody can access their savings, and monetary transactions grind to a halt for weeks on end. 

Despair and distrust 

The banking crisis is homemade. German banks have taken out short-term foreign loans and used the money to offer longer-term loans to German companies - but without adequate capital to cover these longer terms. German industry is struggling after the stock market crash of 1929. Foreign creditors are getting jittery about the success of extremists in the Reichstag elections of September 1930 - especially the Nazi Party, which gets 18.3 percent of the vote. Confidence starts to wane in the reliability of German companies and the stability of the German government. Hundreds of millions of Reichsmark are withdrawn and the Reichsbank is running out of cash. Germany is on the verge of insolvency. 

Bail-outs, nationalisations and a bad bank 

The Danatbank is the worst hit. Its head is Jakob Goldschmidt, one of Germany's best-known bankers, but he has overcooked the bank's expansion with some risky lending. The collapse of the Bremer Nordwolle company, which had disguised its losses and falsified its balance sheets, has dragged Danatbank into the red. Attempts to set up a solidarity package are unsuccessful after resistance from the bank's competitors - other major banks are not keen to get their fingers burned. 

Standstill agreements with foreign lenders and the suspension of reparation payments help to calm the situation, and the introduction of a regulatory system shows that politicians are looking for long-term solutions. But it's too late for Danatbank, which is taken over by the state-owned Dresdner Bank. Other big banks like Commerzbank and Deutsche Bank are restructured with state aid. And a crisis management instrument is introduced that has a familiar ring to it. An acceptance house and guarantee bank is set up to provide guarantees to the Reichsbank and allow troubled credit institutions to secure additional capital - the historical equivalent of a bad bank.
column13: The Berliner Handels-Gesellschaft is the only major bank to survive the crisis without a state bail-out. For the other banks, it takes until 1936 before their partial nationalisation is reversed through private buy-backs.

column8: At Haus Vaterland, dining is a unique experience, offering exoticism and folklore all under one roof
column11:
Exoticism and delusions of grandeur
It's an autumn evening in 1928. We're standing in front of the Haus Vaterland (Fatherland House). Behind us we hear the roar of the traffic on Potsdamer Platz. Dozens of people are streaming into the huge, brightly-lit building. Everyone is curious. Just like us, they can't wait to see what this new pleasure palace has to offer.

Come with me on a tour of the building! There's a huge cinema and a dance hall with sprung parquet flooring. And there are so many places to eat and drink, all run by the famous Kempinski family. Let's start off in the Café Vaterland. We sit at one of hundreds of tables illuminated by magnificent chandeliers. The walls are adorned with paintings, marble and mosaics, and the cafe has a modern, sophisticated feel. But we're looking for a touch of exoticism and extravagance. 

Rhinish gaiety or Bavarian cosiness? 

Let's take a peek at the Rhineland Terrace. Its main attraction is a 3D river diorama. In the background there's a painting of the Rhine valley, complete with castle ruins. In front there is a river with actual water and model boats. First you hear the birds twittering. Then a storm moves in with rain, thunder and lightning. And finally a rainbow appears - the storm is over. But none of the guests get wet. A pane of glass prevents you from getting soaked and saves your Rhineland wine from being diluted.  

Maybe you prefer beer to wine? Let's head for the Löwenbräu. This beer cellar features a two-storey-high glass painting of the Eibsee lake and the Zugspitze mountain. Backlighting creates a range of effects, such as the morning sun and the alpenglow. Bavarian music, Bavarian dancing and, of course, Bavarian beer are also on the menu. 

A quick trip to Turkey, Hungary or the Wild West? 

At the Haus Vaterland you can also travel further afield. There's a Turkish café that is "surely more beautiful than any in the whole of Turkey", as it is described by the Vossische Zeitung. Or we can go to the Hungarian Czarda, a peasant tavern from the Puszta, where "fiery" music gives the evening a more melancholy feel. The walls of the Wild West Bar make it look like a log cabin, and it has a diorama of the Rocky Mountains. Perhaps we'll be served by Mohamed Husen in his cowboy gear. He's actually from East Africa, not North America - but we don't need to get too hung up on the details.  

We finish our tour in Vienna. In the Grinzinger Heuriger tavern you sit under a lilac bower listening to the sounds of the waltz while enjoying fine wine and Viennese delicacies. But now you've probably had enough. The Haus Vaterland knows how to overwhelm your eyes, ears and taste buds! I hope you've enjoyed your tour and it wasn't too crowded - despite the fact that it has had 8,000 visitors today.
column13: The operation is run by Leo Kronau, an international expert in the entertainment business. He was previously the head of Berlin's Luna Park. He has a vision for the pleasure palace: "People don't move from one restaurant to another, they lose themselves [...] in the universality of the world."

column8: When the apparatchiks step out in front of the crowd, they are met with jeers and boos
column11:
State apparatchiks are booed off the stage
The biggest demonstration in the history of the GDR takes place five days before the fall of the Berlin Wall. In front of the crowd on Alexanderplatz, artists and functionaries demand a new political beginning. Nobody is thinking about reunification - but then again, nobody believes that socialism can be saved either.

It is 4 November 1989, and Markus Wolf, who has headed up the dreaded GDR foreign intelligence service for the last 34 years, appears before a crowd of demonstrators who have gathered in Alexanderplatz. He is met by a chorus of jeers and boos. The hands of the once powerful man start to shake. Civil rights activist Bärbel Bohley notices his nervousness and in that moment realises for the very first time that "The revolution is irreversible".  

Less than a month earlier and the GDR is celebrating its 40th birthday with an ostentatious military parade for state visitors such as Mikhail Gorbachev and Nicolae Ceausescu. Although they don't realise it at the time, this is the day that the SED leadership will sow the seeds for the Alexanderplatz demonstration a few weeks later - because citizens protesting against the anniversary celebrations are brutally chased away and beaten by the People's Police and the Stasi.   

The demo is not anti-GDR, but pro-democracy  

However, the organs of state security do not intimidate the GDR's dissidents with this orgy of violence. Quite the opposite: the citizens' movement New Forum and representatives of East Berlin's theatres use the attacks as justification for calling the demonstration on 4 November. The strategy adopted by the civil rights activists and regime critics is simple - they are not demonstrating against the GDR but in favour of a new democratic socialism, freedom of speech and freedom of the press. 

When the event kicks off at 10am on 4 November in front of the ADN (General German Intelligence Service) building in Mollstraße, it quickly develops into the biggest non-governmental demonstration in the history of the GDR. Hundreds of thousands of people converge on the Palast der Republik before moving on to Alexanderplatz for the final rally with 20 speakers from the arts and politics. 

The protesters come up with some witty and creative slogans for their banners, such as "Send the Stasi to Benghazi".

The intellectuals want to save the GDR, but it's too late  

Feelings in the country are running so high that the rally is even broadcast on GDR television. Stasi shills among the demonstrators have little effect - the crowd cheers loudly for authors like Christa Wolf and actors Ulrich Mühe and Jan Josef Liefers, while Politburo member Günter Schabowski and former spy Markus Wolf are mercilessly booed and jeered. 

Looking back, historian Ilko-Sascha Kowalczuk believes that "The event was sustained by a belief that nothing should remain as it is",  "Freedom had to come". 

Christa Wolf, Friedrich Schorlemmer and other speakers call on people not to leave the country - but these intellectuals are also a little out of touch with the prevailing mood. That weekend alone, more than 60,000 mainly young citizens flee the GDR through third countries. It's already too late to save the first socialist state on German soil.
column13: The witty, mocking banners of the demonstrators epitomise the critical but peaceful mood of the event. One of the stage designers from the Maxim Gorki Theatre collects them up after the demo. Everyone involved seems to be aware that they have just made history. The banners have been in the possession of the German Historical Museum in Berlin since 1994.

column8: The collective defeats capitalism - and becomes a property owner
column11:
Have you got two million marks?
It's the mid-1970s. The Kreuzberg district of Berlin, home to leftists, anarchists and punks, is being hit by a wave of demolitions. The area is being systematically torn apart. The people of Kreuzberg decide to resist the destruction and start occupying empty houses. Graffiti proclaiming Legal, illegal, don't give a shit! starts to appear on walls around the neighbourhood.

Something strange is happening in the courtyard behind Gneisenaustraße 2, where you're standing now. An alternative project is in the pipeline. The organisers have even set up an official property management company so that they can buy the premises of what was previously the Berthold foundry. A 5,000-square-metre courtyard for just under two million D-Mark. The Mehringhof collective is keen to ensure that it does everything legally and above board.  

It all starts with a grass-roots school 

At the end of the 1970s, the SFE school - which you can still attend in the Mehringhof today - was desperately in need of new premises. This independent college provides adults with a second chance at education. In the Seventies, it was expanding and open to new joint ventures. The result was a merger with other similar, like-minded initiatives and the decision to move into Gneisenaustraße 2 as joint owners. Regular monthly meetings were held to approve new tenants, how much money should be spent on the buildings, and what the theme of the next Mehringhof Festival should be.   

Alternative, democratic, united  

Today, the courtyard is still home to a unique mix of projects and businesses. The brick buildings provide every tenant with all the space they need. With its reputation for tolerance, the Mehringhof is a breeding ground for radical, leftist and collective ideas. Alongside the bike shop, theatre, print workshop and pub you will also find a medical centre for refugees, a Latin American newspaper, a Turkish workers' association and an emergency shelter that provides the homeless with a refuge on cold winter nights. Schwarze Risse was originally set up as an information centre for the anti-nuclear movement, but for the last 40 years, it has been a bookshop with a distinctly political flavour. 

Back in 1979, no-one imagined that the organisations, shops, initiatives and projects that make up the Mehringhof would still be operating independently 40 years later. It was quite an achievement to use capital to thumb its nose at the capitalism that was threatening to destroy Kreuzberg.
column12: For more information on this location and tickets, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/mehringhof-theater
column13: The SFE is an integral part of the Mehringhof's story. In 2016, the adult education college was awarded the prestigious German School Award. The jury praised the concept behind this privately run, alternative school. It doesn't grade its students and allows them to have a say in drawing up the curriculum.

column8: The Politburo is the GDR's seat of power and Erich Honecker is its leader. But it collapses in 1989
column11:
No country for old men
On 6 January 1986, former Poilitburo member Herbert Häber is ordered to go to the East German government hospital, from where he is taken to Bernburg Psychiatric Hospital. Completely taken by surprise, Häber is deemed a "hopeless case" and locked up in the secure wing. Erich Honecker has arranged for his former expert on relations with the West to be sidelined.

The Häber case highlights the dangers of belonging to the GDR's inner circle in the 1980s. The Politburo might be the state's most powerful body, but its leader wields the true power. Since 1971 this has been Erich Honecker.  

Every Tuesday morning, Politburo members pull up on Marx-Engels-Platz in Berlin-Mitte in their Volvo limousines. This building on Werderscher Markt opened as the Reichsbank in 1940. It is the very building where the Politburo met every week at 10am sharp.  

Honecker would open the meeting, then decisions would be made about everything from economic plans to car prices, building projects and parades. The Politburo wields unlimited power and ministers in the elected government are bound by its directives. This is how East Germany is governed.  

Later, Politburo member Günter Schabowski describes the meetings as having a "classroom atmosphere". Honecker is the teacher, the others are the students. The 15 to 25 voting members and 10 non-voting candidate members do not enter into any heated debates. The General Secretary has gathered a group of yes-men and opportunists, and at the end of the day he makes the final decision.   

Their ritualistic nodding and blind faith in their leader eventually come home to roost. The members of the Politburo - many of whom are well past retirement age - fail to act when the mass exodus of East German citizens begins in 1989. They are either away on holiday or simply look on apathetically. Even the General Secretary is away from his post. He's recovering from a gall bladder operation.  

When Honecker returns for the Politburo meeting 17 October 1989, he asks for "proposals for the agenda". Willi Stoph proposes that Honecker be released from his duties. The boss is speechless. Günter Schabowski later recalls that Honecker's reaction was "50 percent bewilderment and 50 percent not wanting to believe it". Now even Honecker's loyal comrades are stabbing him in the back. The Politburo votes unanimously to dismiss him, and Honecker even raises his own hand in agreement - as is the tradition.  

What happened to the Politburo's former scapegoat Herbert Häber, who had been committed to a psychiatric hospital three years earlier? He fared somewhat better than Honecker and was discharged by a brave doctor with little interest in political intrigue. But in 2004 he is found guilty on three counts of incitement to murder.
column13: In 1989, the average age of the Politburo was 67. A popular joke in the GDR era described a typical Politburo meeting. Agenda item one: Carry in the members. Agenda item two: Turn on the pacemakers. Agenda item three: Sing the workers' anthem Towards the Dawn (We are the Young Guard).

column8: The coachman in the general's coat is murdered. He is one more victim of the Nazi's "euthanasia" programme.
column11:
The Nazi’s euthanasia programme
A gold-coloured eagle carries a swastika. The name Adolf Hitler is emblazoned below. This is the dictator's personal stationery. In the top right we can read the words Berlin, 1 September 1939. It is addressed to Hitler's personal physician Karl Brandt and Philipp Bouhler, Chief of the Chancellery of the Führer. In his letter, Hitler authorises the two men to carry out the "mercy killing" of anyone who is allegedly suffering from an incurable disease. The department charged with carrying out this programme of mass murder is set up at Tiergartenstrasse 4, under the codename T4.

Karl Ahrendt, a coachman, was one of the victims of the National Socialists' euthanasia programme. In 1907, when Germany was still under imperial rule, he was arrested on Alexanderplatz. Ahrendt was wearing a general's coat and trying to pass himself off as a prince. The doctors said he was confused and a danger to the public. He was admitted to a mental hospital where he lived inside his own head ¬- and spent his time sketching. Many of his surreal drawings have survived to this day. In 1941 the National Socialists sent Ahrendt to the gas chamber.  

Crime of the century 

Euthanasia, from the Greek for "good death" is not a new idea developed by the Nazis. Long before 1933, doctors and politicians in Europe had discussed the possibility of euthanasia for the terminally ill, people with physical and mental disabilities, and children with hereditary diseases. But for the Nazis, it becomes a guiding principle - they want to systematically terminate the lives of people who they deem "unworthy of life" according to their own particular criteria.  

The "desk murderers" in the Tiergarten villa 

Berlin, Tiergartenstraße 4. In front of you is a wall of blue glass. You are standing on what used to be the ground floor of one of the most magnificent villas in the Tiergarten. It was destroyed during the Second World War. An information centre and memorial to the victims of the National Socialist "euthanasia" murder programme opened here in 2014. Between 1940 and 1945, some 60 civil servants planned and organised the mass murder of people with mental disabilities. They were mainly people who were "just following orders": doctors, administrators, secretaries, tradesmen, photographers, drivers.  

The office staff in Tiergartenstraße send out registration forms to psychiatric institutions and nursing homes. The resident physicians dutifully fill out the forms. They note the patient's condition, the amount of care required, and the work involved. At the bottom of the document there is a black box that has to be left empty. Once the form is returned to Tiergartenstraße an assessor decides whether the patient should live or die. A minus in the black box means the patient can go on living. A plus is a death sentence. The office staff organise the final journeys of those who are condemned to death. They draw up transportation lists. Buses carry the patients to one of six killing centres, where they are gassed. No one here on Tiergartenstrasse ever sees any of the victims. 

Protests by church institutions lead to the Aktion T4 programme being officially discontinued in August 1941. But the killing continues in secret in sanatoriums and nursing homes. It is estimated that some 300,000 people across Europe are victims of the euthanasia programme.
column12:
Opening hours:
Freely accessible

For more information on this location, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/t4-memorial-and-information-centre-victims-nazi-euthanasia-programme
column13: It can't be driven, but it does move around - a concrete sculpture of a Mercedes-Benz O 3750 bus. The Memorial of the Grey Buses is modelled on the buses that transported patients to the killing centres. In 2008, the sculpture halted in front of the Philharmonie before continuing its journey around Germany.

column8: A small museum with a big message - Ernst Friedrich's Anti-War Museum causes controversy
column11:
Pacifism as provocation
The sign at the entrance to the museum is controversial: "Admission: People: 20 pfennigs - Soldiers: free" The state prosecutor believes soldiers are being treated as non-humans. Museum director Ernst Friedrich is fined 100 Reichsmarks for denigrating the German army and undermining state authority. This isn't the first time that the anarchist and radical pacifist has come into conflict with the law - and it won't be the last.

War against war!

For a generation of soldiers traumatised by the horrors of World War I, Ernst Friedrich's Anti-War Museum touches on many taboos. The myth of dying a glorious, heroic death for the fatherland is contrasted with the horrific reality of industrial mass murder. Soon after the museum opens in October 1925, the police arrive and remove pictures of deformed faces, mutilated bodies and shattered corpses from the display window.

The shocking pictures come from Friedrich's book Krieg dem Kriege! (War Against War!), which brings him international attention in 1924. He uses the proceeds from this bestseller to set up the "first international anti-war museum" in a dilapidated house in Parochialstraße. Photos of victims and perpetrators are placed next to drawings by Otto Dix and Käthe Kollwitz. Weapons, medals and war toys are displayed alongside ration cards and prostheses, all accompanied by sarcastic captions. German and French steel helmets have been turned into flower pots. Above the entrance hangs the symbol of conscientious objectors - two hands holding aloft a broken rifle.

"From peace museum to Hitler barracks" 

As a conscientious objector, Ernst Friedrich is initially sent to prison during the First World War, and then committed to an asylum. After his release in November 1918, he campaigns against the state and the military, against enforced obedience and violence. His passionate commitment to peace in his lectures and writings soon brings the "peace agitator" back into conflict with the authorities. A dozen court cases result in him spending three years in prison, but they also bring Friedrich into the public eye. It is rare to see a soldier in his museum, but he has more success with children and teenagers. For some, such as the futurologist Robert Jungk, a visit to the Anti-War Museum becomes a life-changing event. 

In the final years of the Weimar Republic, Friedrich increasingly finds himself fighting a losing battle. In 1930 he is sentenced to one year in prison. The windows of his museum are smashed, and he is injured in one of the attacks. The sign "Closed due to chronic pecuniary embarrassment!" appears more regularly in the window. In February 1933, the SA storm the museum, destroy the exhibits and set up a torture chamber in the cellar. Friedrich is taken into protective custody and eventually flees the country in December. Before long, the destruction of the reminders of the atrocities of one World War is followed by the murder and devastation of another.
column12: For more information on this location, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/anti-war-museum
column13: Ernst Friedrich flees to Brussels, where he reconstructs his museum in 1936. It is destroyed once again in 1940 when the German army invades Belgium. In 1982, 15 years after the death of its founder, a new anti-war museum opens on Brüsseler Straße in Berlin-Wedding. It's run by Friedrich's grandson, Tommy Spree.

column7: Club der polnischen Versager – Club of Polish Losers
column8: Could the club with the party vibe soon provide Germany with a new Chancellor?
column11:
Failure is the key to success
1 September 2001, 5.45 am. The Club of Polish Losers marks the anniversary of Germany's invasion of Poland by opening its doors at Torstraße 66. Outside, the crowd is held back by a red and white barrier. Then everyone reaches out and tears down the barrier. A symbolic gesture - the barrier is made of cardboard. On the other side? Not Poland but a Berlin club. The crowd cheers. It's a great moment in German/Polish history.

It's early evening, 17 years later. Now you're standing outside Ackerstraße 169. Ivy creeps up the building to the first floor. The door stands open. Come in, come in! Fresh air pours in, but you can still see and smell the traces of yesterday's party. You hear the clink of empties as Piotr Mordel gathers them up. The chairs are quickly set out and a reading begins here in the new premises of the Club of Polish Losers.  

The city's most active losers 

The four founders, including Mordel, arrived in West Berlin shortly before the Berlin Wall came down. They were all well qualified, but none of them could find a job. So they decided to handle this frustrating situation with creativity - and a touch of typically Polish irony. In 1994 they published their Little Manifesto of Polish Losers.  

"We're few and far between in this town. There's maybe twenty or thirty of us. The rest are cool, successful types, cold-blooded experts... We - the weak, the less talented, can't really achieve anything".

The club opens on 1 September 2001. Next door, writer Wladimir Kaminer is already spreading a little East European culture with his Kaffee Burger and Russian disco. It's an inspiring neighbourhood. Briefly known as the CPV, the club is a mixture of pub, cinema and cultural venue. The four founders set it up as a non-profit association. Even after it moves to Ackerstraße, it continues to present a diverse and alternative cultural programme. The club is like a skeleton key, says one of its founders, Adam Gusowski: "It opens doors for us and allows us to communicate with society." The magic password? The club is open when it's not closed. It's as simple as that.  

From political satire to political party  

The club's focus is on celebrating losers and failure in all its aspects. Political satire is a favourite weapon for countering German clichés about Poland.  

In 2018, the Club of Polish Losers sets up its own political party. The goal of the PPD, the Polish Party of Germany, is "...to explain, learn and demonstrate how processes work and what democracy does, using humour but with a serious intent". And perhaps to open another chapter in the history of successful failure - "we're not only interested in taking power, but above all we want to see a Polish Chancellor."
column13: The Club of Polish Losers is suing ARD, Germany's public-service broadcaster. It aired a TV film called Seit Du da bist, which featured a pub with the same name. It's a sleazy place where people go to drink vodka, eat gherkins and sing Russian songs. The CPV is determined to uphold its good reputation as a non-profit cultural institution.

column8: Blade running to a gold medal- welcome to the world of bionics!
column11:
Mobility for all
Marlou van Rhijn was born without lower legs in 1991. At the 2012 Paralympics in London, the Dutch sprinter set a new world record for the 100 and 200 metres - with the help of high-tech carbon-fibre prostheses made by the German company Ottobock. The prosthetics manufacturer is based at the Ottobock Science Center on Potsdamer Platz.

Freedom through movement 

White rooms, digital panels, computer simulations, artificial limbs - is this a glimpse of the future? Or is it the latest science fiction movie? In fact, it's a normal day at the Ottobock Science Center in Berlin. Ottobock has been developing cutting-edge medical technology for the last 100 years. Its prostheses, orthoses and wheelchairs give disabled people a whole new level of mobility. And when you visit the Science Center, the company beams you to new worlds. 

The central theme of the exhibition is understanding what moves us. How do humans balance? How does it feel to travel around Berlin in a wheelchair? What happens to our legs when we sprint? For professional athletes like Marlou van Rhijn, that's an important question. When the two-time world champion tries out her new running blades before the 2016 Paralympics in Rio she is blown away: "Wow, these are exactly what I've been looking for. I can't wait to line up at the start." 

As soon as you approach the Science Center building you can tell that the future is at home here. The building has a very futuristic look. The brilliant white panels of its façade are designed to look like human muscle fibres.
