SA and SS units hastily organise a pompous procession, gathering with a mass of torches at the vast Großer Stern roundabout near Tiergarten Park. The marching of the Nazi Brownshirts echoes eerily through the streets.

First house on the left

Around 8pm, the first marchers reach Pariser Platz square. German-Jewish artist Max Liebermann can view the scene directly from his apartment at Pariser Platz 7.

With characteristic bluntness, Liebermann does not mince his words: "I cannot eat as much as I want to vomit." For over 40 years, he and his family have been living in his parent's home at Pariser Platz. The house is the work of August Stüler, a well-known student of Berlin's renowned architect Karl Friedrich Schinkel - built at a time when the Brandenburg Gate still marked the city boundary. Once when asked for the address, Liebermann laconically replies: "First house on your left in Berlin".

Today, the prominent buildings around include the French Embassy and Hotel Adlon. In his day, German writer Thomas Mann calls Liebermann's house "a focal and gathering point for refreshing and influential personalities".   Liebermann builds a glass studio at the top of his house - and the German Emperor tries to ban it for infringing building law. But Liebermann fights for his rights.

For many years, Liebermann dominates the German art world. In 1920, he is even elected President of the Prussian Academy of Arts - the institution he rebelled against in his youth. As leader of the Berlin Secession artists' group, he belongs to the avantgarde. When the Nazis seize power in 1933, Jewish artists are banned from exhibiting. Liebermann resigns from his office as Academy President. Two years later, he dies in his house at Pariser Platz.

The building is destroyed in Allied bombing raids. Today's Max Liebermann Haus is a new post-Wall building, designed by Josef Paul Kleihues, and inspired by the historical original. Since 2000, this has housed the Stiftung Brandenburger Tor (Brandenburg Gate Foundation). In Liebermann's spirit, the Foundation supports artistic projects. Why not visit and see for yourself!

Summer residence on Wannsee lake

In 1909, Max Liebermann buys a vast plot of land along Berlin's Wannsee lake. Today, surrounded by attractive villas, this is one of the last open lakeside areas. Here, Liebermann builds his summer residence, finished in just a few months. He called it 'my palace on the lake'  - a place where he is exceptionally productive. In the months he spends here with his family every summer, he paints over 200 works. Rather like Monet, he draws his inspiration, above all, from his garden.

Today, reconstructed from Liebermann's paintings to create an artistic unity, the beautiful lakeside house, exhibition area, garden and café are open to the public.
column12:
Opening hours:
Monday 10am to 6pm
Wednesday to Sunday 11am to 6pm
Closed Tuesday
column13: The images flicker, wobbly and blurred. The faces unrecognisable, lost in what looks like a snow storm. This is not what Nazi Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels wanted. He orders the day the National Socialists seized power to be restaged - a re-creation of the night of 30 January. In summer 1933, for propaganda film SA-Mann Brand (Storm Trooper Brand), the Brownshirts again march over the cobbles at Brandenburg Gate. But Max Liebermann is spared this second torchlight procession. Forced into 'inner emigration', he spends his days at his 'palace on the lake'.

column8: Candlelit vigils, protests and a police siege - a church comes to symbolise peaceful resistance.
column11:
A growing belief in change – and a blessing for the regime’s opponents
After a crackdown on peaceful protests on 7 and 8 October 1989, the Candlelit Vigil action group at Berlin's Gethsemane Church distribute a leaflet calling for "Tens of thousands of candles for each protestor in police custody!!!".  And despite the GDR's "People's Police" brutally attacking and arresting hundreds of demonstrators over the last days, everyone agrees protests must stay peaceful.

A mass of candles cover the areas outside the Gethsemane Church, flames flickering in a light breeze. The low walls are already coated with melted wax - but the sea of candles continues to grow. Open around the clock, the church in these days is a beacon for all those seeking consolation, refuge and kindred spirits in the peaceful struggle against the East German regime.

If you look up, you'll see the entrance portal of this red brick neo-gothic hall church. Just here, in October 1989 there is a banner with the message "Be vigilant and pray" - a reminder of the vigil for those unjustly imprisoned.

A joint call for a demonstration is issued by a spectrum of dissenting groups, from the ecumenical Kirche von Unten to the Weißensee Friedenskreis peace activists and the Umwelt-Bibliothek movement. And with news spreading of the GDR regime arresting peaceful demonstrators in Leipzig, crowds of people come to the church. No one, though, could have guessed the Gethsemane Church is soon going to be the target of a violent police action.

Preaching freedom inside - taking it away outside

The 40th anniversary of the founding of the GDR falls on 7 October. Leaving the church that evening, you are met by a wall of units in uniform, kettling the demonstrators in front of the church. They chant "We are peaceful", but their words are ignored. Behind them, police vehicles are already moving into position. The police brutally attack the peaceful crowd, leaving many injured. Over 500 demonstrators are arrested and taken to Rummelsburg remand prison, already full to bursting. The GDR police don't even bother to distinguish between demonstrators and passers-by. Everyone who can escapes into the church, now both a hospital and a place of refuge.

In the church hall, a news information office is hastily set up. There, details and minutes from memory are collected from those injured or attacked. The pastor frees up the telephone line so it can be used as a contact number. From here, information is exchanged on the current political situation in other East German towns and cities. Leipzig, Plauen, Dresden, Magdeburg and Berlin are all peacefully campaigning, side by side, for the release of political prisoners. There are more clashes the next day. But the negotiations with the regime by church representatives and the demonstrators' leaders start to bear fruit. On the streets the gathering crowds chant "We are the people" and their peaceful protests can no longer be stopped. 

"A peaceful revolution was something our theory never envisaged," said Horst Sindermann, then President of the East German Volkskammer, later. "We simply didn't expect it - and it left us defenceless".

Over the following weeks, the Gethsemane Church remains a main meeting point for the grass-roots opposition. The church is also the setting where the opposition leaders present their political programme.
column12:
Opening hours:
Monday 11am - 1pm
Tuesday 4pm - 6pm
Wednesday 11am - 1pm
Friday 11am - 1pm

For more information on this location, events and tickets, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/gethsemanekirche
column13: The Benedictive Jesus in front of the church portal is more than a silent witness of this time of dramatic change. After the Berlin Wall was built, the wooden sculpture was in the Church of Reconciliation, directly in the death strip at Bernauer Straße. When the derelict church was demolished, the statue was given a new home in front of Gethsemane Church.

column8: Young people use street art to protest the gentrification of their neighbourhood - and need a lot of paint!
column11:
Creativity versus commerce
The mural on Manteuffelstraße in Berlin-Kreuzberg looks like a giant Monopoly board. But there's no Park Lane or Mayfair. There's no free parking either, but at least you don't have to go to jail. Kottbusser Tor, Lausitzer Straße and Oranienplatz are on the board, but they're not for sale. The mural is called Berlin not for sale. 

It all starts in the summer of 2014. In Berlin's Kreuzberg district, a group of young people are poring over a city map. They're not looking for the tastiest doner kebab, the coolest skatepark or the hippest bar. They're looking for places where people are being forced to leave their homes to make way for luxury redevelopment projects. What's the best way to stage a protest? Who does this city actually belong to?  

The side of a house becomes a giant Monopoly board  

It's the start of an extraordinary project. The Orangotango initiative organises a workshop for young people. A map has been produced to illustrate the ongoing process of displacement and gentrification in Kreuzberg. The young activists decide to turn it into a piece of art. The cooperative housing project at Manteuffelstraße 39 in Kreuzberg provides them with an empty firewall. Several graffiti collectives get involved in the neighbourhood project. As you can see, the result is pretty eye-catching!  

The young artists only have one weekend to create their street art. They project the image onto the wall and spray-paint each section, like painting by numbers. The weekend is one big party, with sausages sizzling on the barbecue and plenty of cold drinks. Fresh vegetables are provided by the community garden in the Tempelhofer Feld.  

Passers-by soon realise that that the image on the wall is a Monopoly board! But in this version of the game, no one is striving to build a real estate empire, and nobody is going bust. Quite the opposite, in fact. 

The battle for public spaces 

Each space on the board represents one of the hotspots in the argument about the future of the city. The banks of the river Spree represent the loss of access to water. In Reichenberger Straße, a lift transports cars straight into their owner's luxury apartments.  

But many of the images depict places where people are resisting being squeezed out of their neighbourhoods. There's the Köpi building in Köpenicker Straße, one of the city's last squats, though it has now been legalised. There's the communal garden on Bethaniendamm. And at the end of Görlitzer Park on the former death strip, there's the Wagenburg Lohmühle, a camp and caravan site for drop-outs and dissenters.  

Urban development has already overtaken some of the images. On the mural, the Cuvry urban wasteland still allows public access to the Spree. And an investor is building offices on the spot where "Reclaim your city" was once daubed on the giant firewall. So who does this city belong to? Is Berlin just a giant Monopoly board for investors who want everything to be sold off? Some of these questions are answered in the new (2017) version of the young people's city map.
column13: Saving the best for last. Spotlights light up the mural as darkness falls. The graffiti artists are painting an old lady on the edge of the picture. Armed with a spray can, she is spraying the symbol of the squatter movement: a circle crossed by an N-shaped lightning bolt. Resistance is not only for the young.

column8: A little piece of the Peaceful Revolution can be found at the heart of the once hermetically sealed Stasi headquarters
column11:
Peaceful Revolution in the lion’s den
The panels of the Revolution and the Fall of the Wall exhibition break like waves against the inner courtyard of the Stasi headquarters. The other side of the story is now being hold - here, at the heart of East Germany's powerful surveillance apparatus. The exhibition takes us from the first protests to the Revolution and on to the fall of the Berlin Wall.

The grey architecture of oppression. That's one way of describing the dreary office buildings you see before you. When you look at the former Stasi headquarters from the inner courtyard, it feels like it is towering over you. This is typical of a surveillance state where the individual is subordinated and has to conform. What happens behind the walls and countless faceless windows? Interrogations, violence, reprisals of all kinds. 

This exhibition is dedicated to the brave men and women who stood up to the regime between 1945 and 1989. 

The many faces of the Revolution  

Intellectuals, church leaders, young people, opposition members, dissidents - their faces all look out at at the Stasi headquarters. They taste triumph at last. Their photos and documents seem to say: Look at me. You thought you could silence our voices. But the only thing that is silent is the old, soulless lump of concrete that you once called your headquarters.  

1,300 square metres of peaceful protest  

The exhibition panels cover most of the courtyard at the Stasi HQ. The first part is dedicated to the beginnings of the Revolution. The first people's protests against the communist regime of the GDR and the rest of the Eastern Bloc began on 17 June 1953. 

The protest groups were a mixed bunch. There was the peace movement with its strong "swords to ploughshares" symbol, the environmental movement and its subculture, and the regime's active opposition. A community of peaceful freedom fighters began to take shape. 

The second part of the exhibition focuses on the Revolution and sheds light on what happened in the last months, weeks and days before the fall of the Berlin Wall - from the Monday demonstrations in Leipzig to the mobilisation of hundreds of thousands of people on Alexanderplatz. 

The long-awaited turning point, the fall of the Berlin Wall, is the link to the third part of the exhibition, which deals with unity and its consequences. The first free elections, sceptical voices, the new freedom - the exhibition takes us on an authentic journey through history with numerous large-format photos, prints of leaflets and newspaper ads and other recordings.
column12:
Opening hours: 
Accessible 24 hours a day
The information desk in the former officers' mess (Haus 22) is open daily from 10am - 6pm
column13: Haus 1 is still home to the office of Erich Mielke, East Germany's former Minister of State Security. Back then, he could never have imagined that his office window would look out over an exhibition about the Revolution.

column8: Alexanderplatz is a must to experience a vision of urban life in the roaring twenties
column11:
Open heart surgery
In 1929, German writer Alfred Döblin vividly describes construction work on the square in his bestseller Berlin Alexanderplatz: "Boom, boom, the steam pile-driver thumps in front of Aschinger's on the Alex. It's one story high, and knocks the rails into the ground as if they were nothing at all." Döblin's main protagonist Franz Biberkopf, just released from prison, finds it hard to cope with the freedom of a modern metropolis where everything around him is in flux. Here, fiction is a true reflection of reality - Alexanderplatz has always been a place of vibrant change.

In the 1920s, the main impetus for this change comes from Martin Wagner, Berlin's chief city planner. He knows, "A city square for a metropolis of world rank is no small-town project." This central square in the poor east of the city is threatening to dissolve into permanent gridlock. Wagner envisages Alexanderplatz as a circulatory system for modern traffic flows. Work begins in 1927 - underground. Here, at depths of up to 12 metres, a new interchange station is constructed for two new tube lines - today's Line 8 from Gesundbrunnen to Neukölln and Line 5 to Friedrichsfelde. With the tube lines laid from the street, this operation is rather like open heart surgery. For five years, Alexanderplatz is transformed into a massive construction site, leaving pedestrians to weave their way across the square on a series of wooden planks.

Alexanderplatz goes American

Chief city planner Martin Wagner wants a vast circular traffic system around Alexanderplatz, regulating the flow of cars and trams. He announces an architectural competition for the new buildings to line the redesigned square, encouraging some of the great names in modernist architecture to take part. But the financing is still not secured. Only when a US consortium of investors shows interest can his plan move forward. Star architect Peter Behrens, designer of many major buildings for industrial giant AEG, is awarded second place in the competition - and ultimately the contact as well.

Behrens first plans a series of skyscrapers of 20 to 30 floors high. In the end, though, he reduces his grand plan to two eight-storey office blocks. Built between 1929 and 1932, those blocks are named Alexander House and Berolina House. They still here today, on either side of the renowned Weltzeituhr - the World Time Clock. Behrens' rigorously symmetrical facades are inspired by the New Objectivity movement. Instead of ornamental elements, he adds two rows of projecting windows on the sides. And visitors to the cafés on the top floors could also enjoy roof terraces, the ideal setting for a concert of swing music. As the local Berliner Tageblatt newspaper noted: "Both these office and apartment blocks have been built by an American company with American money, and since money is no object, they have also been completed at an American pace." 

Bread rolls for free

The two blocks designed by Peter Behrens replace two places much loved by the locals. Alexander House is constructed on the site of the old Königstädtische Theater, which housed a branch of the popular Aschinger restaurant and beer-hall chain. All the beers cost the same price - just ten pfennigs. The food is also similarly affordable - and all meals come with unlimited bread rolls for free.

Berolina House is named after a statue of the Berolina, the female personification of Berlin, which formerly stood on the site. The majestic bronze female figure is again put up on Alexanderplatz in 1933. But just eleven years later, in 1944, it is melted down to fuel the war machinery. With the Nazi seizure of power in 1933, Alexanderplatz's urban modernist development is abruptly halted. Yet even today, the two office and apartment blocks by Peter Behrens and the Alexanderplatz tube station recall the hopes and dreams of the 1920s.
column13: The World Time Clock stands on the site where the Berolina statue was relocated in 1933 - and continues a tradition as a meeting point for locals and visitors.

column8: In 1995, artist couple Christo and Jeanne-Claude wrap the Reichstag building - a magical summer event lasting two weeks
column11:
A temporary art work
24 June 1995. Christo und Jeanne-Claude have been fighting for nearly 25 years for their project. No wonder they are proud as they watch specially trained rock climbers fix the last roll of material. At long last, the Wrapped Reichstag is a reality - enclosed entirely in 100,000 square meters of glittering silver fabric.

In 1971, Christo and Jeanne-Claude receive a postcard of Berlin's Reichstag building. It is sent by American journalist Michael S. Cullen, who lives in the city. He writes that he hopes Christo will wrap the Reichstag. At this time, Christo and Jeanne-Claude already have an international reputation. They are fascinated by the idea of wrapping the Reichstag. After all, in the divided city of Berlin, the Reichstag stands directly at the border separating two opposing political systems and is visible from East and West.  

A long road to travel  

Christo and Jeanne-Claude talk to politicians and the authorities in Berlin, refusing to be put off. In the meantime, the artist couple wrap such structures as the Pont Neuf bridge in Paris or surround eleven islands between Miami and Miami beach with pink polypropylene fabric. But they still keep fighting for permission to wrap Berlin's Reichstag. 

With German reunification in 1990, the project gains a new momentum. Germany is gripped by a feeling of a new dawn. The German parliament debates Christo and Jeanne-Claude's proposed art project. For the first time in German history, the elected representatives vote on an art performance. It looks like a close result. Chancellor Helmut Kohl and Interior Minister Wolfgang Schäuble voice their objections. Doesn't the project put the dignity of the Reichstag at risk? But finally a majority of German MPs take a different view. The vote goes in favour of the project - the Reichstag is to be wrapped! 

A public festival at the Reichstag 

Work starts on 16 June 1995. Even the process of wrapping the Reichstag is an event. Christo's design does not use scaffolding. A local crowd watches enthralled as 90 rock climbers let down the long rolls of fabric from the roof, fastening them with ropes. It takes seven days to finish this temporary art work. Growing numbers of visitors and locals come to marvel at the Wrapped Reichstag, soon a favourite subject for photographers.  

Where you are now standing, there was a truly magical mood. During those summer days, the square quickly turns into a spontaneous festival, with people on the lawn, barbecuing, making music and playing football. For two weeks, the Wrapped Reichstag seems to emanate peace and joy across the city - a festival of art making headlines around the world. This special summer event, attracting over five million people, only has one day of bad weather. Even those, like Wolfgang Schäuble, initially sceptical about the project are converted. When the performance is over, the rolls of fire-resistant aluminised polypropylene are taken down and recycled.  

The Reichstag looks just as always - and yet something is different. Almost as though the glittering material has freed the building from its past. Shortly afterwards, British architect Norman Foster starts work on refurbishing the Reichstag as the future seat of the German Bundestag. A new chapter begins.
column12:
Opening hours:
Monday to Sunday 8pm to 12am, last admittance: 9.45pm

Admission to the Reichstag building, the Reichstag dome and the guided tours are all free of charge. However, visits must be booked in advance by registering online at the https://visite.bundestag.de/BAPWeb/pages/createBookingRequest.jsf">Bundestag's visitors' page, by fax or by post, stating your name and date of birth. Spontaneous visitors can register in person at the Visitors' Service Office. Free places are allocated a minimum of two hours before the time of your visit, or you can book a place on one of the following two days.

For more information on this location, events and tickets, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/reichstag-in-berlin
column13: Season 10, episode 19. The animated sitcom The Simpsons is not only a massive success in America, but also enjoys cult status in Germany. When Homer looks for ideas for his new career as an artist, his daughter Lisa mentions Christo and the Wrapped Reichstag - and an art performance in Berlin has a cameo role in an episode of the Simpsons!

column7: The GDR’s central remand prison in Hohenschönhausen
column8: No scream could ever be heard outside. The Stasi's top-secret prison was in the heart of Berlin - yet hardly anyone knew about it
column11:
The Stasi’s central institution of terror
Soviet forces and the GDR both incarcerate political opponents in Berlin-Hohenschönhausen. Far from any legal controls, a top-secret prison is set up where inhumane treatment is the order of the day.

No one in the GDR is really free. Yet nowhere are East Germany's citizens further from freedom than in the subterranean bunker-like cells in the Stasi's secret remand prison in Hohenschönhausen.  

The prisoners there dub this damp and cold tract of cells the U-Boot - the "Submarine". In the windowless cells, with a light bulb burning 24-hours a day, the prisoners feel as if they are deep under the sea - submerged, lost, beyond help.

When the Ministry of State Security (Stasi) lock Peter Rüegg up here in a U-Boot cell in August 1959, and maltreat him over a period of months, he thinks "Here, they can do what they like with you.No scream or cry ever escapes these walls." 

The suffering here begins under the Nazis  

The history of human suffering in Hohenschönhausen goes back to the war years. Even during the Second World War, the Nazi regime packs prisoners into barrack huts on the site of a Nazi welfare organisation canteen.  

When the war ends, the Soviet forces in Berlin turn the former large canteen into their Special Camp No. 3 for political prisoners. Conditions are catastrophic. By 1946, hundreds have died. Afterwards, the Soviet secret police use the site for five years as a remand prison. The feared U-Boot tract of cells also dates from these years. 

If you visit the memorial today, just imagine you would never escape these torture cells. Not only were the prisoners flogged and beaten, but also deprived of sleep or had ice-cold water poured over them. What seems inconceivable today was then the cruellest reality inside these walls.  

Psychological terror replaces physical maltreatment  

In 1951, the Stasi finally takes over the building, turning it into East Germany's top-secret remand prison. Until 1989, over 10,000 men and women are held here. In the late 1950s, the Stasi close the notorious cellar cells. But this does not mean the end of torturing prisoners - just that the methods become subtler.  

Prisoners not only spend long stretches in solitary confinement, but Stasi staff sometimes hold invented phone calls in a prisoner's presence, pretending something dreadful has happened to one of the prisoner's close relatives. For the prisoners, the uncertainty is usually worse than any physical maltreatment.  

Moreover, none of the prisoners in Hohenschönhausen knows where they are. For many of the prisoners, the most worrying question was: Have I been taken out of Germany?  

Only after the Wall comes down does the East German Council of Ministers close all the Stasi remand prisons. On 2 October 1990, just one day before German reunification, the Hohenschönhausen remand prison is finally shut down and placed under West Berlin's legal administration. Yet even today, Siegfried Rataizick, head of the secret prison from 1963 until it closed, denies all accusations. In an interview in 2002, he says: "I wouldn't miss a single day for the world. I'd do it all again anytime."
column12:
The former remand prison can only be viewed on a guided tour. Pre-registration is not required; tours last 90 minutes 

For more information on this location, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/event/prisoner-stasi-investigation-center-berlin-hohenschonhausen
column13: Anyone visiting today's Berlin-Hohenschönhausen Memorial can view the office of the head of the prison. The office, restored in perfect detail, has a unique feature - a door disguised as a wall unit leads into the bedroom of the head of the prison. There, he had a row of monitors, not only allowing him to check on the prisoners, but his staff as well.

column7: The Central Round Table of the GDR
column8: Enemies around the table: the GDR grassroots opposition negotiates with state representatives as equals
column11:
Discussions to strengthen freedom
The objectives of the opposition movements are clear: dissolving the Stasi, free elections and a democratic constitution for East Germany. They finally succeed in sitting around a table with the Communist state organisations - but are overtaken by the speed of events.

On 7 December 1989, a dense crowd of journalists and camera teams gathers on the pavement just where you are standing now. Thirty-three men and women push their way through the media crowds, heading for the Dietrich Bonhoeffer House, at that time the community centre of the Protestant Moravian Church. Once in the building, they take their seats in the assembly hall for the first session of the Central Round Table of the GDR. In fact, though, the tables are arranged in a square.  

After a series of demonstrations and protest actions, the popular citizens' movements finally succeed in meeting GDR state representatives for negotiations as equals. The two sides have an equal number of delegates - 15 from the opposition movements, and 15 from the GDR's still ruling Socialist Unity Party along with its block parties. Three church representatives are present to moderate the meeting and keep it on track. Under the large decorative star for the Advent season, the representatives of the people put their demands on the table.  

The end of the Stasi 

The grassroots representatives know exactly what they want to achieve: "The participants in the Round Table are meeting out of their profound concern for our crisis-ridden country, for its independence, and its long-term development." Their declared goal is to prepare for free and democratic elections - and ensure the dissolution of the Ministry for State Security with immediate effect. But that's a demand which the leaders of the Socialist Unity Party (SED) and the Politburo find hard to swallow.  

Through emissaries Gregor Gysi and Wolfgang Berghofer, the new Communist premier Hans Modrow proposes that the Round Table should tackle the task of founding a new agency for internal security - to protect against fascist tendencies. But the opposition members soon expose the suggestion for what it is - just keeping the old Stasi in a new guise. Representatives of the New Forum, one of East Germany's most influential grassroots movements, discuss the topic with a directness that unsettles the church officials presiding over the meeting. At this time, though, they are not yet aware of the extent of Stasi surveillance. This conflict come to a head in further demonstrations, and Modrow can only defuse the situation by promising to abandon his plan of setting up a new intelligence agency.  

Fast forward to free elections  

The representatives of the GDR opposition groups at the Central Round Table meetings are unable to achieve their top priority. Inspired by the desire to pave the way for their country into democracy and freedom, they envision drafting a new constitution. Although work begins on the draft, it remains incomplete. With the first free elections to the Volkskammer (People's Chamber) brought forward to 18 March 1990, the Round Table, which is not an elected body, becomes superfluous. What happens to the country afterwards is then in the hands of the first and only freely elected government of the GDR, the German Democratic Republic.
column12: For more information on this location, please go https://www.visitberlin.de/en/schonhausen-palace">to visit
column13: Today, the building where the Central Round Table met is a hotel. The historic furniture for the first session - several rectangular tables pushed together into a square - are thought to have been thrown away when the building was renovated.

column8: Strict rules bring freedom - and it's celebrated at Berghain, the best club in the world
column11:
The freedom to party
Sunday, two in the morning. You and a hundred other people are queuing outside a building near Ostbahnhof station. It looks like a fortress. Coloured lights are flickering from the high windows. People go quiet as they shuffle closer to the door. A muffled bass beat echoes out of the building. Now you're at the door. This time, will you get into Berghain, one of the most famous clubs in the world?

If you want to get in, look like you don't care. Don't talk loudly, and definitely don't laugh. A tattooed man covered in piercings, appears in front of you. The bouncer. He looks you over. "You're not getting in." When you hear that sentence, you'd better not start arguing.  

Pretty much anything goes 

Perhaps you're one of the lucky ones who has made it into Berghain today. When you step inside the temple of techno, be careful what you do with your phone. You're not supposed to be in touch with the outside world, and photography is strictly forbidden. At Berghain, discretion is the key.   That's precisely why Berghain is known as a place of freedom. It's not a place for show-offs. Nobody gets preferential treatment because they're a celebrity. If you get in, you've joined the clubbing community. It's tolerant. Pretty much anything goes. When you step inside Berghain you're entering a world of intoxication, abandon and ecstasy. 

The best club in the world 

In 2004 the club moved into a former power plant in Friedrichshain. The owners commissioned a firm of designers to strip out and redesign the massive building, which once supplied Stalinallee with power. It gets its name from Kreuzberg and Friedrichshain, the two districts that flank the building - Berg-Hain. In 2009, the British DJ Magazine voted Berghain the best club in the world. International DJs are falling over themselves to get booked. Every weekend, thousands of clubbers hope the bouncers will grace them with their favour.  

Once you've gone through bag check and body check, go up the huge steel staircase. The bass blasts from the speakers in the vast room. There's a corridor to one side. The darker it gets, the more it stinks. Urine or semen? You're approaching the darkroom. Go back. There are more hidden corners and dark corridors. You go up a few steps and are in the Panorama Bar. People are swaying trance-like to the beat, a faint smile on their lips. At sunrise, the huge blinds are opened slightly for a few seconds. Rays of sunlight penetrate the interior. The crowd goes crazy. 

It's 9.30 in the morning. Outside, people are still joining the queue. You can come back later - the club stays open till Monday morning. Clubbing in Berlin has no limits!
column13: The rule is: what happens in Berghain stays in Berghain. But American actress Claire Danes doesn't care. She's so impressed by her visit that she tells a shocked talk show host about her experiences. A Sunday afternoon spent with naked men, dancing and eating ice cream. For Claire Danes, Berghain is "the best place in the world".

column8: Blooming and buzzing - Berlin's urban garden is a haven for city bees
column11:
Where freedom and kohlrabi grow side by side
Every shade of green with splashes of tomato reds and yellows - these are the colours of what must surely be Berlin's most beautiful urban jungle. But it's only a little bit wild. The raised beds that are open to everybody are organised in neat rows. And the tiniest of the urban gardeners are buzzing around busily - the garden's bees.

The fact that the bees have found a home here near Moritzplatz is mainly because of the 30,000 people who signed a petition to preserve the Prinzessinnengärten - the Princess Gardens. The city had very different plans in 2009. The state-owned property company that administered this particular piece of land had no interest in seeing it turned into a permanent green space, but it agreed to let the non-profit organisation Nomadisch Grün (Nomadic Green) rent it on a monthly basis. It was due to be sold to an investor in 2012. But the city authorities are taken aback when the people of Kreuzberg decide they are going to fight to keep their communal garden.   

Princesses against privatisation 

They organise protests against the plans, and the lease is extended. But they are still waiting for a final decision by the Senate. In the meantime, local residents set about bringing nature back to the city. They plant organic vegetables and fruit, perennials and trees on the 6,000-square-metre plot.  

Beekeeper Heinz Risse thinks it could be a paradise for bees so he volunteers to look after the bee colonies. He sees his work as a counterweight to industrial beekeeping and agriculture. The result is not only honey but a new awareness about the importance of bees. "I had to settle into my job of passing on and sharing knowledge in this amazing garden that's unlike anywhere else in the world. I think my biggest challenge is encouraging today's children to ask the right questions. They'll find the answers in their own good time," he says. This doesn't only apply to the countless children who come here on school trips, but also to the adults who help with the gardening and harvesting or simply come to enjoy the lovely surroundings.  

And the up to 500,000 bees? They're just happy to get on with producing delicious urban honey flavoured by the vast array of blossoms that grow in the Prinzessinnengärten.

Opening hours:
All day from April - October Monday - Sunday 10am - 10pm
In season, come along and help:
Thursday 3pm - 6pm, Saturday 11am - 2pm

Free Admission

For more information on this location, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/prinzessinnengarten
column13: Recycling is also part of the ethos of the Prinzessinnengärten. Plants and herbs are grown in old milk cartons and greenhouses are built on Euro pallets. Drinks crates are turned into tables and chairs, while the portaloos are kitted out with toilets and washbasins rescued from the old piano factory across the road.

Homage to Otto Weidt – In the famous backyard at Haus  :Otto Weidt (2 May 1883 - 22 December 1947) was the owner of a workshop in Berlin for blind and deaf. During the Holocaust, he fought to protect his Jewish workers against deportation and he has been recognised for his work as one of the Righteous Men of the World's Nations. The Museum of Otto Weidt's Workshop for the Blind remains on the original site of the factory and is dedicated to his life.

"2268 miles and Luchadora Pachamama" – This piece is part I for a duplex mural. The Poland borne Tankpetrol finished the first part on 8th July 2019, QueenkongSwitzerland will follow at the coming weekend. About 45 meter, the mural is one of the highest in Berlin.

Parliament of Trees – The Parliament of Trees (also known as The Parliament of Trees against war and violence) is a memorial for the death victims of the Berlin Wall, which was installed on 9 November 1990 by performance artist Ben Wagin. This S-Bahn station platform at Savignyplatz is part of this   installation.

East Side Gallery  – The East Side Gallery is an international memorial for freedom. It is a 1316 m long section of the Berlin Wall located near the centre of Berlinon Mühlenstraße in Friedrichshain-Kreuzberg. The actual border at this point was the river Spree. The gallery is located on the so-called "hinterland mauer", which closed the border to West Berlin.

The Reichstag dome is a symbol of an open, modern Germany. But in fact its architect had other plans.
column11:
Berlin’s beautiful showcase of democracy
The Reichstag dome is not just a stunning piece of architecture. It also symbolises a new era of transparency in German politics. But it was almost never built.

You are about to enter the Reichstag dome, which has become one of Berlin's most famous landmarks. But architect Sir Norman Foster had some very different ideas for it back in the early '90s. He wanted to hang a kind of flat canopy over the whole Reichstag building, but critics said it looked like a giant petrol station. 

Today, when you climb the 40.7 metres to the viewing platform in the Reichstag dome, you are rewarded with incredible views over Berlin. This is all thanks to two political parties - the CDU and CSU - and to Helmut Kohl himself. After reunification, the CDU/CSU Union failed to gain support for its plans to rebuild the historic Reichstag dome, so in the end they agreed to compromise and build a modern dome in glass and steel. 

Foster gives in to the politicians - and creates a masterpiece   

It turns out to be an excellent decision. Because it forces the architect to create an icon, a masterpiece that is famous around the world. For the very first time, a parliament building has been topped with a see-through dome and it open to the public. 

As you climb the two large steel ramps that spiral up to the top of the dome, you can sense the excitement that was triggered by Foster's second design. You are treated to an unparalleled, ever-changing vista. With every step, you get a different view of central Berlin - the Tiergarten, the government district, Potsdamer Platz. 

But Foster's 23-metre-high dome isn't only a feast for the eyes. It is also brimming with high-tech features. At the centre of the dome is a giant cone consisting of 360 mirrors, which catch the daylight and direct it down into the debating chamber. 

Radical symbolism and transparency at the centre of political power  

A computer-controlled sun shield tracks the movement of the sun and blocks the light from individual mirrors to prevent excessive glare. The cone also acts as a vent, drawing stale air out of the debating chamber to an opening at the top of the dome. 

Between 1995 and 1999, Foster and his team installed 800 tons of steel and 3,000 square metres of glass in Germany's state-of-the-art domed structure. And yet the true fascination of the design lies in its radical symbolism. Of all people, it is the Germans, whose Nazi dictatorship led to the greatest political catastrophe of the 20th century, who can now quite literally look down on their parliamentarians. They have created a new kind of transparency at their centre of political power.  

The need to renovate the Reichstag to make it suitable for its current use led to the creation of a beacon of democracy that sends out a message to the world. Today the Reichstag dome is Berlin's most-visited landmark. Attracting some two million visitors a year, it is the supreme symbol of German reunification.
column12:
Opening hours:
Monday to Sunday 8pm to 12am, last admittance: 9.45pm

Admission to the Reichstag building, the Reichstag dome and the guided tours are all free of charge. However, visits must be booked in advance by registering online at the https://visite.bundestag.de/BAPWeb/pages/createBookingRequest.jsf">Bundestag's visitors' page, by fax or by post, stating your name and date of birth. Spontaneous visitors can register in person at the Visitors' Service Office. Free places are allocated a minimum of two hours before the time of your visit, or you can book a place on one of the following two days.

For more information on this location, events and tickets, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/reichstag-in-berlin
column13: In the late Eighties, at Helmut Kohl's request, Cologne-based architect Gottfried Böhm designed a new dome for the Reichstag. But the idea was put on the back burner because no-one really believed the people of Berlin would support the plan.

column8: Successful escapes and tragic fates - this museum tells the stories of the victims of the Wall
column11:
Dreaming of freedom
The cement in the newly erected Berlin Wall has barely dried. Resistance fighter Rainer Hildebrandt decides he can't stand idly by and watch what the Socialist Unity Party of Germany is up to. People in the West need to know what is happening along this border.

Like many prisoners of the Gestapo (Geheime Staatspolizei), Rainer Hildebrandt has a dream: "A dream that the cell door opens, the light goes on and a voice says: You're free to go." The historian and human rights activist has never lost his desire for freedom. 

Keeping an eye on the Wall  

On 19 October 1962 Hildebrandt decides to open an exhibition about the Berlin Wall in his small apartment on Wolliner Strasse. The city's brutal dividing line runs directly in front of these residential buildings. He opens his doors to tourists and anyone who's interested in what is happening on the border. His exhibition proves to be so popular that he relocates it to the Haus am Checkpoint Charlie on 14 June 1963. From being purely a museum, it quickly becomes a focal point for demonstrators, journalists, refugees and escape helpers, who have a perfect view of the checkpoint from its small window. 

But it doesn't escape the authorities that the premises are also being used to plan escapes. Rainer Hildebrandt is subjected to several kidnap attempts, but he allows nothing to distract him from his peaceful fight against injustice. His museum grows with the stories of each new escapee.  

Escaping over, under and through the Wall  

When you see some of the exhibits it's hard to believe your eyes. People escaped by hiding in a car's petrol tank, building a home-made submarine and - in the "escape of the century" - two families flew over the wall in a hot air balloon in 1979. The museum also reveals the horror of the border's deadly self-firing weapons, the ruthless border guards, the tragic stories of those who died and suffered at the hands of the regime.

The fall of the Wall is a dream come true for Hildebrandt. He has always longed for "freedom in unity", and now it has arrived. And the Haus am Checkpoint Charlie itself becomes a witness to history.  Today the exhibition also covers broader themes, such as non-violent revolutions around the world. 

BlackBox Cold War   

Just a few metres from the Checkpoint Charlie house stands a black cube. This spot, where the American and Soviet tanks met on 22 October 1961, is now the site of a fascinating multimedia exhibition about the Cold War.
column12:
Opening hours: 
Das Haus am Checkpoint Charlie
Daily, 9am - 10pm
BlackBox Cold War
Daily, 10am - 6pm

For more information on this location, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/mauermuseum-museum-haus-am-checkpoint-charlie-wall-museum
column13: Rainer Hildebrandt even uses placards to make contact with East German border guards. They read: "Look inside your uniform! And if you find a human being in there, give us a wave.". Well-disposed border guards respond by marking their Kalashnikovs with a cross or giving secret hand signals.

column8: Vergiss die Wirtschaftskrise! Vergiss die Nationalsozialisten! Und feiere durch die Nacht!
column11:
Jazz and a touch of the exotic in Berlin’s West
It's 3am at 10 Joachimsthaler Straße - closing time. Through the door marked with a bright neon sign spelling out KAKADU TANZ, a noisy crowd spills onto the street and heads off into the Berlin night.

Some hail taxis, while others take a turn on Berlin's most prestigious boulevard, the Kurfürstendamm, before heading home. Money talks, and the bars, cafés and cabarets all vie for the attention of the passers-by, whether it's Berlin's bohemian set, visitors from abroad, or German tourists. 

Champagne, champagne - the crazy years 

On the corner of Joachimsthaler Straße and Augsburger Straße, the Kakadu bar is managed by brothers Georg and Dagobert Tichauer. It's a hip place to be, with a daily programme that includes acrobatic dancers, comedy, cabaret, live bands, a vegetarian restaurant on the mezzanine floor and Berlin's longest bar, which stretches 15 metres along the back wall. The bar promises its guests a touch of exoticism. The South Seas-style furniture evokes memories of long-lost colonies. The walls are covered with golden red fabric and the rooms are flooded with rich red light. Meanwhile, the bar provides a striking contrast in shades of blue and gold. 

Hostesses glide around, ensuring their guests are having a good time. They are dressed like "flappers", confident young women in loose, sleeveless dresses, who smoke and drink and behave like brash young men. Outside, the economy is in tatters. Inside there is dancing and drinking, flirting and partying. All accompanied by a wild kind of music that is rapidly gaining popularity in the Twenties, but also attracting criticism - jazz. 

The rhythm of the city 

While the Kakadu has a regular house band led by Max Herrnsdorf, it also occasionally puts on a "Tschetzbend", or jazz band. Then the dance floor is jumping as guests dance the Charleston and Shimmy. Everybody can have a go because there don't seem to be any fixed dance steps. The guardians of public morals view all this wiggling and shaking with suspicion; they seem to be breaking sexual taboos. But, as Franz Wolfgang Koebner notes as early as 1921, the waltz is "as good as dead". In contrast, the jazz bands are alive and kicking - playing music that is fast, eccentric, and loud. The new, modern city dweller rushes everywhere - and jazz rushes with them. 

The bands are brash and noisy, but the Kakadu also puts on more refined jazz ensembles for those with more sophisticated musical tastes. There's a constant coming-and-going at the Kakadu, which is disturbing for local residents. But it's all over at three in the morning. The band plays its last number as the audience call for more. The next day, it all starts again. Until 1936, when it really is all over - forever.
column13: In der Kakadu-Bar sitzen tatsächlich Papageien auf der Stange. Es gibt Berichte darüber, dass diese, wenn ein Gast mit dem Messer an das Glas schlägt, darauf trainiert sind, nach der „Rrräächnung!" zu verlangen. Mitunter landet wohl auch deren Notdurft auf den Tellern von unachtsamen Gästen.

column8: From pomp on Pariser Platz to desolation in the death zone
column11:
A grand hotel in the shadow of the Berlin Wall
The Hotel Adlon was always the best hotel in the square. More precisely, the best hotel on Pariser Platz, with its view of the Brandenburg Gate. But after the glories of the imperial age and the glamour of the Roaring Twenties, it ends up in ruins.

Baldur hates the colour blue. He has all the blue pens, armchairs and inkpots removed from his room at the Adlon. So what if it's the famous Adlon blue? Of course, the grand hotel bows to the wishes of the Reich's influential youth leader, Baldur von Schirach. 

Because the customer is king at the Adlon - and in the early days they were even emperors. When it opened in 1907, the hotel's first regular guest was none other than Wilhelm II, who preferred the luxurious Adlon to his own residence. Hardly surprising, as Lorenz Adlon had decided to create a luxury hotel for Berlin's high society.  

From magnificence to ruin 

In the Roaring Twenties, the Adlon is known around the world as a meeting place for the rich and famous, but its guest numbers plummet during the Second World War. The hotel's cosmopolitan flavour is not to the National Socialists' taste - they prefer a simple stew to a sophisticated ragout. As the bombs fall on Berlin, the Adlon is miraculously spared.  

So it seems like a bad joke when the hotel is burned to the ground by two Red Army soldiers who break into the wine cellar on 2 May 1945. One of them drops a burning cigarette into the wood shavings - and starts a devastating fire. All that's left of the magnificent building is a rear service wing. 

After the Wall is built in 1961, the German Democratic Republic renovates the hotel and runs it until the early 1980s - but the west-facing windows are walled up. In 1964 the hotel hosts the wedding of stage designer Horst Eilers and dancer Erna Lange. But the happy couple's special day is marred by the police presence at the reception. And the regime only allows them to invite ten guests to this very special location - right next to the death zone.  

Apprentices are occasionally housed in the Adlon building until it is demolished in 1984 on the orders of the SED's Politburo - the Adlon has had its day. 

After the fall of the GDR, the Altstadtbau property developers erect a new building on the site of the former hotel complex, which you can now admire in all its glory. It was opened by German President Roman Herzog on 23 August 1997 as the new Hotel Adlon Kempinski.
column13: The new hotel still tries to accommodate the whims of its guests. For one guest, it had to rip the bathtub from the wall of his luxury suite, then install it again after his departure. No problem, so long as the customer is paying.

column8: A famous street artist turns a blank wall into a gallery, then erases it himself
column11:
Painted black – iconic graffiti vanishes from sight
It's the night of 12 December 2014. A piece of wasteland in Kreuzberg. Several people are standing on a hydraulic platform covering a huge firewall with black paint. Passers-by stop to watch what's going on. Some have tears in their eyes. Others are simply stunned. Boos and whistles are directed towards the painters who are covering over one of Berlin's most iconic pieces of graffiti. They are erasing one of the icons of the city's street art scene. Who is behind this destruction? Amazingly, it's the artist himself!

He calls himself Blu, hails from Italy and is a famous street artist. In 2007 he selects a huge firewall on Cuvrystraße in Kreuzberg as the site for his latest artwork. He plans to paint a huge mural directly on the wall of the building. He spends several days and nights painting two huge white figures.  

Reclaim your city 

One figure stands upright, the other is upside down. They're pulling at each other's masks in an attempt to see the face underneath. The fingers of their free hands form the letters W and E - West and East.   

In the top right corner are the words "Reclaim Your City". The mural is just a few metres from the remains of the Berlin Wall. One year later, Blu paints a headless figure on the adjacent firewall. The faceless businessman wears a gold watch on each wrist, linked together by a chunky gold chain. He's adjusting his tie with his manacled hands. 

These paintings are icons of Berlin's street art scene. The sightseeing buses slow down as they drive past because tourists love the murals. Tour guides bring their groups here to admire these city landmarks.  

Another open space disappears 

When you walk north along Cuvrystraße, you quickly reach the River Spree. The first beach bars opened here in the 1990s. The land on Cuvrystraße changes hands several times - it's ripe for development. But local residents want to keep it for themselves. They set up a protest camp to oppose plans to build the BMW Guggenheim Lab. It's like a favela in the middle of Kreuzberg. People are sleeping in tents and homemade wooden shacks. Eviction notices become part and parcel of daily life. They are fighting to keep one of the last open spaces in Kreuzberg. The police eventually clear the site in September 2014. Then the bulldozers move in and start preparing the land for building the office complex.  

Blu doesn't want his artwork to exist in these surroundings. He doesn't want it to be part of a development that forces people out of their homes to make way for luxury housing that they can't afford. The artist also sees the destruction of his murals as a wake-up call. His art as a symbol of resistance has had its day. "Reclaim Your City" is now just "Your City". The rest has been painted black.
column12: Empty plots are developed, and the old firewalls are swallowed up
column13: Just one detail is briefly preserved - the extended middle finger of one of the figures' hands. It stands out starkly against the black background. It is a message from Blu "to the city, the developers and, above all, to the people who love this piece of art." Before long, this last vestige of rebellion has also disappeared.

column8: A dreary building becomes a canvas for creativity
column11:
Street art unleashes creativity
Berlin, 1984. The scaffolding on the corner of Schlesische Straße 7 is being dismantled. Suddenly everyone can see the words: Bonjour tristesse. They are written on the new building designed by architect Siza Vieira. Hello, sadness! No-one knows how the graffiti got there or who painted it. But many people agree with the sentiment when they see the building's dismal façade and monotonous array of windows. Ever since the 1980s, Berlin's graffiti has been a form of communication between the city and its people. Now another example has joined its ranks.

Walls tell stories  

The graffiti movement emerges in the US in the late Seventies. It soon spills over to Europe, accompanied by a wave of hip-hop culture and punk music. West Berlin is ready to soak it up. The city's divided state means everything is politicised, including art. West Berlin offers artists plenty of scope.  

Many buildings have been reduced to rubble during the Second World War, leaving empty spaces punctuated by immense, blank firewalls. These were constructed to protect houses from the spread of flames in the event of fire, but now they provide perfect empty canvases. Graffiti artists use them to tell their stories, big and small, in images and letters. Monotonous facades such as the building by Siza Vieira become a screen for projecting political news.  

The Kreuzberg district is a major draw, not only for its many firewalls, but because it is home to the biggest canvas in the world - the west side of the Wall. In 1976 the GDR border guards begin building a new type of wall. Made of gleaming white slabs, it is an irresistible invitation to artists. They flock to Berlin from far and wide to leave their comments on local and world politics on the Wall. 

In 1986, the Checkpoint Charlie Museum invites top American street artist Keith Haring to come to Berlin. He is given free rein on a hundred-metre section of the Wall, where he paints his vision of a united Germany in black, red and gold.  

Street art and graffiti can also be found in East Berlin. In the district of Marzahn, an artist from Nicaragua is allowed to paint the facades of East Berlin's typical concrete apartment blocks, but the authorities keep him on a tight rein. From time to time, illegal murals also appear around East Berlin, and as the regime crumbles, the Wall is daubed with slogans such as "Down with the wall of shame" and "Freedom - no more SED lies". This is viewed as subversive activity and punished accordingly.  

The start of a new era  

The fall of the Wall in 1989 heralds a new era for street art and graffiti. Now it's on a roll in East and West alike. Artists from all over the world are drawn to Berlin by events such as the Mural Festival. Today, Berlin is considered the European capital of street art and graffiti.
column13: Bonjour tristesse is no longer alone. In 2012 it was joined by the words BITTE LEBN - please live - written in red to the right of the old graffiti. Here, too, the artist is unknown. But it comes with a trademark sign, the anarchist A.

column8: What begins as a strike ends up as one of the bloodiest street battles in Berlin's history
column11:
The Moabit riots
September 1910 in Moabit - a clerk named Katzmarek is on his way home from work. When he gets off the tram, he's attacked quite out of the blue by baton-wielding policemen. One of them shouts: "What are you looking at?" The uniformed officers charge towards him with sabres drawn.

At the same time, writer Erich Mühsam is noting in his diary: "Encouraging news in Berlin. Workers and women have gathered to confront the strike-breakers at the Moabit coal workers' uprising." 

Fighting for a few pennies 

The confrontations begin on 19 September 1910. Life is hard for workers because food prices and rents are soaring while wages remain low. Workers at Kupfer coal merchants are fighting for a pay rise from 43 to 50 pfennigs an hour. When management rejects their demands, the workers walk out on 19 September.   

Industrialist Hugo Stinnes tries to keep his company's coal business running, but every day there are angry demonstrations. Stinnes asks the police for help and hires an expert strike-breaker called Hintze. He boasts: "I can break any strike. In eight days I can have six thousand men here." His armed strike-breakers eventually arrive on 23 September. This enrages the local residents, who side with the strikers.  

A strike becomes a riot 

Both sides are quick to espouse violence and the strike becomes a bloody battle between picketers and locals on one side and law enforcement and strike-breakers on the other. Police wade into the crowd with their batons, windows are shattered. Stones, bottles and pots rain down. On 25 September, the Kupfer company sends a telegraphs Stinnes, saying: "It's a full-blown battle." 

Two days later, Berlin's police superintendent Traugott von Jagow orders his men to use firearms. 30,000 people are out on the streets. On 27 September, his officers fire on the protesters and crush the rebellion. The people of Moabit are defeated and the strike is over.  

The final shot rings out, the angry mob draws back - and an elderly man lies dead in the street. He had left his house to look for his son and been run through with a sabre. The police have attacked him for no reason, just like Katzmarek. Fortunately, the clerk escapes from the police by jumping onto a passing tram.  

The public are agitated about police brutality and the question of who is to blame for the violence. In October, tens of thousands of workers take to the streets in Moabit to protest against police brutality, followed by more demonstrations four weeks later in Wedding. In his diary, Erich Mühsam concludes: "The whole episode is yet further evidence of something I've known all along: that Berlin workers are the best, the manliest, the most independent and the most libertarian in Germany."
column13: News of the Moabit riots flies around the world because four British journalists are on the street at the time. In Turmstraße they run into armed police who, following orders to "get stuck in", attack the English reporters with sabres. Reuter's correspondent Lester Lawrence is left with his middle finger slashed to the bone.

column8: Squatting becomes an everyday occurrence in East Germany. But many of the occupiers are actually paying rent
column11:
The freedom to live wherever you like
East Berlin, 1981. A grey city filled with crumbling buildings. A 27-year-old physicist has recently separated from her husband and is looking for a roof over her head. She finds an empty apartment. The door is locked, so she simply breaks it open and moves in. Her name is Angela Merkel.

But Germany's Chancellor was not a squatter in the classical sense. "I simply transferred the rent to the state renting agency", she says later on. Back in the 1980s, Merkel was not the only one to find a home in this unorthodox way. In East Germany, schwarzwohnen - occupying vacant buildings - had become the norm. Merkel occupied two properties, first at Marienstraße 24 and later in Templiner Straße.  

Rents at 1936 levels 

Real socialism has produced a severe housing shortage. The government is busy building prefabricated houses while old buildings in the city centres are derelict. Compulsory nationalisation has led to a shortage of skilled tradesmen. The SED freezes rents at 1936 levels, meaning rents stay low but it is impossible for landlords to cover their costs.  

Even for the state, letting property in the GDR is a loss-maker. There is no money for renovations and existing housing stock becomes uninhabitable. In the early 1970s, 600,000 people are officially looking for housing, and the trend is upwards.  

Many young people choose to take matters into their own hands rather than waiting for the state housing agencies to act. On average, the waiting list for a new apartment is 10 years. Meanwhile, countless buildings are standing empty because they are deemed uninhabitable.  

Move in, then register  

But the younger generation don't care. They are not looking for comfort, they want freedom. Outside toilets, coal stoves, leaky windows and roofs, no showers - nothing puts them off. Many of the occupants carry out repairs themselves and register with the police, so the authorities and other residents tend to tolerate them.  

The young people even voluntarily pay rent, as this increases their chances of staying in the long term. They ask their neighbours for the landlord's bank details and hang on to their receipts. If they are forced to move out of one building, they simply move into another. In this difficult situation, the penalties are limited. Fines are generally low, and evictions are prohibited under GDR civil law. This means that the occupiers often go on to become legal tenants.  

The illegal occupations in East Germany provided people with desperately needed places to live. But they also had a psychological effect. The historian Udo Grashoff describes it as an important act of self-assertion by courageous young people, who were often students or artists. He believes the experience of taking action and discovering that state control has its limits was a key element in building the occupiers' confidence in the political arena. Who is perhaps the best proof of this theory? Angela Merkel.
column13: The Ministry of State Security is better informed about illegal occupations than the authorities, but it often chooses to do nothing. Most of the buildings have not been occupied for political reasons but because of the housing crisis. And in every other case, the Stasi is quite happy to have its opponents under control.

column8: A treaty is violated and a street demolished to make way for the Aviation Ministry
column11:
A treaty violation carved in stone
From their lofty pedestals, the stone eagles gaze fiercely over Wilhelmstraße. A Luftwaffe troop marches past in formation. Minister for Aviation Hermann Göring strides across the forecourt. Curious employees lean out of the windows of his ministry. It is 16 March 1937, the second anniversary of the reintroduction of Germany's right to military rearmament. Göring steps up to the microphone for a radio broadcast and reports on the successful rearmament of Germany's Air Force. This clear violation of the Treaty of Versailles was planned in the building in front of you.

The Ministry of Aviation is established soon after the National Socialists take power. This new ministry is set up to work on building a national air force, one of the key steps to becoming a military superpower. This is prohibited under the Treaty of Versailles. But after two years of secret rearmament, Hitler declares Germany's right to military rearmament at the Nuremberg Reich Party Congress. What he actually means by this is the country's right to rearm in contravention of existing treaties. 

In 1935, the new German Luftwaffe gets its own ministry building on Wilhelmstraße. It is one of the Nazi's first monumental building projects. More than 1,000 workers toil on the construction site, working around the clock in three shifts. An entire city block is demolished and cleared and work on the new Aviation Ministry begins on eight different sites. The reinforced concrete building goes up quickly thanks the latest construction methods. For the Nazis, it is one of the key construction sites of the new era - an expression of their power.  

A building with a chequered history 

You are now standing where Hermann Göring and the architect, Erich Sagebiel, officially opened the building in July 1936, shortly before the opening of the Olympic Games. Imagine two huge imperial eagles on their pedestals and swastika flags flying on the roof. Otherwise, nothing much has changed. Göring is happy with the building. He praises its "austere lines as an expression of the austere spirit that governs us all today". With more than 2,000 rooms, the Ministry is one of the biggest office buildings in Europe. But "Fat Hermann" is rarely found at work in his Berlin fortress. He doesn't even have a proper office there.  

The state rooms have been preserved to this day. The dark wood panelling of the small banqueting hall has witnessed many stories and occupants over the years. Ironically, the building where the bombing of Europe was planned and organised survived the war largely unscathed. It has remained in uninterrupted use to this day.  

Its thick walls have housed more than 80 years of political history. Göring's Ministry of Aviation was succeeded by the Soviet military administration, then on 7 October 1949 the building provided the location for the GDR's official founding ceremony. It changed its name to the House of Ministries. After the fall of the GDR, the building became the headquarters of the Treuhand, an agency for restructuring East Germany's state-owned industries after reunification. Today, it houses the German Ministry of Finance.
column13: The new, lightweight material aluminium is transforming aircraft design. This technical innovation is also reflected in the Ministry building. In striking contrast to the stone architecture of the interiors, the balustrades are made of aluminium and still exist in their original state.

column8: The Reichstag Fire on 27 February 1933 came to symbolise the Nazi dictatorship
column11:
The Reichstag fire in 1933 and the road to dictatorship
On 30 January 1933, the National Socialists under Hitler seize power in Germany. Officially, the country still has a democratic constitution. On 27 February 1933, it's Carnival Monday. Not only is the weather bitterly cold, but the mood in the city is equally frosty. Shortly after 9pm, sirens are heard in the inner city - the Reichstag, the German parliament building, is on fire! The fire services arrive quickly, but too late to save the building. A fateful night for democracy in Germany. The Reichstag fire comes to symbolise the Nazi seizure of power.

 

The Reichstag is burning 

Just thirty minutes after the fire starts, the core of the building is almost beyond rescue. The Nazis openly disparage the German parliament. For them, it is just a "talking shop" - and now the parliament building is in flames. The police find a young Dutchman inside, and arrest him as a prime suspect. His name is Marinus van der Lubbe, a communist supporter. Had he really set fire to this massive building all on his own?  

During his first interrogation, he describes in detail how he set the fire. He climbed through a window on the west side of the Reichstag, setting fire to the curtains, wooden panelling and desks. As he went through the building, he used his shirt as a burning torch. Soon curtains, tapestries, carpets, and tablecloths were all on fire. After less than thirty minutes, van der Lubbe walks straight into the arms of two guards.  

"Let's set to work. Everything's bright. That's what we need!"  Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels is thrilled. The Nazis immediately see the propaganda potential of the Reichstag fire. Now, they have an excuse to eliminate their political opponents. Just a few hours after the fire, they arrest hundreds of Communist party functionaries in Berlin. In the course of the day, Hitler's cabinet suspends basic democratic rights. From now on, anyone can be arrested without specific charges. The Nazis claim the country must be protected against a Communist putsch. The tolerance marking Germany in the 1920s is thrown overboard. There is an end to press freedom and freedom of opinion. President von Hindenburg approves the emergency decree ushering in a wave of terror. The measures under the so-called Reichstag Fire Decree turn Germany into a dictatorship. 

At odds over historical events  

In December 1933, a Leipzig court sentences Marinus van der Lubbe to death for arson and treason. Since then, historians have argued over the Reichstag fire. Did van der Lubbe really set the fire alone? Did he have helpers? Was he working for someone else? And what role did the Nazis play? After all, they profited most from the fire.  

For years, a secret underground tunnel connects the Reichstag with the palatial residence of the Reichstag President - in 1933, Herman Göring. So could Göring have sent his SA or SS henchmen through the tunnel?  No surviving historical documents prove the Nazis were involved in the fire - and even fire experts believe Marinus van der Lubbe could have acted alone.
column12:
Opening hours:
Monday to Sunday 8pm to 12am, last admittance: 9.45pm

Admission to the Reichstag building, the Reichstag dome and the guided tours are all free of charge. However, visits must be booked in advance by registering online at the https://visite.bundestag.de/BAPWeb/pages/createBookingRequest.jsf">Bundestag's visitors' page, by fax or by post, stating your name and date of birth. Spontaneous visitors can register in person at the Visitors' Service Office. Free places are allocated a minimum of two hours before the time of your visit, or you can book a place on one of the following two days.

For more information on this location, events and tickets, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/reichstag-in-berlin
column13: Franz and Erich Sass are the best-known safebreakers of their day. They try their luck at Deutsche Bank branch offices, the safes of the Dresdner Bank, and many others as well. The Sass brothers are a legend in their lifetime, and locals also ascribe some unsolved crimes to them. When the Reichstag went up in flames, the locals asked: Who set the fire? And in 1938, they ask: Who set fire to the synagogues? The smart alecks know the answer: the brothers SA-SS.

column8: Rock-bottom - at the Palm, homeless people experience the dark side of the "Golden" Twenties
column11:
A home for life’s castaways
"This palm tree stands on the beach of poverty, and in its shade there is little happiness." This is how journalist Max Barthel describes the municipal homeless shelter in Fröbelstraße in January 1929. Dating back to imperial times, the brick fortress is feared by most Berliners. Nobody wants to sink so low that they have to sleep at the "Palm", as the homeless shelter is called because of the exotic plant that grows at its entrance.

Day in, day out, a long queue of homeless people forms at the shelter, waiting for it to open its doors at 3 o'clock. They are mainly men: "young lads and old hobos, forced to live as beggars for decades, the derelicts of bourgeois society". This is how they are described in the communist newspaper, the Red Flag. The queue is also full of people who have ended up on the street because they can't pay their rent. Many of them have simply given up hope.  

Police checks 

In the reception area, it's like a military barracks. The homeless have to salute the staff on duty. Most of them still display the Prussian mentality that equates homelessness with crime. Each new arrival is carefully checked for a criminal record, and the police keep a close eye on the homeless shelter. Anyone who wants a bed for the night has their neck stamped and is told to strip to their underwear so that their clothes can be disinfected in the delousing room. Only then are they given their standard bowl of watery gruel.  

At 10 o'clock, the doors of the "Palm" close for the night. That's when the moaning and groaning starts. Up to 70 men can be accommodated in each dormitory at the rear of the shelter. The main building has a few rooms for women and children. When times are tough, more than 5,000 people can be sleeping in the shelter. Fights break out constantly over people's meagre possessions. Sleep is often out of the question. The stench is almost unbearable. 

Into the unknown 

Everyone is kicked out at six the next morning. Most of them don't know what to do or where to go and will end up back in the queue that afternoon. But they can't stay for longer than two weeks. This rule is spelled out to everyone who comes looking for a bed: "You can only stay here for 14 days. During that time you have to find a job and somewhere to live." 

For most of them, it's an impossible task. But if they try to stay longer than two weeks they run the risk of being sent to the notorious municipal workhouse in Rummelsburg. Once this happens, they have not only lost their home, but also their freedom.
column13: In 1911, Rosa Luxemburg writes an impassioned article protesting about the conditions at the homeless shelter in Fröbelstraße after 70 homeless people died there, poisoned by adulterated alcohol and contaminated fish.

column8: Hitler's Reich Chancellery is a symbol of power - and vanishes entirely after the war
column11:
Hitler’s megalomania in stone
The floor is smooth as glass. The diplomats carefully place one foot in front of the other, their footsteps echoing through massive rooms that smell of varnish and new paint. Impressed, they look at the magnificent marble in the seemingly endless gallery. The date is 12 January 1939 - a New Year Reception for the diplomatic corps. The event coincides with the inauguration of the new Reich Chancellery. After what seems an eternity, the ambassadors and emissaries reach the reception hall. There, they are welcomed by Adolf Hitler - at the first and last New Year reception in this building.

The old Reich Chancellery looks like it was fit for a soap company, Hitler remarks bitingly. A new Reich Chancellery is needed, he decides. He orders Albert Speer, his General Building Inspector, to design and build a new Chancellery reflecting the Third Reich's aspiration to world power. Speer has an entire street at his disposal for his design. The new Reich Chancellery is to stretch 500 metres. So if you walk down all of Voßstrasse, you get a feeling of just how vast this building was.  

Working without a break 

A brochure published to mark the opening of the Reich Chancellery contains the lines, "The Führer's Reich Chancellery is built overnight, there Professor Speer has created a masterpiece!". Not surprisingly, the new Chancellery takes more than one night to construct, although it is built within a year - quite an achievement. The workers are on site in shifts, day and night, every weekend, and every public holiday. The costs spiral to three times the original budget.  

Hitler's new Reich Chancellery opens its doors for a New Year reception. The reception rooms are designed to impress - but there is still scaffolding in the offices on the upper floor. The Reich Chancellery is not functional, and hardly used in the years afterwards. But it is a symbol of Hitler's power. 

Hitler is especially impressed by the long marble gallery, twice as long as the Hall of Mirrors at the Palace of Versailles - a place hated by the Nazis as the scene of signing the Treaty of Versailles that ends the First World War. "On the long walk from the entrance to the reception hall, they'll get a taste of the power and grandeur of the German Reich!", Hitler says to Speer.  

Nothing left to see 

In the Second World War, the Reich Chancellery is less damaged than many buildings in the vicinity. Its ruins become a tourist attraction. Before the Potsdam Conference, both British Prime Minister Winston Churchill and US President Harry S. Truman come by to view it. Then work starts on demolishing this monolith - and takes seven times as long as it did to build it.  

When the Berlin Wall goes up, the open site of the former Reich Chancellery becomes part of the border area, lost in no man's land. Shortly before the Wall falls, East Germany constructs some prefabricated concrete-slab apartment blocks on the eastern section of Voßstraße. The tower blocks are still there today. In search of the remains of the Reich Chancellery, tourist groups often visit the tube station at Mohrenstraße. The red marble there seems suspiciously similar to the materials used for the Reich Chancellery. But historians have shown there is actually no connection. There really is nothing left to see of the Third Reich's once monumental symbol of power.
column13: There are many rumours about the whereabouts of the globe Hitler had in his study - the globe that became world famous through Charlie Chaplin's dance with it in his film The Great Dictator. The globe is said to be in the German Historical Museum - or is it the one in the Märkisches Museum? The original globe is thought to be lost, but it belongs to the legends about the Reich Chancellery.

column8: On the list for demolition - but saved by a grassroots protest by locals
column11:
A symbol of reconciliation
Demolition, reconstruction or something new? In West Berlin, what to do with the Memorial Church's ruins was hotly debated. Ultimately, they became a symbol of peace.

Architect Ego Eiermann feels more than annoyed. On 25 March 1957, his design for rebuilding the Kaiser Wilhelm Memorial Church wins the architectural competition. He plans to entirely demolish the old church, left in ruins by the war.
