The estate is to provide affordable housing for the workforce at the nearby Siemens production site. Between 1929 and 1934, a total of 1379 apartments are built, all with either 2 or 2.5 rooms.

The estate's six architects include four members of the Der Ring avant-garde association: Walter Gropius, Hans Scharoun, Otto Bartning and Hugo Häring. The other two architects involved are Fred Forbát and Paul Rudolf Henning.

Breaking with tradition

The aim is to find architectural and urban planning innovations for a modern world. The time has come to move on from perimeter block developments with their dark courtyards - the traditional approach in pre-1918 Germany. This estate sets out to create similar conditions for everyone living there - the same space and light, and an equal chance to enjoy sun and fresh air. The six architects soon agree on dividing the design of individual rows of houses between them.

Hans Scharoun, responsible for the estate's overall urban planning, proposes an entirely new style of residential estate for Berlin. With this design, he can realise his idea of a residential neighbourhood - rows of housing set in generous space and communal green areas.

Six individual signature styles

Strolling through the estate today, take the time to look at the individual architectural details. With each architect responsible for individual rows of houses, the details form a kind of personal signature.

Hans Scharoun designs the access to the estate, creating a sort of funnel of three five-storied buildings on both sides of the street. He also borrows some elements from naval architecture, such as the circular windows recalling portholes.

Very different principles are applied to the two rows on the western side of the spreading estate. Here, Walter Gropius, founder of the Bauhaus, has kept to a cool functional elegance. The white block façades broken by the dark grey of the windows and the angular contours of the balconies are informed by the rationality of the New Objectivity movement.

Otto Bartning's long ribbon building stretching 338 metres is oriented east-west. The living rooms and bedrooms face south, the kitchens and bathrooms are set to the north. The plain façade is certainly not to everyone's taste, and locals soon nickname the building the lange Jammer ('long lament'). 

In Hugo Häring's designs for his rows of houses, natural materials and colours play a large part, with warm brown and ochre tones harmonising with the landscaped grounds. Here, the most noticeable elements are the kidney-shaped balconies projecting from the façades.

The rows of houses by Fred Forbát and Paul Rudolf Henning also bear each architect's own signature. On some ground floor apartments, Henning integrated terraces, underscoring the focus on fresh air and sunshine. Forbát's architecture is inspired by clear lines and geometric shapes, enlivened with brick elements on the staircases.

Each in their own way, the six architects of the large Siemensstadt estate aspired to nothing less than optimal, modern living conditions for the contemporary age. In realising that goal, they anticipated the trends in urban design in the post-war years.
column12:
When you visit the Großsiedlung Siemensstadt estate, you are visiting people's homes.
We would ask you to respect their privacy! Thank you!

For more information on this location, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/large-siemensstadt-housing-estate
column13: Berliners were quick to react to Hans Scharoun's ship-like design at the entrance to the Siemensstadt estate, soon dubbing the residential block the "armoured cruiser". Yet in this work, Scharoun also convincingly demonstrated his remarkable talent for harmoniously unifying unusual forms. He himself lived in one of the apartments until 1960.

column8: A married couple from Berlin's Wedding district write postcards against the Nazi regime
column11:
Postcards against Hitler
Late summer 1940. A man leaves the door of the apartment building at Amsterdamer Straße 10. His hat is set low to cover his face. He walks rapidly towards the Müllerstraße boulevard. Unobtrusively, he enters Müllerstraße 174. He puts a hand-written postcard in the lobby, and quickly leaves. Together with wife Elise, Otto Hampel writes postcards against the Nazi regime.

The path to resistance 

After the National Socialists' seizure of power, Otto and Elise Hampel are just like almost all other working-class couples. They simply adapt to the new conditions. But in 1940, Elise's brother is killed in the war. His death prompts the couple to turn their back on the regime - and to act. From 1940 to 1942, driven by this personal tragedy, they write around 200 postcards and leaflets. These are a general call to stop supporting the Nazi regime's criminal war, and to overthrow the dictator Adolf Hitler: "Down with Hitler's gang responsible for the war!" 

Postcards for freedom 

Otto and Elise Hampel only attended elementary school for a few years. Their texts may reflect their simple background, but their feisty messages do not mince words: "Hitlerism destroys the basis of all human rights!" 

The Hampels are taking an enormous risk. The Nazi regime has draconian punishments even for just listening to foreign radio broadcasts. Most people finding the Hampels' postcards hand them directly to the police, either from fear - or obedience. The investigations are launched straight away. 

In the Gestapo's Department IV, Detective Sergeant Willy Püschel sticks flags into a Berlin map on the wall, marking where the postcards and leaflets are found. Most of the flags are in the Wedding district, though some are in Charlottenburg, Schöneberg and Kreuzberg. Despite the many clues, the Hampels repeatedly slip through the Gestapo's fingers. 

Finally, in October 1942, after two years of investigations, the police arrest them. A woman saw the couple laying out postcards on Nollendorfplatz square and reports them.  

Just a few months later, the People's Court sentences Elise and Otto Hampel to death for "subversion of the war effort" und "preparing for high treason". Faced with the death sentence, they start blaming each other. On 8 April 1943, Elise and Otto Hampel are executed separately in the Berlin-Plötzensee prison.
column13: The fate of the Hampels inspired German writer Hans Fallada to write his 1947 novel Jeder stirbt für sich allein (published in English as Alone in Berlin). The plot is largely based on the trial records. The novel has been filmed several times, last in 2016 starring Emma Thompson, Brendan Gleeson and Daniel Brühl.

column8: As new residents pour into Berlin, sewage pours out of the city
column11:
A city beneath the city
As far as Arthur Hobrecht is concerned, the whole thing stinks. Berlin's mayor has a problem. The city is mushrooming, and its sanitation system is at breaking point. The gutters in the streets and even the River Spree itself are becoming cesspools. Berlin smells like a toilet used by a million people.

It's not just the disgusting smell. The city is totally unhygienic and urgent action is needed. The eminent physician Rudolf Virchow raises the alarm and warns of cholera and typhoid epidemics if the city's streets and water supplies continue to be contaminated by excrement. The old wells have been replaced with a drinking water supply, but sewage is a growing problem. The city's sewage system has never been upgraded. Berlin's 16,000 water closets are flushed into the metre-wide gutters that line the streets. The majority of residents still have outhouses in their backyards, from where the waste is collected and often illegally dumped into the Spree under cover of darkness. Rats rummage through the waste looking for food, and a permanent foul stench hangs in the air. The rain regularly rinses out the gutters, but in winter the wastewater freezes, turning the streets to sheet ice.  

No more sewage in the streets  

The liberal mayor's brother, James Hobrecht, made a name for himself in 1862 when he came up with his Land Use Plan for the Environs of Berlin - known as the Hobrecht Plan. Earlier plans had been rejected, such as pouring all the city's sewage into the Spree. Holbrecht is charged with planning and building a new sewage and drainage system. 

Earlier in his career, Hobrecht had travelled to many major cities to study their sewer systems. Armed with this knowledge, the new urban planning office draws up a plan for Berlin, which it presents to the city council on 16 November 1872. It recommends the construction of twelve separate pumping stations, known as radial systems. The name comes from the sewer pipes that run down to the centre of the circular systems, like the spokes of a wheel. Pumping stations like the Radialsystem V pumping station that you see in front of you dispersed the sewage to drainage fields outside the city.  

Two-way traffic 

More and more people are leaving the countryside and heading for the city - meaning more and more sewage has to be pumped the other way. Sewage from Pumping Station V ends up in the sewage farms of northern Falkenberg. It passes through a pressure pipe into a settling tank where the solid sediment is skimmed off. Then it is spread over the drainage fields, where it is filtered through several layers of soil. Once it has been purified in this way, the water returns to the groundwater. James Hobrecht's radial system cleans up Berlin, improves the health of its inhabitants and makes lasting changes to the urban landscape. The sewer system is an ingenious city beneath the city.
column12: For more information on this location events and tickets, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/radialsystem-v
column13: The first sewage irrigation tests are carried out at Tempelhofer Feld in 1871 and 1872. By order of the police, all Berlin's households have to be connected to the new sewer system by 1874.

column8: Beaten, shot and drowned - the fate of the Spartacus leaders leaves the revolution in shock
column11:
The murder of Rosa Luxemburg and Karl Liebknecht
A cab pulls up next to a dark footpath in Berlin's Tiergarten. Eight men get out, seven of them in uniform. The eighth is dressed in civilian clothes and staggers as he gets out. The soldiers lead him down the path to the lake Neuer See. Shots ring out into the night of 15 January 1919.

It's three days since Freikorp troops suppressed the Spartacist uprising in Berlin, when Communists occupied the police headquarters and the office of social democratic newspaper Vorwärts. The bloody protests ended with leaders of the uprising going on the run, including Rosa Luxemburg and Karl Liebknecht.   

Arrests and interrogations 

Around 9pm on 15 January, men of the Wilmersdorf militia force their way into Mannheimer Straße 43, the home of a merchant called Siegfried Marcusson. This is where the leaders of the Sparticist movement had taken refuge the previous day. Karl Liebknecht, Rosa Luxemburg and Wilhelm Pieck are all led away. Luxemburg is allowed to take a small suitcase of books with her. They're taken to the Hotel Eden on Kurfürstendamm, today's Budapester Straße 35, which houses a division of the Freikorps. Liebknecht is brought in around 9.30, Luxemburg half an hour later. 

They're both taken to the interrogation room on the first floor. 38-year-old Captain Waldemar Pabst interrogates them separately. Luxemburg is clearly exhausted by the events of the last few days. She looks gaunt, with dark circles under her eyes. When Pabst ask whether she is really Rosa Luxemburg, she simply says: "Decide for yourself" and starts sewing up the hem of her skirt, which was torn during her arrest. And she reads Goethe's Faust - for the very last time. 

Transportation and murder 

During Luxemburg's interrogation, soldiers take Liebknecht down to the foyer around 10.45 pm. At the side exit, soldier Otto Runge strikes him twice in the face with his rifle butt. Bleeding, he is led to the car. Lieutenant Pflugk-Harttung's official orders are to take Liebknecht to Moabit prison. But instead he heads for the Tiergarten. Under the pretext of a flat tyre, the soldiers stop the car and tell Liebknecht to get out. Pflugk-Harttung pretends to release Liebknecht, but then shoots him in the back of the head at close range. Three other soldiers also fire at him.  

When Lieutenant Vogel takes Rosa Luxemburg outside shortly before midnight, she has no inkling of Liebknecht's fate. Runge once more swings his rifle butt, and she loses consciousness. She's still alive as she's driven away in an open-top car, but just 40 metres from the hotel, Lieutenant Hermann Souchon takes out his pistol and shoots her. The soldiers throw her lifeless body into the Landwehr Canal near the Lichtenstein Bridge. Today, a memorial to Rosa Luxemburg stands on this spot near the bridge.
column12: For more information on this location and events, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/tiergarten
column13: A court-martial has been in session since 8 May, but Luxemburg's body has not been found. A diver is sent to search the Landwehr Canal. He doesn't find Luxemburg, but he does find three other bodies. Her body is eventually found in the canal on 31 May by lock worker Gottfried Knepel, near the Freiarchen Bridge.

column8: A monster success comes to a tragic end - how the Love Parade destroys itself
column11:
Germany’s famous techno parade
"Hey, can you hear me?" A storm of cheers. "Really?!" The crowd screams again. "Hi, it's me, Dr Motte! Welcome to the Love Parade 1998 One World One Future! How are you doing?" Cheers. "We hope you'll have a good time. It's great to see you all. A million people are here!!" The crowd on Berlin's Große Stern go crazy. 

A mini parade becomes a major event 

Dr Motte's Love Parade speeches at the Victory Column are the stuff of legend. The techno DJ started the open-air event in 1989 under the motto peace, joy and pancakes. In an interview he comments: "The first Love Parade gave me goose bumps for five hours. We walked up the Ku'damm with 150 people, the police in front and behind. On the way back, we blocked an intersection and danced in the street." 

Within 10 years, this small parade has turned into a major event. Every year, the Kurfürstendamm disappears beneath a sea of bodies dancing to the techno beat. Where you are walking today is where ravers came to party at the Love Parade - until 1995. Then, the Ku'damm was so full that the crowd spilled across the street and over to the Brandenburg Gate.  

Commerce, criticism and catastrophe  

"If the number of visitors continues to grow like this, the whole planet will be dancing by 2005", says Love Parade organiser Ralf Regitz. But its founder, Dr Motte, is feeling disillusioned with the peace parade because it's becoming too mainstream, too commercial. And it has a bad image because of blatant drug dealing, the rubbish left in the Tiergarten, and the harassment of local residents.  

More than a million ravers descend on Berlin for the tenth anniversary of the Love Parade, but numbers start to decline in the 2000s. Sponsors jump ship and the event is cancelled in 2004 and 2005. It is brought back to life in 2006 - but without Dr Motte. "I'm finished with the Love Parade", he says. The Love Parade moves from Berlin to the cities of the Ruhr area, until disaster strikes in 2010. At the Love Parade in Duisburg, mass panic breaks out in a narrow tunnel. 21 people are killed and hundreds are badly injured. It spells the end of the legendary techno parade.
column12:
Opening hours:
Open daily (except 24 December)
April - October Monday - Friday 9.30am - 6.30pm, Saturday & Sunday 9.30am - 7pm
November - March Monday - Friday 9.30am - 5.30pm, Saturday & Sunday 9.30am - 5.30pm

For more information, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/siegessaule
column13: In 1997 a counter movement to the Love Parade is founded - the Hate Parade. It is a political demonstration against the commercialisation of culture and public spaces. But when certain media interpret the Hate Parade to be a "parade of hate", the organisers rename it Fuck Parade. It still takes place every year in Berlin.

column8: For the National Socialists, Sachsenhausen was a model concentration camp. It was an instrument of terror
column11:
Where martyrdom is part of everyday life
As soon as you enter this place, you start to question whether you really appreciate the freedom you enjoy every minute of every day. The Sachsenhausen concentration camp epitomises the National Socialists' systematic persecution and oppression. They imprisoned their opponents here under the most inhumane conditions.

Sachsenhausen concentration camp   

The order from the head of the SS, Heinrich Himmler, is to build a "totally modern, up-to-date, easily expandable" camp. The project is assigned to architect Bernhard Kuiper. He draws up a plan for the complex, which is laid out like an equilateral triangle. It incorporates the prisoners' huts, the commandant's office and barracks for the SS guards. The design is predicated on a "geometry of total terror". From watchtower A, a single machine gun has a clear line of fire over all 68 of the prison barracks grouped in four rings around the semicircular roll call area.  

The camp is separated from the outside world by 3-metre-high walls and an electrified barbed wire fence. Nine watchtowers, mounted guards and vicious guard dogs stifle any hope of escape for the prisoners. The Nazis have chosen to build their chamber of horrors in the forest north of Berlin. From 1938 onwards, the camp also acts as the administrative centre for all other concentration camps in Germany.  

As they enter the camp through the main wrought-iron gate, prisoners are taunted by the inscription "Arbeit macht frei" ("Work sets you free"). The SS commandant lives in Tower A. The tower's architecture symbolises the power of the SS, built solely on violence and cruelty. Every day, the prisoners spend up to 16 hours doing hard physical labour, building roads, working in local factories or in the forest. Death is an everyday occurrence. Inmates die from exhaustion, typhoid or dysentery. Day after day, prisoners are interrogated, tortured, shot or beaten to death. 

Martyrdom is a part of everyday life 

Martyrdom is a part of the prisoners' everyday lives. Thousands are crammed into 68 huts. Sometimes as many as 500 inmates are squeezed into a single hut. The day is organised along military lines. The lights come on at 4.15am sharp and the prisoners assemble for roll call. Their lives are dominated by back-breaking work. Anyone who doesn't toe the line or breaks the most minor of camp rules faces brutal punishment, such as being whipped on their naked buttocks. The force of the blows breaks the backs of some prisoners, exposes their kidneys or crushes their testicles. 

At first, the Nazis mainly send their political opponents to Sachsenhausen. Hitler's would-be assassin Georg Elser is held here until he is moved on to Dachau. Other prominent inmates include the Protestant pastor of the Confessing Church, Martin Niemöller, actor Erwin Geschonneck, publisher Peter Suhrkamp, and SPD politician Rudolf Breitscheid. The National Socialists also do not tolerate homosexuals or "the workshy" in their "people's community". With the outbreak of World War II, they start bringing people to the camp from all over the occupied territories. After 1941 thousands of Soviet prisoners of war are executed by shooting.
column13: The story is made even more tragic by the fact that the end of Nazi rule fails to restore peace to this place. 12,000 people die here after the end of the war, including Berlin theatre director and UFA film star Heinrich George in 1946. His son Götz George later commemorated the fate of his father in a film (George, 2013). Götz George is well known in Germany for his leading role in the popular TV crime show Tatort. The name of his character, Schimanski, is a tribute to former Auschwitz prisoner Tadeusz Szymanski, whom the actor met while shooting the film Death is my Trade (1977) in Auschwitz.

column8: Beating the Wall - attacking the monstrosity of unfreedom with hammers and chisels.
column11:
Souvenirs of the new freedom
Shortly after the Wall falls on 9 November 1989, the "Wallpeckers" are busy at work. These souvenir hunters, tourists, vendors and GDR opponents take away parts of the Berlin Wall bit by bit. The façade of this once insurmountable "protective wall" starts to crumble.

The West Berlin police loudspeakers boom out loud and clear: "Stop chipping away at the Wall!" But it takes more than that to stop the Wallpeckers. As they knock pieces off the concrete Wall, they create a wall of sound never heard before in Berlin - hammering, clanging, banging, and cracking.  

Anyone who hears this "historic noise" live can never forget it - just like Michael Glaser, working for East Germany's only record label VEB Deutsche Schallplatten. In his view, the noise of these days is "an incredibly great sound". And while the entire world watches events in Berlin spellbound, Glaser and his colleague Horst Langheinrich captures them acoustically - by hanging microphones out of their office window. Later, their recordings are released as the CD Mauerspechte - The Wall-Peckers -  the 100% authentic sound of the Peaceful Revolution. 

The façade crumbles  

Even before these dramatic events, there are solo actions attacking the Wall by, for example, John Runnings, a committed freethinker and peace campaigner. In 1986, Runnings climbs the Wall at Potsdamer Platz and, using a sledgehammer, knocks off some of the smooth pipe on top - an action later leading him to be dubbed "Father of all Wallpeckers". In the night of 9 November 1989, the Berlin Wall at the Brandenburg Gate is again conquered - this time by euphoric crowds attacking it with hammers or even their bare hands.  

A few days later the first souvenir hunters arrive, all keen to scavenge a piece of this world-famous concrete wall. In no time at all, the small group of people carefully knocking pieces off the Wall swells to hundreds. It becomes a kind of popular sport. Suddenly, the market for fragments of the Wall booms, especially for pieces showing traces of the original graffiti. In many cases, though, the colour is actually sprayed on afterwards - without colour, the fragments just look like any lump of concrete. 

Where is the wall? 

Work officially starts on demolishing what the GDR called the "anti-fascist protective wall" in June 1990. The Wall dividing Berlin for over 28 years is quickly removed. In autumn 1990, the most frequent question tourists ask is: "Where is the Wall?" The answer today is easy - bits of it can be found scattered around the world.  

In 1989, Hagen Koch is responsible for organising the demolishing of the Wall. He knows that selected pieces end up abroad as memorials, prize trophies, advertising gifts, art objects or as gestures of thanks - among the most famous recipients, for example, Ronald Reagan, Bill Gates and the Vatican. You can also find small original parts of the Wall in the Berlin Tourist Info Centres at Brandenburg Gate, the Central Station, the Europa-Center and the Hotel Park Inn by Radisson Berlin Alexanderplatz.

And if you find yourself in front of a surviving part of the Wall, for instance at the East Side Gallery, just remember: Chipping pieces off it is strictly prohibited!
column12: For more information on this location, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/brandenburg-gate
column13: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy claims he was one of the first Wallpeckers. A photo supposedly shows a young Sarkozy hammering at a piece of Wall covered in graffiti. Allegedly, he is on the old GDR side - yet graffiti spraying was strictly prohibited in East Germany and, in any case, no one could have come close enough to the eastern side of the Wall to spray it. So when Sarkozy posts the photo on Facebook, many doubt its authenticity.

column8: US President Ronald Reagan ignores his advisers - and goes down in the history books
column11:
A “provocation” becomes reality
When Ronald Reagan uttered his famous words: "Mr Gorbachev, tear down this wall!", many people felt he was being deliberately provocative in the midst of the Cold War. But a few years later these words lead to him being hailed as a political prophet.

It's 12 June 1987, a special day for Berlin. Schools have been closed, roads blocked, the underground trains have come to a standstill. The city is celebrating its 750th birthday - but few people guess that it will be a historic day for quite different reasons. After all, the guest of honour, US President Ronald Reagan, is only dropping in for five hours. He's not even spending the night.  

Along with visits to the Reichstag, Bellevue Palace and Tempelhof Airport, there is one other item on the itinerary for the world's most powerful man: Reagan is to give a speech at the Brandenburg Gate. Political observers are not expecting it be particularly significant. 

Protests against the Cold War hardliner   

But some Berliners are in no mood for celebrating. They think Reagan is a Cold War hardliner who sees the Soviet Union as "the evil Empire". Protests break out in Kreuzberg and demonstrators fight running battles with police.  

Meanwhile, American and German flags are waving in front of the Brandenburg Gate. The Senate and US Embassy have assembled a sympathetic crowd for the speech. "For the last two-and-a-half hours there's been what can only be described as a carnival atmosphere". This is how reporter Peter Schulz describes the scene for West-Berlin based Radio in the American Sector (RIAS).  

The danger of an assassination attempt from the East forces Reagan to stand behind bullet-proof glass panels. He talks about the Olympic Games and disarmament before addressing his soon-to-be famous words to the Soviet Union's General Secretary: "Mr Gorbachev, open this gate! Mr Gorbachev, tear down this wall!" 

A muted response  

The crowd cheers - but no-one imagines Reagan's words will end up in the history books. Reagan's speech is covered in the Western press, but the response is muted. The Soviet news agency TASS, on the other hand, accuses the US president of delivering a "war-mongering speech".  

That's what Reagan's staff had feared, and it's why they tried to talk the president out of including the phrase. Just a few hours before the president was due to speak, the State Department sent over a less provocative draft of the speech. But Reagan sensed the mood of the time and stood his ground. 

After 1989, the president's words became famous all over the world. But he was not a prophet when he gave his speech two years earlier. He was simply summing up the prevailing mood in Berlin. 

In 2017, SPIEGEL revealed that Reagan had qualified his suggestions in talks with Moscow's Foreign Minister Shevardnadze in 1988. He admitted that it was "perhaps unrealistic to suggest tearing down the entire wall".
column12: For more information on this location, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/brandenburg-gate
column13: To this day, it remains unclear who Reagan had to thank for this famous phrase. John Kornblum, later US ambassador in Bonn, and Peter M. Robinson, Reagan's speechwriter at the time, both still claim credit for these historic words.

column8: Graphic artist Josef Fenneker not only designs posters for the TAM, but also often receives commissions from the renowned Marmorhaus am Kurfürstendamm 236 in middle-class Charlottenburg.
column11:
“Blonde Poison” and bags of candied fruit
The movie Theater am Moritzplatz (TAM) employs seven musicians, six ushers and ticket sellers, a projectionist, one woman for the cloakroom and two selling candied fruit. With daily shows with two changes of programme every week and a music ensemble providing the accompaniment, TAM offers everything film fans need.

Along with such popular films as Das Blumenmädchen vom Moritzplatz (The Flower-Girl of Moritzplatz) by Johannes Eißner, movie theatre operator Siegbert Goldschmidt also shows the film Blondes Gift (Blonde Poison), commissioning a poster by ambitious graphic artist Josef Fenneker. But soon after the film premières in September 1919, Berlin's Police President classifies Blonde Poison as indecent and bans it. The film tells the story of Loni, a femme fatale played by Hedda Vernon. Loni first brings disaster on her husband and then, when both her lovers die, shows no remorse.

TAM is part of the Establissment Buggenhagen, a large restaurant and beer garden which, in turn, belongs to the successful Aschinger-Bierquelle stock corporation. Aschinger epitomises the major league of Berlin's standing-only beer halls, a perfect fit for the liberal clientele at Moritzplatz.

In 1911, in a large Establissment Buggenhagen ballroom at Oranienstraße 147 on Moritzplatz, the Union-Theater movie theatre opens its doors. In August 1919, entrepreneur Siegbert Goldschmidt takes over the theatre. Goldschmidt, who also runs the well-known premiere cinema Marmorhaus on Kurfürstendamm, extends the space to create the Theater am Moritzplatz, a cinema seating 783 guests.

As early as 1925, Siegbert Goldschmidt's recurring health issues force him to give up the management of his cinema, which for a time also housed the Alhambra Varieté theatre. In 1928, after the cinema stands empty for nearly three years, Fritz Kärger leases it and renames it the TAM - Theater am Moritzplatz.

According to Chamber of Commerce and Industry records, Kärger employs seven musicians, six ushers and ticket sellers, a projectionist, one woman for the cloakroom and two selling candied fruit.

In the global economic crisis and with the rise of the talkies, Kärger closes his cinema at Moritzplatz and opens one in Fürstenwalde, outside Berlin.

In the meantime, Siegbert Goldschmidt is reduced to penury. Living on welfare since 1930, he is even unable to raise the money to have his company officially deregistered. He dies in February 1938 aged 64 and is buried on the Jewish Cemetery in Berlin-Weißensee.

The TAM has a series of owners before the building is destroyed in an air raid in 1943. Today, the site is home to the Aufbau-Haus.
column13: On the same site, you can again find a theatre - the TAK, Theater Aufbau Kreuzberg, is part of the Aufbau-Haus building.

column8: Dreams of omnipotence lead to the construction of the Italian Embassy in 1938
column11:
A prestige project in the diplomatic quarter
Tiergartenstraße, early December 1942. It's still a construction site, but the building looks finished. With its shimmering reddish-brown façade, it stands out from the grey buildings all around. From inside comes the sound of hammering and the voices of German and Italian construction workers. This prestigious building project at the heart of the Third Reich is nearly finished - the new Italian Embassy.

New diplomatic quarter  

It is to be the most impressive embassy in the city's new diplomatic quarter. Adolf Hitler and his architect Albert Speer have drawn up a plan to turn Berlin into the new capital of the Reich, to be called Germania. But entire districts, including many embassy buildings, stand in their way. So Speer decides to build a new diplomatic quarter in the western part of the Tiergarten district to accommodate twelve embassies and residences.  

The best locations and largest plots are reserved for Germany's closest allies: Italy and Japan. Hitler has a particularly close political alliance with the Italy's Duce, Benito Mussolini. The Italian embassy is due to be built at one end of Siegesallee. This "Victory Avenue" runs to the Victory Column, which has recently been moved to its new location in the Großer Stern square.  

Construction work on the embassy begins in 1938. The architect is a German, Friedrich Hetzelt. But the Italians are involved in drawing up the plans and hold frequent meetings with Hetzelt. The results are clear when you look at the façade. The front of the building is faced with travertine, a type of stone from Tivoli. Marble from the Strona Valley has been used for the stairs and terraces at the rear. The Italian Embassy resembles a Renaissance palazzo. 

The party is over  

1939. Work on the building grinds to a halt just before it is completed. Germany has declared war on the world. The construction workers have to go off to fight. Building materials become scarce. But Hitler wants to show his respect for the Duce and insists the embassy has to be finished. So construction resumes with the help of Italian builders from Volkswagen in Wolfsburg. In autumn 1942, Renaissance doorways and sections of French wooden wall panels are delivered to ensure the interior is as magnificent as the exterior. Electrically operated dumb waiters are standing by, ready for the glitzy opening ceremony.  

But the party is cancelled. There's a war on, so it's not a good time to be swilling champagne and scoffing canapés. Architect Friedrich Hetzelt and an Italian colleague simply sign off the building and it's ready to move in.  

But the Italian ambassador barely has time to get his feet under the table before the building is bombed. After the war, the Tiergarten diplomatic quarter falls into a deep sleep. Children use the ruins as an adventure playground. Part of one wing is renovated to accommodate the Italian Consulate General.  

1990. After German reunification, Italy is determined to rebuild the embassy. It reopens in 2003, part of a brand new embassy district in the Tiergarten.
column12:
Opening hours: 
Monday and Friday 8.30am - 12.30pm
Tuesday 8.30am - 10.30am
Wednesday and Thursday 1pm - 5pm
Closed Saturday and Sunday

Temporary exhibitions
column13: A bundle of sticks and an axe. This ancient Roman symbol is now the symbol of Italian fascism. Bundles of sticks decorated the entrance lobby of the original embassy. During renovations they are discreetly moved to another part of the building, where an information board explains their significance.

column8: The egg storage warehouse at Oberbaumbrücke supplies Germany's fast-growing capital
column11:
And two on Sundays
75 million eggs? If the thought of eating even one egg for Sunday breakfast is too much for you, you might find it hard to believe that 75 million eggs were once stored in this huge building with the yellow clinker facade. In their typically blunt fashion, Berliners call this cold storage warehouse the "Eierspeicher", or "egg store". It opened in 1929 in the Osthafen dock area as a logistics hub for the city's egg trade.

Along with handling 450 truckloads of eggs, the warehouse also has plenty of space for other chilled goods, such as 8,000 tonnes of frozen meat, game and poultry. The facility has nine storeys and thousands of cubic metres of storage space, which is kept at -10 to +8 degrees Celsius. It also stores butter, wine, canned goods and deli products. 

Feeding Berlin's millions 

The steel-frame building commissioned by Leipziger Kühltransit AG is a classic example of a modern, purpose-built facility designed for a distribution company in the Twenties: efficient, functional, dull. Around 10 million eggs are consumed in Berlin every day, that's two eggs per person per day. The egg storage warehouse is designed to close a gap in the supply chain. It's a constant source of annoyance to chefs and housewifes alike that eggs go off so quickly, but now they can arrive in the shops in perfect condition. Berlin is growing, and so are the challenges of moving goods around the city. Berliners want fresh food. 

Goods from all over the world 

The cold storage warehouse is mainly a transit hub. Perishable foods from as far afield as Argentina, Austrialia and China arrive here to be repackaged and prepared for onward transit. It has the perfect location, providing easy access by sea, rail and road. Ramps and freight elevators ensure a fast turnaround of goods. 

Form follows function 

The functional, plain block designed by architect Oskar Pusch is inevitably a little short on aesthetic appeal. The building envelope is well insulated, with smooth brickwork on the outside and a 20-cm layer of cork cladding on the inside. There are no windows (except in the stairwell), no wall openings, no sunlight - because if any heat gets in, the energy consumption of the refrigerators and other machinery goes through the roof. The architect tries to brighten up the exterior by adding a coloured clinker facade, but the beauty of this imitation Gothic ornamentation is very much in the eye of the beholder. Don't be fooled by the glass frontage that you can see on both sides of the building. The glass was added during renovations in 2001 to try to break up the monotony of this brick monolith. The Universal Music Group moved into the building in 2002. At least they don't have to worry about sound insulation!
column12: The area around the building on the banks of the Spree is open to the public
column13: Sculptor Olaf Metzel uses the police barriers piled up between the former egg storage warehouse and the granary next door to create an installation called 13.4.1981. The sculpture is designed to commemorate the riots that broke out on the Kurfürstendamm in April 1981.

column8: The proletariat break down class barriers and simply build their own theatre
column11:
The people’s theatre brings education to the people
Rudolf Werner is a bag of nerves. He prowls up and down his dressing room. He knows his lines, his costume fits well - but he is racked with stage fright. Tonight is a special night. The actor is about to go on stage to play Götz von Berlichingen to celebrate the opening of the new Volksbühne people's theatre. "Long live freedom!" Goethe's words will soon be ringing out across the auditorium.

But, today of all days, a technical problem ruins plans for the opening of this state-of-the art theatre. The revolving stage isn't working. A last-minute decision is taken to perform When the Young Wine Blossoms by Björnstjerne Björnson instead. But this comedy from the company's repertoire doesn't really reflect the theatre's political stance.  

Take a close look at the building in front of you. Every single brick was paid for by workers' hard-earned pennies. The Freie Volksbühne association (Free People's Theatre) was established in Berlin in 1890. It was the first cultural/political organisation to be set up by working-class members, who scrimped and saved to build this temple of the theatre.  Their somewhat militant slogan was: "Bring art to the people!". 

These words written by Dr Bruno Wille in an article in the Berliner Volksblatt on 23 March 1890 led to the founding of the Freie Volksbühne. Wille and theatre director Otto Brahm were the driving force behind the new association. It had a clear aim: workers who are usually denied access to culture for financial reasons should be able to afford to enjoy the theatre and its educational benefits. The Freie Volksbühne initially puts on plays in private theatres that support the association's aims. It charges its members 50 pfennigs to go in. Members can enter a draw to win seats in a box or on the balcony. Class boundaries become blurred as the proletariat emancipates itself and appropriates the theatre culture of the bourgeoisie. 

One of the side effects is the promotion of contemporary works that criticise society  

One of the unique features of the Freie Volksbühne benefits contemporary authors such as Gerhard Hauptmann. The association's productions are classed as private events, so Prussian censors can't get their hands on the scripts. The police decide to send their informers in to spy on the radical cultural association. The authorities hear they are staging socially critical plays - tales of working-class life spoken in dialect, the language of the people.  

In 1912, the members of the association - which at its height number almost 160,000 - decide to build their own theatre. They appoint famous theatre architect Oskar Kaufmann, who helps them to build their own theatre under the most trying of circumstances. When the foundation stone is laid in September 1913, nobody imagines that it will be built while the First World War is raging. 

The 2,000-seat Volksbühne theatre is built in the heart of the poor Scheunenviertel district. The association's members are bringing theatre to the people.  

Götz von Berlichingen hits the stage in the New Year   

Rudolf Werner gets to play Götz a few days later. The local press is kind about the debacle on the opening night: "According to superstition, a little bad luck at the start of an undertaking is an omen of its future success." How right they are!
column12: For more information on this location, events and tickets, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/volksbuhne-am-rosa-luxemburg-platz">visit
column13: Over the last 100 years, the Volksbühne has had many homes. It was originally built on Bülowplatz then moved to Horst-Wessel-Platz during the Nazi dictatorship. It was located on Liebknechtplatz immediately after the war then moved to Luxemburgplatz in 1947. In 1969 it changed to its present location on Rosa-Luxemburg-Platz.

column1: Aroser Allee, Emmentaler Straße, Genfer Straße
column8: In north-west Berlin, three architects create a residential estate which, around the world, came to epitomise modernism.
column11:
Global symbol of modernism
The Weiße Stadt (White City), constructed in Reinickendorf from 1929 to 1931, belongs to the UNESCO six Berlin Modernism estates.

In the late 1920s, Martin Wagner, Berlin's chief urban planner, has a problem. He introduced a rent tax in 1924 to fund social housing. Now, with the economic situation rapidly worsening, revenues from the tax are falling. But he still has to build more residential housing - with an especially urgent need for small flats.

More space for experiments

Using 15 million Reichsmark from current budget resources, Wagner launches a special building fund. The rent tax funding always comes with conditions. But with the new fund, architects no longer have to adhere, for instance, to rooms of a specified size or a defined floor height. With more freedom in planning, this is an attractive project.

Wagner commissions three architects - Wilhelm Büning, Bruno Ahrends and Otto Rudolf Salvisberg - to construct over 1200 new apartments along Schillerpromenade (today's Aroser Allee) in the Reinickendorf district.

Yet despite the greater leeway in planning, the number one priority is still a cost-saving design. The simplest way to save money is to standardise all prefabricated structural elements such as doors, windows and staircases. The three architects also agree on 9.40 metres as the uniform depth of all the buildings.

One of these cost-saving measures also determines the appearance of the estate. With uniform plain white facades, the estate has a unique distinguishing feature. Very soon it is nicknamed the Weiße Stadt - the White City.

White houses in three variations

Salvisberg is responsible for the overall urban development of the estate. His plan foresees a network of communal green spaces amid a mix of block buildings fronting the streets and rows of houses. Salvisberg's bridge house across today's Aroser Allee forms the centre of the estate.

The estate's best-known image is still the view down this avenue. If you approach from Emmentaler Straße, you first see the gatehouse-like buildings designed by Ahrends. With their five storeys, they tower over the other buildings, giving the estate an almost fortress-like appearance.

On its four rows of columns, the 40-metre-wide bridge building by Otto Rudolf Salvisberg stands majestically in the centre of Aroser Allee. The reinforced concrete construction has a surprising elegance, seemingly almost suspended between the rows of houses to the right and left.

Architect Wilhelm Büning focuses primarily on plans for rows of houses, positioning the rows radially in a fan-shape between Genfer Straße and the Schillerring. His large framed windows for the stairwells are a conspicuous feature, while the broad coloured eaves set the roofs off from the white façades.

Shortly after completion, the Weiße Stadt is already viewed as a successful example of a modern housing estate. Photos of the white façades are published in the international press. Damage to the buildings during the Second World War is repaired under Wilhelm Büning from 1949 to 1954. In 2008, the Schillerpromenade estate is inscribed as UNESCO World Heritage.
column12:
When you visit the Weiße Stadt, you are visiting people's homes.
We would ask you to respect their privacy! Thank you!

For more information on this location, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/weisse-stadt-white-city
column13: The green spaces in the estate were designed by Ludwig Lesser, the landscape architect who also worked on the Falkenberg Garden City project. In the Weiße Stadt, though, rather than laying out gardens for tenants, he focuses on communal green spaces. generous areas with playgrounds for children and benches where adults can sit.

column8: A fascinatingly diverse ensemble of architecture, art and culture between Potsdamer Platz and the Landwehr Canal.
column11:
A meeting place for art, music and science
The Kulturforum has its roots in the West Berlin of the 1960s and 1970s - and in three buildings by two internationally renowned architects. Hans Scharoun's Philharmonie, opened in 1963, marked the start of a new development to the west of Potsdamer Platz. The concert hall's striking tent-like roof and golden façade contrast sharply with Ludwig Mies van der Rohe's functional form and clear lines for the Neue Nationalgalerie (New National Gallery) opened five years later.

Looking around the open spaces at the heart of the Kulturforum, you can't help but notice the nineteenth-century St. Mathew's Church - very much a building from a different era.

A diversity of the arts

In the early 1970s, Hans Scharoun designs the Berlin State Library - the Staatsbibliothek - which opens in 1978 on the other side of Potsdamer Straße. The library, together with the neighbouring building housing the Ibero-American Institute (IAI), belongs to Scharoun's major works only finished after his death in 1972. With costs for work on constructing the State Library spiralling, the other building projects on the Kulturforum are put on hold.

It is some time before Edgar Wisniewski, who worked with Scharoun for many years, can finally oversee the construction of the Museum of Musical Instruments and the Chamber Music Hall, both based on Scharoun's original plans. The museum opens in 1984 and the Chamber Music Hall three years later in 1987 - punctually for Berlin's 750th anniversary celebrations.

The changing face of museum architecture 

The Kulturform, set so close to the Wall, is a prestige project for West Berlin. It has a twofold aim - not just setting a new benchmark in the constant competition with the GDR, but also sending out a clear message to West Germany. Many art works and literature archives were taken out of Berlin for safe storage during the war. Now, though, their return is slow and sporadic. With this series of high-profile buildings, West Berlin hopes to add to the pressure to accelerate the process.

As early as 1965, West Berlin announces an international architectural competition for the entire Kulturforum. The expectations are high. The winning design should do nothing less than "define the architectural essence of what a museum means for us today".

In the jury's view, none of the plans realise this ambitious goal. Finally, they agree on the work of Stuttgart architect Rolf Gutbrot as a compromise solution.

His plans date from a time of questioning the tasks and functions of museum architecture. How do a museum and the collection it houses mutually influence one another? Which target groups are to be addressed?

Gutbrodt sees his designs as a deliberate contrast to the neo-classicist and neo-baroque museums on East Berlin's Museum Island. Rather than intimidating visitors, his museums are intended to attract people from all walks of life.

By 1985, when the Museum of Decorative Arts (Kunstgewerbemuseum) opens, the design envisaged twenty years before seems outdated. Public reaction is muted, while the most outspoken critics condemn the building as a "concrete bunker". Criticism reaches such a pitch that Gutbrod is taken off projects for the other new buildings at the Kulturforum. Yet again, it seems there is no clear plan for the Kulturforum's future.

Then Munich architects Heinz Hilmer and Christoph Sattler are commissioned to overhaul Gutbrod's designs for the Museum of Graphic Arts and the Art Library. They change numerous details, for instance, removing the exposed concrete pillars in the exhibition hall. The museum and Art Library are opened in 1994. Today, the façade with its concrete and clinker brink cladding seems empathically low-key.

Hilmer and Sattler also designed the Gemäldegalerie, which houses an outstanding collection of European art from the thirteenth to the eighteenth century. In their plan, rather than creating prestige facades, they focused on the quality of the interior design. Their generous exhibition rooms with perfect lighting allow visitors to enjoy the Gemäldegalerie's exquisite collection to the full.
column12: For more information on events and tickets, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/kulturforum
column13: Presently closed for renovation, the Neue Nationalgalerie is scheduled to reopen in 2020. That same year, the Museum of the Twentieth Century, planned nearby, is also due to open its doors. This new building set between the Philharmonie concert hall and the Neue Nationalgalerie provides a permanent showcase for the National Gallery's holdings and, architecturally, further articulates the Kulturforum's spatial structure.

column7: Museum of Otto Weidt’s Workshop for the Blind
column8: Jewish men and women are saved by making brooms and brushes in Otto Weidt's Workshop for the Blind
column11:
Righteous Among the Nations
27 February 1943, Rosenthaler Straße 39. Gestapo trucks are parked in front of a workshop for brushes and brooms. The Jewish workers, most blind and deaf, climb into the trucks and are whisked away. Otto Weidt, the owner of a small factory workshop, is furious. Shortly afterwards, he is ready to leave. His destination - the Gestapo's Department of Jewish Affairs.

The afternoon of the same day, passers-by see a very odd spectacle. Around 50 men and women are walking down Rosenthaler Straße towards the workshop for brooms and brushes. The group is led by Otto Weidt. Just like the others, he is almost blind. Later, writer Inge Deutschkron recalls, "It was like a scene from an ancient tragedy."  She also works for Otto Weidt. Just as he has several times before, he manages to convince the Gestapo of how vital his workers are for the war effort.  

Freedom for a time 

Brushes and brooms can save lives. At the start of the war, they are declared essential to the war effort. The Wehrmacht, the German army, is one of the largest clients of Otto Weidt's little broom factory. For a long time, he can protect his blind workers, many of them Jews, from Nazi persecution. He brings many of his workers here from factories with brutal and inhumane conditions. In his workshop, they can demonstrate their skills - and survive.  

On an old photograph, Otto Weidt is sitting surrounded by his employees. They call him "Papa Weidt". Otto Weidt is a pacifist. He loathes the Nazis - and wants to help the people they persecute. 

During Hitler's dictatorship, more than 1700 Jews survive underground in Berlin - thanks to helpers such as Otto Weidt. These helpers become known as "Silent Heroes". Today, Otto Weidt is also honoured in Yad Vashem as Righteous Among the Nations.  

The survivors hidden in Berlin include later journalist and author Inge Deutschkron. Down the years, apart from her work as a writer, Inge Deutschkron gives many talks in schools to keep alive the awareness of the persecution and murder of the European Jews. In the late 1990s, when a group of students discover the empty rooms of Otto Weidt's old workshop by chance, Inge Deutschkron immediately wants to help. With her support, an exhibition is held in these historic rooms.  

A cupboard as a refuge 

As you come into the exhibition, the floorboards creak at every step. The workshop is one small room after another. The last room seems to end with a cupboard against the wall. But carry on! Behind the cupboard door built on at the front, there's a secret doorway to another room. Without windows in the room, the atmosphere is oppressive. For many months, this is where Otto Weidt hides all four members of the Horn family. At that time, a cupboard with a double door stands in front of the little box room. It is a safe hiding place - until an informer betrays him to the Gestapo. In October 1943, the Horn family is arrested during a raid on the workshop. A little later, they are murdered in Auschwitz. This time, they are beyond Otto Weidt's help.
column12:
Opening hours:
Monday - Friday 10.00-20.00 Uhr

For more information on this location, events and tickets, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/museum-blindenwerkstatt-otto-weidt
column13: The postcard does not have a stamp - there are no stamps on the train to Auschwitz. "If you find this postcard, please put it in the letter box. Thank you." The postcard is from Alice Licht, Otto Weidt's secretary and helper. By a miracle, her postcard reaches Otto Weidt. When she escapes, Weidt manages to help her. Alice Licht survives. Today, her postcard is on show in the museum.

column8: Berlin hangs onto a masterpiece of street art ­- by replanting it
column11:
The story of a mural
4 May 2018. Ben Wagin is overjoyed as he watches a group of young artists standing on scaffolding recreating his mural Weltbaum (World Tree). They are painting it on the end of a building in Lehrter Straße in Berlin's Moabit district. The longest branch reaches 20 metres towards the sky. The artists are relocating one of Berlin's most famous pieces of graffiti. The original is three kilometres away and about to disappear behind a new building. Street art is ephemeral. But it's also spontaneous and flexible.

The performance artist Ben Wagin was born Bernhard Wargin in 1930 and has lived in Berlin since 1957. His artistic career began with the construction of the Wall. He began planting trees all over the city and became known as the "godfather of trees". His trees can be found in front of ministries, theatres and museums, but his art always has a political flavour.  

A pioneer of the modern street art scene 

On 9 November 1990, Wagin creates an installation called The Parliament of Trees on the former border strip. He dedicates the trees to the victims of the Berlin Wall. They commemorate the division of Germany and the struggle for German unity.  

Ben Wagin likes to plant ginkgo trees and, so far, has planted more than 50,000 all over the world. With his art and other projects, he is trying to make people think about the relationship between mankind and nature.  

He also paints, including his now famous Weltbaum mural in Berlin, which he created in 1975. At that time, words like street art and graffiti hadn't yet been invented and no-one talked about murals. Wagin created one of Berlin's first large-scale murals. He's a pioneer, a role model for future generations of street artists. And every day, tens of thousands of Berlin's residents and visits see his art as they travel around the city.  

Passengers can look out of the window at Tiergarten S-Bahn station and admire Weltbaum I - Grün ist Leben. It adorns the wall of Siegmunds Hof 21, on the corner of Bachstraße. The tree screams in agony as exhaust gases from the machine beneath choke it to death. A barge sails across the top of the picture. It is loaded with trees - a gloomy vision of the future. We are destroying our natural world.  

A tree is on the move 

The Weltbaum in Tiergarten is getting on in years and the paint is starting to fade. But it's still a shock for the artist when he discovers that the tree is going to be covered over by a new building. A high-rise office building is going up on the empty plot in front of the mural. The tree has disappeared from view. There's just a narrow gap between the new building and the painting.  

It's time for a change - why not relocate the tree? In spring 2018 the Weltbaum is moved from Tiergarten to its new home in Moabit.
column13: In 1933, many artists live in the area around Savignyplatz, including the poet Mascha Kaléko, painter Georg Grosz and writer Else Ury. Another Weltbaum by Ben Wagin at the Savignyplatz S-Bahn station is a reminder of key events in German history and, above all, acts as a memorial to the Berlin Jews who were persecuted at the hands of the Nazis.

column8: Spy crossing, escape route, central checkpoint, duty-free heaven - this is a station like no other
column11:
A gap in the Iron Curtain
When you stand on the busy platform at Friedrichstraße station it's hard to imagine that this was formerly the border between East and West Berlin. The rumble of the incoming trains, the clang of the doors as they close - everything's so normal. But between 1961 and 1989 things were very different.

The station is known as a super checkpoint - and with good reason. It is watched by Stasi surveillance cameras and patrolling border guards.  

Next stop: Freedom     

It provides a relatively easy way for visitors from West Berlin to travel into the Eastern sector. But anyone who steps onto the platform on the East Berlin side has already endured a series of humiliating checks before finally being allowed to leave. Locals call the station the Tränenpalast, the Palace of Tears, because it has seen so many tearful goodbyes. It's a strange place where you leave your family behind - but freedom beckons. 

Border crossing for spies and stowaways  

Every day, spies mingle with the bustling crowds. This is where they can move between the two sectors. Informers for the East German regime avoid the checkpoints by passing through a small glass pavilion on the corner of Friedrichstraße and Reichstagsufer.  

17-year-old Karl-Heinz Richter is also dreaming of sneaking across the border. This high school student is one of a small group of teenagers who have discovered a gap in the border fence on the railway line. One by one, they attempt their escape by climbing onto the bridge and hiding in an alcove until the Moscow to Paris Express passes by. The train drivers are instructed to pull out of the station as fast as they can to prevent stowaways from leaping on, but just a few metres further on they have slowed again. This allows nine boys to leap onto the steps of the train and smuggle themselves across the border. 

Press coverage in the West, punishment in the East   

Even the Western press picks up the story and reports on the schoolboys' escape. It is 30th January 1964. Karl-Heinz and his friend Frankie have thought of everything - except the two border guards who are having a cigarette break directly beneath their hiding place. When they move away, the boys manage to hop onto the footboard of the very last carriage. But Karl-Heinz slips, falls off and can only stare after the receding red lights of the train as it carries Frankie off to freedom. In his desperate flight from the border guards, he breaks both legs, several ribs and an arm - and in the end is arrested, despite his severe injuries. He spends many months in a Stasi prison, and is finally granted permission to leave East Germany in 1975.   

By then, Friedrichstraße station had been fortified still further in order to prevent any more escape attempts.
column13: Cheap schnaps, cigarettes, chocolates - the Intershops in the station tempt visitors from West Berlin with duty-free products that they can buy without having to go through East German border controls. It's a nice little earner for the socialist system. With an annual turnover close to 80 million West German marks (1977), the regime decides to allow a little capitalism.

column8: The Soviet memorials hold the graves of thousands of Red Army soldiers - but they look like a film set
column11:
Buried far from home
On the morning of 30 April 1945, shots rip through the air near Potsdam Bridge. The final battle for Berlin is raging in the city centre. A little girl cowers helplessly next to a dead Red Cross nurse. 23-year-old Soviet soldier Nikolai Ivanovich Massalov screws up his courage, crawls to the bridge and rescues the crying child from the hail of bullets.

It's not unusual for heroes to be recognised for their courage - but the honour bestowed on Sergeant of the Guard Massalov takes on a whole new dimension. The story of his daring act reaches Yevgeny Vuchetich, whom the Soviet military administration commissions in 1946 to create a memorial to the fallen Soviet soldiers. After hearing the story, the sculptor decides to create a massive statue of a Red Army soldier carrying a child in his arms.  

A Red Army soldier standing over a broken swastika  

The memorial in Treptower Park is inaugurated on 8 May 1949, the fourth anniversary of the end of war. All eyes are drawn to the huge statue inspired by the heroic deed at Potsdam Bridge. Vuchetich's soldier stands on a high pedestal on the mausoleum hill - the imposing bronze figure is 30 metres tall. With his sword lowered and a shattered swastika beneath his boots, the statue symbolises victory over the Nazis and the hope of a future lived in freedom. 

Covering some 100,000 square metres, the main Soviet War Memorial in Treptower Park is the largest in Germany, but it was not the first to be built. A memorial was constructed in the Tiergarten in November 1945, and the Schönholzer Heide and Buch memorials in Pankow were erected in 1947. All four complexes also house war cemeteries. Around 80,000 Red Army soldiers were killed in the battle for Berlin, and more than 20,000 have found their final resting place at one of these four memorials. 

Like a film set  

The Tiergarten, Treptow and Schönholzer Heide memorials are all built in a monumental style and reflect the grandiose stylistic ideals of Soviet realism. The sheer size of the memorial in Treptower Park is perhaps the most obvious example of this aesthetic. With its arched entrances, huge flags carved from red granite and an impressive view of Vuchetich's colossal statue, the complex looks like a set for a film about the Soviet era.  

Today, more than 70 years after it was built, the huge statue still amazes visitors from all over the world. We still don't know the name of the girl who is immortalised in the arms of the bronze soldier. Her saviour, Nikolai Ivanovich Massalov, died on 10 December 2001 in Kemerovo, Siberia.
column12: For more information on this location, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/soviet-memorial-treptow
column13: Sculptor Yevgeny Vuchetich is inspired by the story of the soldier Nikolai Ivanovich Massalov, but the statue itself is modelled on another Red Army soldier: Ivan Odarchenko. 60 years later, Odarchenko once again serves as a model, this time for a veterans' memorial in Tambov. In this statue, the bronze warrior holds a girl in his lap.

column8: "Roll up, roll up!" It costs just a few pennies to enjoy all the fun of the fair
column11:
Uncle Pelle’s funfair
Fabian, the protagonist of Erich Kästner's novel of the same name, sets out on an "adventure" in Wedding, a poor, working-class district of Berlin. There's not a lot to see in Wedding, so Fabian visits the Nordpark funfair in Müllerstraße. Nordpark is squeezed into a gap "between old, solid tenement buildings", writes Erich Kästner. When he gets there, it's in "semi-darkness", the paths are "sticky" and many of the attractions are shoddy or not even running. It's true that Fabian meets a woman with whom he is destined to have a brief fling, but the trip to the funfair is not exactly an exciting adventure. The prevailing mood is one of sadness.

Nordpark is portrayed quite differently in Curt Moreck's Führer durch das lasterhafte Berlin, a guide to "naughty" Berlin. He describes Nordpark as a "meeting place and stomping ground for pleasure-seekers, a piece of real Berlin."  Another travel guide says: "Give the people of Berlin their funfair and they're happy, they find everything 'knorke'.  That's Berlin slang for 'awesome'! 

In the 1920s, funfairs are popular with people on low incomes. They can be found in all of Berlin's poorer, working-class districts. In July 1925 Nordpark offers a riding track called the Hippodrome, sideshows, a swing ride, a carousel, shooting galleries and a wheel of fortune with sausages as prizes. Funfairs are particularly popular with children and teenagers. 

A harmless pleasure?  

But many journalists and child welfare organisations think they are anything but harmless. A broad alliance of educationalists, clergymen, youth welfare workers, social workers and police are united in their opposition to funfairs, calling them hotbeds of vice, squalor and immorality. They are particularly enraged by the games of chance and sideshow attractions. For their part, the showmen defend the entertainment they offer, saying the criticism reflects the paternalism and arrogance of the cultural elites. 

A harmless clown? 

The Nordpark is particularly popular with children, because its operator, Adolf Rautmann, is the creator of the much-loved clown Uncle Pelle. He delights younger guests at local festivals and fairs. Indeed, the Uncle Pelle character is so successful that Adolf Rautmann protects it by patent. Once the patent expires, other clowns carry on using the name Uncle Pelle until the Fifties.  

Adolf Rautmann is not just a clown; he's also a businessman. He runs several fairgrounds and entertainment venues in Berlin and works hard to defend the interests of Berlin's showmen. But even seemingly harmless clowns have their political views. Adolf Rautmann was a card-carrying National Socialist from the early 1930s.
column13: Uncle Pelle's trademark is a one-metre-long sausage as thick as your arm. One end of the sausage is tightly stuffed so that he can swing it around and use it like a truncheon. At the other end, the sausage is floppy, an empty skin. This is where Uncle Pelle gets his name - Pelle is the German word for skin.

column8: How Rainer Eppelmann goes from being public enemy no. 1 to a minister in the GDR's last cabinet
column11:
The world’s one-and-only disarmament minister
Rainer Eppelmann is going to die. It's been decided. A little tampering with his car followed by a fake accident - the Ministry for State Security has the assassination all planned out. The drama unfolds in the mid-1980s when Eppelmann, the pastor at the Church of the Good Samaritan, is driving his Trabant over a crossroads in East Berlin. A car pulls out in front of him and the collision causes Rainer Eppelmann to fly head first through the windscreen.

A few years earlier, young people are dancing to blues music in the Church of the Good Samaritan in Friedrichshain. Someone is reading from the Bible, everyone feels free to enjoy themselves. It's not quite the normal image of the German Democratic Republic. But the Blues Masses held by the Samaritan church in East Berlin, are something special. They have been going on since 1979, giving young people a chance to escape the restrictions of living in the GDR - at least for the duration of the service. It's all thanks to their organiser, Rainer Eppelmann.  

He is not only the pastor at the Church of the Good Samaritan but also a committed pacifist, conscientious objector and member of the opposition movement in his community. He is not one to mince his words when it comes to political grievances. He has been a thorn in the side of the East German regime for years. When he publishes his Berlin Appeal in 1982 calling for disarmament in both East and West it's seen as a milestone along the road to peaceful revolution - and Eppelmann is now considered an enemy of the state. 

A tradition of rebellion 

Even during the days of National Socialism, the Church of the Good Samaritan is at the heart of the opposition movement based around the Confessing Church's Emergency Covenant of Pastors. Under the GDR the church becomes a nucleus of the peace movement and the birthplace of one the country's largest opposition groups. This is all helped along by the popular Blues Masses.  

And Rainer Eppelmann? He breaks several vertebrae in his neck but survives the crash. He is slowly recovering when his career takes an unexpected turn. In May 1989, his church's Peace Circle takes part in a campaign to expose electoral fraud during municipal elections in East Germany. After the fall of the Berlin Wall, Eppelmann becomes one of the founding members of Democratic Awakening (DA), a political party that merges with the CDU in 1990. 

"We had won"

Following the first and last free elections to the GDR People's Chamber on 18 March 1990, Eppelmann becomes the country's first Minister for Disarmament and Defence. One of his main tasks is the dissolution of the National People's Army - a source of great satisfaction to a pacifist like Eppelmann.  He remains in office from 12 April to 2 October 1990 and to this day, Rainer Eppelmann is the only disarmament minister the world has ever seen.  

Today Eppelmann lives in Berlin and is chairman of the Federal Foundation for the Study of Communist Dictatorship in East Germany. In an interview in 2009, he talks of the moment he appeared before the GDR's generals in his new role as minister of disarmament: "...that was the first time it really hit home: we had won".
column13: Rainer Eppelmann's son Martin is also a familiar figure in the GDR. As a teenager he regularly annoys the People's Police with his punk outfits, and he likes to disagree with his teachers in civics class. Today, Martin Eppelmann works as a detective in the Berlin police force - "one of the good guys", as he's at pains to stress.

column8: Bethanien Hospital has been the scene of many struggles for freedom
column11:
A turbulent history of freedom
When you approach the former Bethanien Hospital from Muskauer Straße, you might think you're entering a Disney fairy-tale. But, in fact, the building has had a turbulent history since it was built between 1845 and 1847. It has been the scene of many struggles for freedom and independence.

It started life as a Central Deaconess Institute and Hospital commissioned by King Frederick William IV of Prussia. It was always said that the King "only wants to build churches", which should be "islands of promise", but with the new hospital in Köpenick, the monarch sent a signal that public health was also important to him in the industrial age. 

In the mid-19th century, Bethanien was set amongst gardens and rye fields - "surrounded by greenery", which was just how His Majesty liked it. His royal preferences were also reflected in the building's architecture. Today, the imposing entrance hall looks more like a church than a hospital. The hospital housed 500 beds, a nursing school and an orphanage.  

Barbarism or freedom?  

But just a year later, the bloody March Revolution reaches this haven of tranquillity. Theodor Fontane, a pharmacist in Bethanien at the time, notes: "... the very day I moved into Bethanien, the militias were fighting on the Köpenick fields, then the people stormed the armoury, and there were alternating calls of 'The Russians are coming' and 'The Poles are coming'. The former were synonymous with the collapse of barbarism, the latter with the establishment of freedom." 

In 1933, the deaconesses are put to the test when the National Socialists try to turn the management of the hospital over to members of their party. But the deaconesses fight back and maintain their independence. Eight years later, the establishment is placed under the authority of the National Socialists' welfare organisation, but time is already running out. Bethanien is badly damaged during the Second World War.  

The battle for Bethanien continues 

The reconstruction work lasts until 1966, but things are rapidly going downhill. The hospital's location close to the sector border means patients no longer come from East Berlin. It closes down in 1970, but the fight for Bethanien is not over. Now there are plans to tear down this magnificent complex. The building is saved after massive protests by conservationists and public campaigns. In 1969, the complex is listed as a historical monument.  

On 19 December 1971, after a concert by the rock group Ton Steine Scherben, squatters move into the nurses' home, the Martha-Maria-Haus. They rename it the Georg-von-Rauch-Haus after a Berlin anarchist and urban guerrilla who had been killed in a confrontation with police the previous year.  

After much debate, the Berlin Senate finally approves the squatters' legal right to occupy the building. In 1973, artists' groups manage to turn Bethanien itself into a centre for cultural and social projects.  

In 2005, the Yorck59 Group occupies the south wing of Bethanien to prevent the sale of the complex to a private investor. Some 25 social and cultural groups currently use the Bethanien site. We can assume that the deaconesses' former hospital will see many more struggles for freedom in the future.
column13: The rock band Ton Steine Scherben is involved in the occupation of the Rauch-Haus. The band's singer, Rio Reiser writes the Rauch-Haus-Song during its occupation. It becomes one of the group's best-known songs with lyrics that celebrate the squatter scene: "You can't get us out of here! This is our house!"

column8: The former upper chamber of the Prussian parliament now houses the Bundesrat, where representatives of Germany's federal states meet to debate legislation
column11:
The voice of the federal states in Berlin
A fleet of limousines pulls up in front of the Bundesrat building. Blue and pink hydrangeas are surrounded by immaculate box hedges. But the Federal Council members have no time to admire the beautiful Baroque-inspired courtyard. Many of them have had long journeys to Berlin from every corner of Germany. The plenary session begins on the dot of half past nine, the first since the two-month summer break. Michael Müller, Governing Mayor of Berlin and current President of the Bundesrat, welcomes his colleagues. There are more than 50 items on the agenda for 21 September 2018.

"The most perfect work of art is the creation of political freedom."  It is with these words that Konrad Adenauer opens the first meeting of the Bundesrat in Bonn in 1949.  

A clear lesson has been learned from National Socialism. It is vital to prevent the re-emergence of a centralised power that neutralises politics and sweeps aside democracy and freedom. The Bundesrat is an important instrument here, as it represents the federal system that underpins Germany's 16 federal states. It acts as an important bridge between the country's federal and state governments.  

The Bundesrat has 69 members, including the minister-presidents or mayors of the various states. The main task of this constitutional body is to participate in the legislative process. Hundreds of laws pass through the Bundesrat every year.  

Moving to Berlin 

Shortly after reunification, the Bundesrat members decide to continue sitting in Bonn. But they soon realise they have made a mistake. If it is to work effectively, the Bundesrat needs to be close to other federal institutions. The decision is revoked - it's time to move to Berlin. 

The Bundesrat moves into the building that once housed the upper chamber of the Prussian parliament in Leipziger Straße. The arrival of this institution breathes new life into the building, which is in the shadow of the Berlin Wall and has stood empty for many years. 

The GDR only used parts of the building, with the foyer serving as a kitchen and the plenary chamber as a storage area. In the year 2000, after many years of renovation work, it finally opens its doors to Members and tour groups. 

The Three Graces 

When you visit the Bundesrat building, your first port of call is the foyer. Three women set the tone here: The Three Graces. This is the name of Rebecca Horn's art installation. These particular Graces come in the shape of pointed staves made of gold-coloured brass hanging down form three dome-shaped openings in the ceiling. The Graces are in constant motion and, the artist explains, act as a link between interior and exterior, above and below. A little reminder for the politicians within?  

Governing Mayor of Berlin Michael Müller has brought the sitting to a close. The work will be continued in the numerous committees and the Council will meet again in a month's time.
column12:
Opening hours:
Guided tours only
Tour times: Monday - Friday, 8.30 am, 9.45am,
11.45am, 1.45pm, 2.30pm and 3.45pm

For more information on this location, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/bundesrat-building
column13: The Bundesrat gained some new members in the spring of 2016. A fox family with five young decided to move into the building's courtyard and the garden shared by the Bundesrat, the Federal Ministry of Finance and the Berlin House of Representatives. Every now and then the foxes can be seen venturing out onto busy Leipziger Straße.

column8: The building that once housed Germany's dictators now provides a window on the world
column11:
A ministry with a dark history
Joschka Fischer, Germany's first Green Foreign Minister, is holding a gold-plated key. On 19 January 2000, he is symbolically handed the key to the building on Werderscher Markt. Those present gaze at the wood panelling and the luminous ceiling of the Weltsaal, the World Hall. They both date back to the 1930s. Yes, it's true - the Foreign Minister of the new Berlin Republic is based in a building erected by the National Socialists. The relocation of the ministries from Bonn to Berlin after reunification posed some problems for the German government.

In 1991, the decision is made - Germany's federal government is to move from Bonn to Berlin. But where will all the ministries be housed? Civil servants pore over their city maps on the hunt for new premises. The Federal Foreign Office would like to have a prestigious new building, perhaps in the Ministergärten, the green space in the centre of Berlin. But space and budgets are tight.  

The move needs to be professionally managed, so Environment Minister Klaus Töpfer is appointed as relocation officer in 1995. He assigns the Foreign Office an old building on Werderscher Markt. Of all ministries, it is to be the Foreign Office, the one that represents Germany worldwide, that is to move into a building built by the Nazis.   

Tackling history head-on 

You're standing outside the Foreign Office's hall of records. Government limousines and a motorcycle escort are standing by as the gates can open at any time. 

The large sandstone building on the banks of the Spree has had many occupants over the years. The National Socialists built it as the Reichsbank, and this is where they stored the gold that supported the war economy. A little later, it was occupied by the Central Committee of the Socialist Unity Party of Germany (SED). This is where General Secretaries Walter Ulbricht and Erich Honecker decided on GDR policy. The SED's massive party emblem was removed from the façade in 1990.
