In 1936, Bonhoeffer is forbidden to work as a teacher. This is soon followed by a ban on publishing and public speaking. He is also banned from staying in Berlin. Several times he has the chance to flee Germany. But he stays with his parish, even though he knows his efforts for freedom can cost him his life.  

Through Hans von Dohnanyi, a schoolfriend and later his brother-in-law, Dietrich Bonhoeffer is enlisted by the disaffected Abwehr military counter-intelligence unit headed by Admiral Canaris. There, he comes into contact with groups in the German military resistance. He cultivates contacts to the Kreisau Circle of dissidents around Helmuth von Moltke. In 1941 and 1942, Bonhoeffer travels to Norway, Sweden and Switzerland as a courier for the resistance. As a representative of the resistance against Hitler, his task is to contact the Allies abroad. In 1943, Bonhoeffer is entangled in an attempt to assassinate Hitler by the group around Admiral Canaris.  

The Gestapo uncover the conspiracy, arresting Bonhoeffer and his brother-in-law Hans von Dohnanyi for sedition and subversion of the war effort. 

In prison, Bonhoeffer writes many poems, including Stations on the Way to Freedom. Freedom means daring to do what is right, and taking up responsibility - and it transcends the private sphere. Bonhoeffer also calls for direct political action since "mere waiting and looking on is not Christian behaviour". 

In 1944, since he is classified as a "personal prisoner of Hitler", Bonhoeffer is interrogated at the Gestapo headquarters in Prinz-Albrecht-Straße. He is sent to Buchenwald and then to Flossenbürg concentration camp. Shortly before the end of the war, he is summarily court-martialled and sentenced to death. The sentence is carried out on the morning of 9 April 1945. As a final humiliation, he and the other condemned prisoners have to walk out naked to the gallows.
column12:
Opening hours: 
Wednesday to Saturday 1pm - 6pm
Sunday 11am - 4pm
column13: In his prison letters, Dietrich Bonhoeffer explains his vision of a church in future without state privileges, supporting the poor and fighting for social change. Although this vision is not part of past-war Europe, it resonates with the church in South Africa under apartheid and in Latin American liberation theology.

column8: Under the GDR regime, Wolf Biermann's apartment becomes a magnet for free thinkers
column11:
Wolf Biermann finds freedom within his own four walls
Chausseestraße 131, 1968. Wolf Biermann sings and yells into the microphone: "I've had enough!" The songwriter directs his typically angry, sarcastic lyrics at opportunists, cowards and bureaucrats. Behind him, a tape recorder is running. This is Biermann's home, but it is also his recording studio and a rare bastion of true freedom in a world of state socialism.

In the late 1960s, Biermann finds himself under enormous pressure from the East German regime. The state has effectively banned the lyricist, singer and composer of political songs from working. Biermann is not allowed to perform or publish his songs. His lyrics are too accurate, his criticisms too pointed, his satire too caustic and creative. The regime decides to muzzle him.  

Barred from professional recording studios, he starts recording his first album at home. He smuggles in a top-quality Sennheiser microphone, which picks up the sound of trams and Trabants driving by. This would normally be a musician's nightmare, but here it acts as a perfect time capsule. The street sounds in the background are a charming reminder of how, in the GDR, criticism can only be articulated behind closed doors.  

Biermann's LP Chausseestraße 131 is eventually released in West Germany. Later on, the singer comments: "The title should have been: This particular Bierman is banned in the East, (...) but it's not like he's actually in hiding, he has a name and address in Berlin, easy to find for both friend and foe". 

For many years, his apartment was as a meeting place for the intellectual opposition, and attracted Western celebrities such as Udo Lindenberg, Heinrich Böll, Rudi Dutschke and Joan Baez. But Biermann's closest confidant and most regular visitor was Robert Havemann. During the Third Reich, Havemann worked for Communist International's intelligence service and was a founding member of the European Union - not today's organisation, but a Berlin-based antifascist resistance group. He was arrested and sentenced to death in 1943 but was never actually executed.  

In the GDR, Havemann quickly became a leading critic of the regime and a friend and mentor to Wolf Biermann. But their time together in Chausseestraße came to an abrupt end. After his concert in Cologne on 13 November 1976, the GDR expelled the songwriter and banned him from returning to East Berlin. At a stroke, Biermann had lost his friend Havemann and his legendary home.
column13: Opponents of the East German regime speak freely when they visit Biermann's home - yet they all know that the Stasi have bugged the apartment. Later, Biermann describes Chausseestraße 131 as a "grubby Stasi-ridden hole" (2) and in his Stasi Ballad he mocks the state spies who have to listen to his foul language and sexual escapades.

column8: Long before Disneyland, tens of thousands enjoy a day out in Berlin's Luna Park.
column11:
Amusement park at Halensee lake
In early September 1928, the Berlin police hold their summer festival in the Luna Park. They also offer a special competition, open to everyone keen on testing their own detective skills. At the entrance, visitors are given a flyer describing three wanted men. The task is to find these three men in the festival crowds - and win a top prize of a stately 1000 Marks.

To enter the Luna Park, you first pass the monumental entrance gate on Kurfürstendamm boulevard. Then you follow a narrow colonnade down towards the main restaurant - the Terraces at Halensee. From the tower at the Terraces, you have a panoramic view of the amusement park's attractions.

Spoilt for choice

While visitors try to spot the three wanted men, they can enjoy a wide range of rides and amusements - from bumper cars to little boats on a water slide into Halensee lake, or dancing to jazz music. On the Devil's Wheel, a spinning circular platform, the riders slide off as its speed gradually increases, or you can wobble your way down the Shimmy Staircase, divided into two offset tiers of shaking stairs. Visitors can also enjoy concerts, eat in the Terraces restaurant or carouse to their heart's content in the Bavarian village. The highlight of the evening's entertainment is a firework display.

An amusement park needs a varied programme to regularly draw the crowds. Every year, the Luna Park management offer new, sensational attractions. In summer 1924, for instance, the amusement park launches a prize draw - with top prizes including cars and even a house in the country. In 1926, the Luna Park boasts an escalator - one of the first in Berlin. That same summer, the amusement park also hosts a boxing match won by Max Schmeling, then unknown but later world heavyweight champion. At Luna Park, Schmeling needs just three minutes to win by a knock-out. In 1927, the big attraction is a wave pool. The Luna Pool is Berlin's first fun and wave pool, but also a venue for serious competitions. In summer 1928, the wooden roller-coaster is given its most modern setting - a skyscraper city.

"Who are these three men?"

As newspapers report, the police summer festival attracts thousands of visitors - though crowds of that size are not an exception at the Luna Park. In warm summer weather and with their special events, the amusement park often draws crowds of 50,000 to 60,000. The main restaurant can serve over 7,000 guests at any one time. With such teeming crowds and a wealth of attractions, no one manages to identify all three of the wanted men. But at least one visitor goes away as a happy second place winner. The prize is awarded in the presence of the Wilhelm Abegg, State Secretary of the Interior, and Bernhard Weiß, Berlin's deputy Chief Constable.

In autumn 1933, the Luna Park closes its gates for the last time. Today, the amusement park on Halensee lake has disappeared without trace - and not solely due to poor business decisions. Luna Park certainly suffered after the global economic crisis, but it was also on a site in the way of the Nazi regime's bombastic urban masterplan. If you visit Halensee today, you can see the result of that plan from the Trabener Steg - thousands of cars roaring past where once thousands celebrated.
column13: Like all other amusement parks, the Luna Park was closed in the First World War. As the local Berliner Tagblatt newspaper noted, it was put to a "serious use in the war years". Some buildings housed wounded soldiers, while the Terraces kitchens produced cans of tinned food for the German troops.

column8: Le Corbusier wants to lead Berlin into the modern age. But his visionary residential complex remains one of a kind
column11:
Life in a “machine for living”
Charles Edouard Jeanneret-Gris, better known as Le Corbusier, thought it would all turn out very differently. The original plan was for Le Corbusier to build a flagship residential unit here on the edge of Grunewald - a Berlin version of his "unité d'habitation". It would be a first for Berlin, a high-rise building with a truly modern approach to living. But the building ends up being a shadow of its original design.

At first glance, the new Cubist building bears similarities to other designs by the famous Swiss architect, who was responsible for the French contribution to the Interbau International Building Exhibition. But by the time the topping-out ceremony is held in the summer of 1958, it's clear that many of Corbusier's architectural principles have fallen by the wayside. There's no roof garden with an open-air theatre. The room height has soared to 2.65 metres, and there's no sign of his usual long, horizontal windows. German building regulations and the need to save money have taken their toll.  

Tenement or architectural landmark?  

What remains of Corbusier's original ideas are his favoured concrete columns and open-plan layouts. Even before the building is finished, the local press are calling it "Berlin's largest tenement building at Interbau". West Berlin struggles to come to terms with the colossus, which is due to contain 500 apartments. Yet the city is proud to be working with such an eminent architect, whose building is meant to be a response to the Socialist Classicism that is rampant in East Berlin. Architecture is just another front in the battle between the two political ideologies.  

But that's of little concern to the first occupants of the 17-storey block. They're just happy to enjoy the amenities - panoramic views, a row of shops on the ground floor with a post office, hairdresser, doctors' surgeries and a grocery store that even delivers to their door. 

Idea or ideology?  

Le Corbusier is particularly keen to lighten the burden on housewives: "Freed from the heavy burden of housework and childcare, families will lead happy lives in my building. There will be no quarrels between neighbours and no divorces." However, he is not a proponent of women's rights. He still believes a woman's place is in the home, and his aim is solely to relieve them of some of their household chores.   

Corbusier is clear that his huge, angular buildings are not designed to be creative refuges for the individual. He is seeking solutions for the masses. That's why he invented the Modulor, a standard scale for a building's proportions. It is based on an ideal body height of 1.83 metres and a navel height of 1.13 metres. He used this to calculate the ceiling heights for this building - 2.26 metres.  

The fact that the basic principles of his "machines for living" work on paper but not in practice is of little interest to Le Corbusier. The building's endless corridors make life more difficult, and there are no cellars. And once the grocery store moves out there's no need for the celebrated food hatches in each apartment. At the end of the day, urban living can't be designed like a factory.
column12:
The outdoor area is freely accessible

For more information on this location, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/corbusier-house-berlin
column13: The Corbusier House has no mail boxes, so the postman has to deliver to every single apartment. It can take three hours to tramp up and down the 150-metre-long corridors (known as streets) and get round all 500 apartments.

column8: Is the cowboy riding across the screen from right to left or left to right? It depends on which auditorium you're in
column11:
Berlin’s oldest cinema
"Normal or mirror room?" This question is asked hundreds of times a day at the box office at Hohenstaufen-Lichtspiele cinema, today's Moviemento. It's a question that matters, because tickets for the mirror room are cheaper, and we're on the border between Kreuzberg and Neukölln, two working-class districts where people have to watch the pennies.

The cinema's particular layout on the first floor of a corner building and its location in a working-class neighbourhood gave the owners an idea. Filmgoers can choose between two screening rooms. If you opt for the larger auditorium, you watch the film in the normal way at regular admission prices. But if you want to save a little cash you can opt for the mirror room, which is built at an angle to the main auditorium and located behind the screen. The screen itself is made of translucent silk batiste, so the audience in the mirror room can also watch the film, but the images are back to front.  

Mirror technology with a catch 

With the advent of the talkies around 1930, it didn't matter too much whether the audience saw the images the right way round or back to front. But silent movies had captions to explain the plot and reading them the wrong way round was a little more challenging! The answer was to install a mirror to turn the images and text back the right way. So if you don't mind the film being a little paler, the sound a little quieter and the actors acting back to front, you can save your hard-earned dough by buying a ticket for the mirror room. 

Neighbourhood cinemas 

Today's Moviemento is the oldest cinema still in existence in Berlin. Films have been shown here since 1907. In the 1920s, most modern cinemas were specifically designed to show the latest films after lavish premieres. But other cinemas opened all over the city in former shops and apartments, in dance halls and ballrooms, in courtyards and side buildings - basically in spaces that weren't designed to be cinemas. It meant that some of them had to get creative with mirrors - like today's Moviemento.  

These cinemas usually attracted audiences from the immediate neighbourhood. Admission was cheap, the audience didn't have to travel far, and the films were not necessarily the latest releases. The audience tended to take a few more liberties than they do today, often eating, drinking and smoking during the film and passing loud comments about what was happening on the screen. Many of them also used the neighbourhood cinemas as places to keep warm in winter or to escape from their cramped homes, and young couples had somewhere to cuddle under cover of darkness. The film itself - whether back to front or not - was not necessarily the main attraction.
column13: The Moviemento has had many names over the years: Vitascope, Odeon, Hohenstaufen-Lichtspiele, Taki and Tali. It may be an urban myth, but it's often claimed that the slang word for cinema, "Kintopp", originated here, after Alfred Topp, one of the cinema's early operators. One thing we do know is that the filmmaker Tom Tykwer worked at the cinema in the 1980s and was responsible for selecting the programme.

column8: In plain sight - Berlin is full of forced labourers
column11:
Nazi Forced Labour Documentation Centre
The apple tree hangs temptingly over the barbed wire fence that separates the forced labour camp from the neighbouring garden. Ugo Brilli can't resist one of the dark red apples. He reaches out but it's too high up. One of the guards immediately fires a warning shot. Brilli, an Italian internee, never goes near the apples again.

You're standing in front of one of the 13 barracks that make up the former forced labour camp in Schöneweide. This camp complex is the only one in Berlin to have been preserved largely intact.

In plain sight

In 1943, forced labourers are a common sight. Up to 11 million people are being forced to work in Germany and its occupied territories. Many of them are in Berlin. The camp in Schöneweide, one of around 3,000 such camps in Berlin, is located in the middle of a residential area. Local residents can look over at the camp while they eat their Sunday breakfast.

The first of over 2,000 forced labourers arrives in Schöneweide in mid-1944. They work on building sites, in munitions factories, for the German Railway, or they're put to work building anti-aircraft installations or clearing rubble. Without forced labour, the German economy would collapse. The camp in Schöneweide quickly fills up, mainly with deported civilians from Western and Eastern Europe and female prisoners from a satellite of the Sachsenhausen concentration camp. There are also a few Italian soldiers.

Cigarettes can save lives

The Italians arrive in Schöneweide at the end of November 1944. Until recently they were military allies. But when Italy switches sides, they become enemies whose labour is to be exploited.

Ugo Brilli is one of them. On 18 November 1944, he is issued with a housing card. He will live in building 3, room 7 until the end of the war. At first Brilli works for Siemens, clearing rubble. The job is physically exhausting, and he gets thinner by the day. Then he uses cigarettes to buy himself a kitchen job in the camp. It proves to be his salvation - his weight has dropped to 48 kilos.

A life in limbo

Apart from going to work, the forced labourers rarely leave the camp. They are not forbidden to leave, but they are not allowed to take any part in public life. So they can't go to the cinema or play sport. Public transport is off limits. This restricted freedom of movement means that many inmates are killed in air raids because they are not allowed to use public air raid shelters.

Brilli survives. On 23 April 1945, the Red Army liberates the forced labour camp. He has a long journey home, arriving in northern Italy in September 1945. Decades later he recounts his experiences of daily life in the camp. You'll hear his story as part of the audio guide that accompanies your tour of the camp.
column12:
Opening hours: 
Tuesday to Sunday, 10am - 6pm
Thursday 10am - 8pm

For more information on this location, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/nazi-forced-labour-documentation-centre
column13: "At that time Berlin was full of wooden barracks. Rows of brown, wooden huts covered in tar paper could be found in every nook and cranny of the city. Greater Berlin was one big camp. " This is how French forced labourer François Cavanna describes the Germany's capital. He goes on to set up the satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo in France.

column8: Silent movies versus talkies - film history was made on today's Caligariplatz in Weißensee
column11:
Hollywood in Weißensee
It's September 1919, barely a year after the end of the First World War. Electricity and building materials are scarce. Despite this, Decla, a film production company, is building a film set in Weißensee and invites the press to visit the shoot. Decla even covers the cost of the journalists' taxis and provides them with sandwiches. They're shooting a crowd scene - a procession through medieval Florence.

The journalists thank the production company for its generosity by writing effusive articles praising the elaborate set and professional film work. The producer of the epic film The Plague in Florence is Erich Pommer. The plot is unrestrainedly theatrical, and the film turns out to be a box office flop. But just a few months later, Pommer produces a film that is destined to become a classic of silent cinema: The Cabinet of Dr Caligari. 

Shooting silent movies in Weißensee 

In the 1920s Weißensee is known as Little Hollywood. Dozens of silent movies are shot at the many major film studios that set up shop here between 1913 and 1928. They include detective films, historical dramas - and the expressionist classic about the scary Doctor Caligari. The film studios are located on Franz-Joseph-Straße, today's Liebermannstraße. A small square in Weißensee now bears the name Caligariplatz in memory of the many films that were made there. 

Ten years after the shooting of The Plague in Florence, a new cinema opens on Caligariplatz. The exterior of the Delphi cinema is fairly plain - only a pyramid-shaped neon sign with the slanting Delphi lettering adorns the smooth plaster of its almost windowless façade. The Delphi is a large cinema. The auditorium has seating for 900 people in the stalls and circle, and the screen is framed by three impressive stucco arches.  

The talkies take over 

When the Delphi opens in Weißensee, the silent movie era is already coming to an end. In reality, the films were never truly silent. Before sound films were invented, the screenings were accompanied by orchestras, pianists or mechanical musical instruments. Sometimes a narrator provided a running commentary on the plot. The talkies made a breakthrough in Germany in 1930 with the release of two classic early sound films Die drei von der Tankstelle and Der blaue Engel. However, these new films weren't shot in Weißensee, but at the film studios in Babelsberg. The Delphi also has to adapt to the new era and start showing films with sound.  

Unlike many cinemas in Berlin, the Delphi survives the war largely unscathed. But it later falls into disrepair and closes in 1959.Over the years, its foyer is used as a vegetable store, a stamp shop and a laundry. Since 2013, the listed building has served as a venue for independent cultural events - and as a location for film and TV. In the series Babylon Berlin it provides the backdrop for the dance scenes at Moka Efti.
column13: If you want to watch a film in Weißensee today, you can go to the Toni cinema on Antonplatz, which was owned by to the Decla film production company in the early 1920s. Otherwise there is the Brotfabrik cinema on Caligariplatz. Artists from this cultural centre were behind the idea of giving the square this new name.

column8: The Manoli advertising sign shines out brightly over Moritzplatz! Incidentally, if you read Manoli backwards, you can discover the name of tobacco manufacturer Jakob Mandelbaum's wife - Ilona M.(andelbaum)!
column11:
The first Wertheim store on Moritzplatz becomes a café
Hot food day and night, two dance bands and a billiard hall - a winning line-up drawing the crowds to Café Moritzplatz. The square is a busy intersection - packed with a stream of horse-drawn carriages and omnibuses carrying white-collar and blue-collar workers, travellers from across the world and those seeking entertainment in the German capital.

Shortly before the First World War, Café Moritzplatz opens in Oranienstraße 53/54. The building, designed by Alfred Messel, initially houses the first branch of Georg Wertheim's department store in Berlin. But despite having an annex built, the premises for the store are soon too small. Wertheim moves to a new Moritzplatz building - today the site of the Princess Gardens. The old department store in Oranienstraße is turned into a spacious coffee house. Café Moritzplatz can host over 1200 guests - and has no less than two dance bands to choose from. Its own advertising labels proudly bear the claim of being the largest Concert Café in the south of Berlin.

In those days, these adhesive advertising labels to market products or promote causes were known as poster stamps. They could easily be glued onto parcels or put up in urban space - in a similar way to flyposting for clubs and bars today. The posh-looking man with a top hat and monocle decorating the café's advertising label is highly reminiscent of the Manoli Dandy, an iconic figure advertising a leading Berlin brand of cigarettes in the 1920s.

Manoli advertises with large illuminated signs across Berlin set high up on corner houses, the signs casting their light down the streets. One of these round advertising signs was also set directly on a corner building at Moritzplatz.

The café boasting hot foot day and night and a large billiard hall is owned by Richard Korant, who also runs a distillery and wine shop in nearby Prinzenstraße 82/84.

In the 1920s, Café Moritzplatz became the Triumph-Palast. Later, the premises were used by a silk yarn factory.
In the Second World War, the building was severely damaged in an air raid. In 1957, the ruins were demolished. The new Wertheim department store at Moritzplatz was also destroyed in the Second World War.
column13: Today, in a listed building not far from the former Café Moritzplatz, you can find the traditional Berlin pub Max und Moritz. Its opening in 1902 marked the 70th birthday of humourist and poet Wilhelm Busch, author of the children's cautionary tale Max and Moritz. Then as now, the pub offers hearty regional dishes. Today's guests, though, are rather different - a colourful mix of tourists, locals from the neighbourhood, families and groups.

column8: It begins as a desire for space and freedom, but ends in a bloody battle with police
column11:
Barricades and evacuations
It stinks of smoke. The sound of shattering glass and shouted orders is drowned out by the hiss of water cannons and the clatter of stones as they hail down onto the street. It feels more like a scene from a civil war than a planned eviction. But the police are determined to take back the street - at any cost.

Long live Mainzer Straße! That's the message on the orange container in the squatters' barricades.

Since the spring of 1990, this has been the home of East and West Berliners alike, a diverse group of antifascists, non-conformists, punks, gays and artists. But they are all united by their desire for space and freedom, whether it's room for new countercultures or empty places to live. There is no shortage of opportunities, because East Berlin is still a power vacuum. The West German police don't feel they are responsible for it, and East Germany's Volkspolizei no longer have an incentive to get their fingers burned. As far as the police are concerned, East Berlin doesn't exist.  The fall of the Wall also means that large numbers of old buildings are standing empty, and it's unclear who owns them. 200 are taken over by squatters. 

The occupation of the first ten houses in Mainzer Straße leads to the emergence of an alternative community. There are art studios, gay bars, theatres, cheap food at the "Volxküche" (people's kitchen), playgrounds and junk shops. Then there's the gay house, the lesbian and women's house, and lots of mixed apartment buildings. But there are people who hate these free-wheeling lifestyles. The squatters face regular attacks from neo-fascists. 

The "Berlin Line" policy reaches the East  

As of 24 July 1990, the "Berlin Line" policy also applies in the East, meaning that new squats can be cleared within 24 hours. Although the Mainzer Straße squats are all old buildings, on 12 November it becomes clear that the Senate is not prepared to make an exception. An armoured car is sent in to flatten the squatters' blockades, the police spray tear gas, and a water cannon is turned on the buildings. The squatters respond with a hail of stones, forcing the police to retreat. The next day is filled with demonstrations against police brutality. The street plenum, which is jointly responsible for Mainzer Straße, repeatedly announces its willingness to negotiate and promises the immediate dismantling of the barricades. But all attempts to reach someone in the Senate are doomed to failure.  

14 November 1990, 3.45 am - it all kicks off  

A cellar is in flames. Pure coincidence? Or is it a deliberate attack, meaning some of the barricades have to be moved to make way for the fire brigade? Whatever the cause, once the fire brigade has left the scene, the police get heavy handed. At 6am they begin a major offensive involving 3,000 policemen, 10 water cannons and several armoured cars. They are met with Molotov cocktails and stones being hurled from the house roofs. The riot police attempt to take control of the roofs by shooting rubber bullets and gas grenades from helicopters. It's a miracle that no-one falls off. But the people of Mainzer Straße realise the only way to break the spiralling violence is to clear out. Later, Mayor Walter Momper justifies the police crackdown by saying the squatters were "prepared to kill". But he fails to mention the massive police brutality.
column13: With the "Volxsküche" the squatters open a cheap street kitchen, which is also used by other residents. No wonder: for three Deutschmarks they can buy a freshly cooked hot meal, bought directly from the producers or local agricultural cooperatives.

column8: A passionate appeal to the determination of Berlin's population and the humanity of the Western Allies
column11:
An appeal for the freedom of hundreds of thousands
On 9 September 1948, Ernst Reuter - later West Berlin's first Governing Mayor - makes his powerful appeal to the western powers: "People of the world, people in America, England, France and Italy! Look upon this city and know you cannot, you must not, forsake us." And his appeal is heard.

You are now on the Platz der Republik, the square in front of the Reichstag Parliament building. The square covers around 40,000 square metres, an area equivalent to roughly six to seven football pitches. On 9 September 1948, Berlin residents crowd into this space to hear speakers in front of the Reichstag ruins. They have some eventful days behind them. Three days before, the city assembly in the Rotes Rathaus in the eastern sector is the scene of harassment and unrest. Members of the Socialist Unity Party, which has strong links to Moscow, violently disturb the session, but the East Berlin police do not intervene.  

Moreover, in June the Soviet forces already seal off land and water access to the sectors of Berlin under the Western Allies. The blockade hangs like a dark shadow over the divided city. At that time, Ernst Reuter is the elected Lord Mayor of Berlin, but the Soviets refuse to recognise his position. He knows his city is facing a crucial test - and his appeal must make itself heard. Reuter is a man of the people with a very chequered biography. But as he moves forward to the rostrum his past is unimportant, whether as a former Communist, a left-wing social democrat, a concentration camp inmate or an émigré under the Nazi regime. He knows exactly what is at stake - the freedom of the 300,000 people gathered to hear him, and the future of all those threatened by Communism.  

From the rostrum to the entire world  

His voice echoes over the square: "Today is the day when the people of Berlin raises its voice. Today, the people of Berlin are calling to the entire world." Enthralled, his audience follow his speech closely as he talks of the hungry Russian bear not just ready to swallow up Berlin, but all of Germany. Yet rather than seeking to fuel people's fears, Reuter wants to break out of the victim role. Each of his words is a challenge to the threat from the East: "We cannot be traded, we cannot be bartered away, and we can also not be sold." For him, Berlin in ruins is "a bulwark, an outpost of freedom".  

Rhetoric against repression   

His appeal to the determination of Berlin residents in the western sectors is enthusiastically received, with the huge square erupting into applause. Even well beyond Berlin and Germany's borders, Reuter's appeal is heard. The nations he calls on are ready and willing to support the divided city. Finally, with the Allied expansion of the airlift, the Soviet blockade is breached and defeated.
column13: Thousands follow Ernst Reuter's speech on radio broadcast by the RIAS American sector service. Just before the speech is due to go on air, RIAS's transmitters go dead - but the fault is quickly identified and fixed.

column8: David Bowie, Genesis and friends show the GDR regime that rock music transcends borders
column11:
A concert for Berlin – the whole of Berlin
"Good evening Berlin, good evening East Berlin, good evening West Berlin, good evening Germany and good evening to anybody who speaks English",  shouts Phil Collins, singer of the band Genesis - to cheers from the 60,000-strong crowd. Everyone knows that these words will also find their way over the Wall.

The radio station RIAS 2 spends weeks plugging the three-day concert, to be held as part of Berlin's 750th anniversary celebrations. It will be broadcasting it live - giving hope to those citizens who were not allowed to stand where you are now, in front of the Reichstag building. East Germans can listen to RIAS 2 too - but only in secret. Unfortunately, the many illicit listeners are unable to see David Bowie's huge Glass Spider stage set or Annie Lennox's daring red bra.  

Songs transcend borders  

But at least music transcends borders. And the stars know it. David Bowie lived in Berlin for a few years, and he wants it to be a concert for the whole city. He headlines the show on the first evening, greeting his fans on the other side of the Wall in a loud, clear voice, saying in German: "And we send our best wishes to all our friends who are on the other side of the Wall". 

The lure of freedom  

Of course, the organisers are well aware of the show's impact on young East Berliners. They later deny that some speakers were deliberately turned towards the border, but the wind still carries the music over the Wall. The East Germans hear its siren call. At first, a few fans dribble towards the Brandenburg Gate. Then on Whit Monday, the third day, Genesis take to the stage and several thousand East German fans rush to the border. When Phil Collins introduces the song Domino and speaks almost prophetically about the domino effect on "the people over there" his West German fans cheer loudly. In the East, his fans feel the effects of police batons.  But despite the many injuries and arrests, the domino effect is well underway.
column13: Eighties-style fake news. That's the best way to describe how the GDR regime reacted to coverage of the event in the Western media. Injuries and arrests? Fake news! But the statements of numerous eyewitnesses, including ARD reporters, tell a very different tale.

column8: The renaissance of a magnificent building - how the Berlin Palace is being brought back to life
column11:
A dialogue between the world’s cultures
In the 15th century, if you were to stand on this very spot where the Berlin Palace is now being built, you would have seen towers instead of cranes and heard the sound of horse-drawn carriages instead of pneumatic drills. It was the residence of the feudal nobility, then the Prussian kings, and later the imperial court. After being badly damaged during the Second World War, the palace was blown up in 1950 on the orders of the East German government and replaced by the Palast der Republik. In the end this palace was also demolished between 2006 and 2008 because of the asbestos used in its construction.

One man in particular is fascinated by the history of the palace - the entrepreneur Wilhelm von Boddien. Ever since Germany's reunification, this lover of fine architecture has been hoping the magnificent building will be restored to life. In 1992 he sets up a foundation to lobby for its reconstruction and pays for a full-size canvas mock-up of the palace in its original location. 

Understanding the world as a whole  

This proves to be controversial, and some critics claim the building embodies a "national neurosis". However, in 2002, a large majority in the German Bundestag approves the reconstruction of the palace as a seat for the Humboldt Forum, which will provide a "showcase for the cultures of the world". Wilhelm von Boddien's foundation continues to collect donations for the reconstruction of the building's historic facade, and by 2018 has amassed around 80 million euros. 

The palace is to be more than just a tourist attraction. The new building with the baroque façade will house the Humboldt Forum - a centre for art, culture, science and education. It is due to open in late 2019, 30 years after the fall of the Wall. Admission will be free of charge.  

"Named after the Humboldt brothers, the Humboldt Forum aims to present the challenges and opportunities faced by the whole world through a series of fascinating exhibitions, research projects, talks and other events. This is the idea behind the Humboldt Forum", writes Horst Bredekamp, Professor of Art History and, until June 2018, one of the founding directors of the Humboldt Forum. 

Squaring up to controversy 

What can you expect when you visit the Forum? The Humboldt Forum is very aware of the discussion about the provenance of museum exhibits and Germany's colonial past. Where did the exhibits come from? Were they donated? Were they obtained legally? Or were they effectively stolen? With the relocation of the non-European collections from the Dahlem museum to their new home in central Berlin, the spotlight will not only be turned on the beauty of the exhibits, but also on their origins.
column12: For more information on this location, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/humboldtforum-berlin-city-palace
column13: On the night of 29 May 2018, the first major exhibit is delivered to the site of the Berlin Palace from the Dahlem Museum: a unique boat from the island of Luf in Papua New Guinea. It is transported in a 16-metre-long box and lifted into the building using special hoists. It will stay in its protective packaging until the building work is completed.

column8: Deviating from the norm is normal at Südblock
column11:
Everyone is welcome
Today's lunch is vegan beetroot and walnut risotto. If you're a vegetarian you can add a sprinkle of parmesan. And on request you can add a little Serrano ham. These three lines on the menu tell you everything you need to know about Südblock - it has something to suit every taste and every lifestyle.

 The urban planners call the buildings on the south side of Kottbusser Tor "Südblock" - south block. For some, the name is synonymous with a dodgy neighbourhood, a dangerous area. When Tülin Duman, Dennis Kuhlow and Richard Stein saved this one-storey building from being turned into a gambling den, born-and bred Kreuzbergers chose this particular name. At the opening on 4 December 2010, Stein commented to a reporter from queer magazine Siegessäule: "We've (...) all lived here a long time and don't believe it's a social 'non-place' or in any way dodgy." 

When you sit on the red plastic chairs outside Südblock, you find yourself sitting in what is probably Berlin's most urban beer garden. Behind you are the Kreuzberg apartment blocks, in front the busy Kottbusser Tor traffic junction. It doesn't get more Kreuzberg than that. But a special kind of neighbourhood has grown up in this urban jungle over recent years. Südblock is a place for everyone.  

Gays, lesbians, Turks 

A café, a stage and sometimes a social centre - Südblock offers a diverse programme. When it was being renovated and the imitation terracotta and suspended ceilings being torn out, friends and neighbours all turned up to help. The LGBTQ community has been involved from the start, but it's also popular with local Turkish residents. A café by day and a party venue by night, it still makes sure it doesn't disturb the neighbours. When the glass windows of the "aquarium" next to Südblock start to steam up on the inside, the beer garden is strictly off limits so that the neighbours can get their sleep.  

Problems, queers and parties 

Südblock also addresses social - and cosmetic - problems in Kreuzberg. The Hartzer Roller association offers advice on welfare issues every Tuesday from 1pm, while the Salon Saalam offers haircuts and fortune-telling every second Monday. It also hosts regular events and discussions on local issues. And of course it wouldn't be Kreuzberg without all kinds of party events, such as the Flittchenbar, Dance-Karaoke and Queer Arabeske. Not to mention serving breakfast, lunch and cake all day long. For the people of Kreuzberg, Südblock is a home from home, a place where they can simply be themselves. Being queer - deviating from the norm - is normal here.
column12:
Opening hours:
Monday to Saturday from 11am, Sunday from 10am
column13: Equality for all - the blue-tiled toilets in Südblock are unisex. The urinals and stalls are separated by a swing door - with instructions for women on how to pee standing up.

column8: 126 metres up - the view from Berlin's Funkturm, the Radio Tower, is quite breathtaking
column11:
Berlin’s Radio Tower
Welcome to the opening of the third "Great German Radio Exhibition"! On 3 September 1926, the late summer sun is shining brightly on the fairs and exhibition grounds along Berlin's Kaiserdamm boulevard. The guests gathered for the opening admire the festive decorations in the exhibition hall. The Berlin Radio Orchestra launches into Beethoven's Leonore Overture No. 3. As the final notes fade away, radio announcer Alfred Braun reads an inauguration poem. Then Gustav Böß, Mayor of Berlin, officially declares the new Radio Tower open to the public.

A mini-Eiffel Tower

The Radio Tower rises into sky behind the ceremony, a silent guest of honour, its iron braces decorated with garlands of flowers. Although inspired by the Eiffel Tower in Paris, Berlin's Radio Tower looks more linear and less elaborate - and, as a result, is lighter and much cheaper to construct. The German capital's new iconic landmark is around 150 metres high, just half the height of the Eiffel Tower, and stands as a symbol of global communication and technical progress. In his Welcome Address, Dr. Alfred Schick, director of fairs and exhibitions, enthuses: "As a new Victory Column in the west of the city, the Radio Tower proclaims the human mind's peaceful victory over time and space." 

From A for anode to W for wave meter

From the foot of the Radio Tower, visitors stream towards the large exhibition hall known as the Haus der Funkindustrie (House of the Wireless Industry). So, let's take a look at the attractions for ourselves. For ten days, 250 exhibiters at the trade fair are showing the latest innovations in wireless transmission technologies. The Berlin companies of Siemens, AEG and Telefunken are the market leaders - and they assert their right to place their exhibition areas and displays in the centre of the hall. Around them, competitors from local heroes, like the Nora-Radio company from Charlottenburg, to national players, such as SABA from the Black Forest, show off radio frequency coils, condensers and headphones. Does that lush sound seem familiar? Then it must be an Acuston speaker! Don't miss a visit to the gallery - there, in one of the soundproofed demonstration booths, you can experience a radio broadcaster in action. The Funkstunde, Germany's first radio broadcaster, is broadcasting live from the fair and exhibition grounds.

Radio is uncharted territory

The years of radio's enthusiastic youth, between 1923 and 1933, are a time of innovation and experiments. Early radio construction and listening is, first and foremost, driven by amateurs, geeks and boffins. In the early days, technical know-how is needed to set cables and antenna for interference-free reception. But by 1928 at the latest, German companies are already looking to produce radios in series. The young republican democracy of Germany, founded in 1919, promises to put a radio in every home so all its citizens can participate in cultural life. After the Nazi seizure of power in 1933, the regime instrumentalise the Great German Radio Exhibition as a political show. Aware of the power of wireless as a propaganda channel, the Nazi regime prioritises production of the affordable Volksempfänger ("people's receiver"). Then, at the latest, the world of radio loses its innocence.

The Radio Tower falls silent

After the Second World War, the idea of a major fair for radio is revitalised. From 1971, Berlin hosts the IFA (Internationale Funkausstellung), attracting electronics experts and fans from all over the world. Just as in the 1920s, the event is held in the exhibition hall directly next to the Funkturm - Berlin's Radio Tower. There is, though, one major difference - with modern transmitters so powerful, the Radio Tower has long fallen silent. But the Radio Tower restaurant and viewing platform remain just as popular as ever.
column12: For more information on this location, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/funkturm
column13: In 1928, the exhibition hall hosts the first public display of television in Germany. Two years later, in 1930, the opening speech of the seventh Great German Radio Exhibition is given by no less a figure than Albert Einstein, Nobel Laureate for Physics.

column8: A Prussian parade ground, the site of mass rallies and a public park - the Lustgarten has a chequered history
column11:
Parade ground of the Weimar Republic
In 1918, on the Sunday before Christmas, the imperial capital witnesses one of the "most moving demonstrations" in its history. The Imperial Association of War Veterans and War Wounded is staging a protest march from the Lustgarten park to the War Ministry in Wilhelmstraße. 10,000 war veterans make their way along Unter den Linden - the blind, the crippled and the wheelchair-bound all remind the people of Berlin of the terrible consequences of the lost war. They carry placards asking: "Is this the thanks we get from the Fatherland?" 

"Long live the Republic - No more war!" 

During the 1918 revolution, the former parade ground of the Hohenzollern monarchy becomes a central rallying point for the young republic. In the early 1920s, hundreds of thousands of people gather here to demonstrate against militarism and tyranny. This is the precise spot where emperors would accept their oaths of allegiance from young recruits. During World War I, this is where captured enemy cannons were displayed and where German weapons were blessed. On 1 August 1921, 200,000 people are mobilised to take part in an anti-war demonstration.  

Democrats and pacifists protest peacefully, but opponents of the Weimar Republic resort to violence. Just three weeks after this peace demonstration, centrist politician Matthias Erzberger is killed by right-wing terrorists. His memorial service in the Lustgarten on 31 August 1921 is attended by 500,000 Berliners, turning it into a rejection of violence and a demonstration of support for the Republic. 

"Berlin remains red!" 

The right to protest is enshrined in the Weimar constitution. The workers' parties make the most of this, with Social Democrats and Communists regularly mobilising their supporters to attend May day rallies in the Lustgarten. They swear allegiance to socialism as they wave their red flags and sing the Internationale. But demonstrations are increasingly banned after 1928 because of street battles instigated by the communists.   

In the end, it's the National Socialists who benefit from these proletarian battles for control of Berlin's streets. In March and April 1932, the brownshirts hold their own rallies in the Lustgarten for the very first time. These right-wing rallies are initially much smaller than those organised by the anti-fascist Iron Front. But emergency decrees and bans on demonstrations mean that the supporters of the Republic are increasingly on the back foot. 

However, even after the Nazis take power, the pro-democracy Reichsbanner organisation continues to display the resistance of "red Berlin". On 19 February 1933, the Republicans gather in the Lustgarten for the last time. Reichsbanner leader Karl Höltermann stands on a rostrum swathed in the organisation's traditional black, red and gold. When he declares that they will fight every one of their opponents in defence of freedom, a hundred thousand voices roar: "Freedom!"
column13: In preparation for the 1936 Summer Olympics, the Nazis turn the Lustgarten into a parade ground for their mass marches and rallies. After 1945 it is used by East Germany's Socialist Unity Party and renamed Marx-Engels-Platz in 1951. In the late 1990s, the park is returned to its original name and design.

column8: Ladies only - the Violetta Lesbian Club puts on dances and costume balls at the Nationalhof
column11:
“What is life without love?”
Wednesday night in Schöneberg. Hidden away at the back of Bülowstraße 37 is the entrance to the Nationalhof ballroom. The Violetta women's club is meeting in the Red Room for an "evening of fun". Men have to stay outside - gawkers are not welcome. The band strikes up and everyone lets their hair down.

The organiser and club leader is Lotte Hahm, a leading light of Berlin's lesbian scene. Looking dapper in her tuxedo, she gets everyone dancing the Tyrolienne. She wants everyone to dance with everyone else. Dance a few steps, then change partners - the women are always in the arms of someone new. Everyone is dancing, laughing, flirting - nobody's going home alone tonight.

An intimate, easy-going place

The Nationalhof is actually a relic of the imperial age, when it was known as the Königshof (the Royal Court). In the 1920s, it becomes a popular meeting place for gays and lesbians. A homosexual theatre company puts on shows, it's home to a glamorous men's club and the largest of the gay rights pressure groups, the Bund für Menschenrecht (Federation for Human Rights), organises dances and gay rights events.

For lesbians, the Nationalhof has its heyday between 1927 and 1929. The Violetta has about 400 members and the Nationalhof serves as their clubhouse in the heart of a neighbourhood packed with pubs and bars. The area around Nollendorfplatz is the "lesbian love quarter", as Curt Moreck describes it in his famous Führer durch das lasterhafte Berlin (Guide to Depraved Berlin).  The Hohenzollerndiele, Dorian Gray, Topp-Keller, Olá lá - there's a gay bar or club on every corner.

Violetta club evenings are all about escaping everyday cares, being free to dance and find love in a laid-back, safe atmosphere. Moreck describes it as somewhere that women go to find "diversion, entertainment, conviviality, love", adding: "For many lesbian women, Violetta is the home they are deprived of elsewhere."  The Nationalhof allows them to be themselves, to find love and passion. It's a place where the predominantly young lesbians who frequent it can enjoy the kind of freedom that they are denied in the provinces.

Vibrant, diverse, creative

Berlin is the lesbian capital of the world - and the world needs to know about it. Lesbian life is vibrant and exciting, female homosexuality is no longer taboo. Dozens of clubs large and small, like Violetta and its main competitor Monbijou, jostle to attract members by placing ads in magazines like Die Freundin and Ledige Frauen. Cool clubs like the Nationalhof hold sailor parties with tug-of-war competitions, "Purple Nights" with showers of sweets, costume balls and special evenings for transvestites, crossdressers and drag queens. Gay culture is flourishing with a diverse, creative nightlife.

But, even before 1933, there are campaigns to criminalise lesbian lifestyles and denounce female homosexuality as immoral. Before long, magazine advertising is prohibited, and in 1932 the police chief bans the LGBT community from holding public dances. Raids and police checks ruin ladies' evenings in bars and clubs. Then the Nazis take power and outlaw homosexuality, forcing lesbian Berlin to go underground.
column13: In 1943 the Nationalhof changes hands and reopens as Walterchen's Ballhaus. With his ties to the black market, businessman Walter Draesel has high hopes for the club. But he struggles to restore its former glamour in the conservative post-war period. The Nationalhof is demolished in 1975, ten years after Walterchen's demise. The only reminder of its existence is the single column that stands in front of today's building.

column8: While the Soviet regime fights to control education, the students are fighting for educational freedom and an independent university
column11:
A think tank for freedom-lovers
Medical students Helmut Coper and Stanislaw Kubicki take a dim view of how Berlin's University at Unter den Linden has turned into a communist-style institution. Students who are not loyal to the regime risk being arrested and hauled off by Soviet counter-intelligence agents. They want an independent, outward-looking university!

Students are increasingly being spied on and forced to attend compulsory lectures on politics. This leads to ever-louder calls for a new, independent university to be set up. Defying threats of consequences, 2,000 students stage a protest at the Esplanade Hotel on the border with the Soviet sector. 

Out of the lecture hall and onto the streets 

They want an education policy that is not based on party loyalties but on international democratic standards. Their demands are given a sympathetic hearing. General George Hay, High Commissioner of the US sector, sets up a special committee and gives the project the go ahead. This is followed by a meeting of professors, lecturers, politicians and students, including West Berlin's Mayor, Ernst Reuter. This group is now responsible for the process of setting up the Free University. The first job is to find the right location.  

Nothing can stop them - even the Berlin Blockade 

Helmut Coper and his friend Stanislaw Kubicki help to set up the university's secretariat. The building at Boltzmannstraße 4, where you are now standing, survives the war intact but at first it lacks basic amenities. In the absence of tables and chairs, documents are laid out on the floor. Fortunately, the building has a telephone, as lots of people are already interested in applying for a place. Helmut Coper is elected Chairman of the General Student Council and works closely with Ernst Reuter and the US authorities. 

Their help is vital, particularly during the Berlin Blockade, when power cuts mean that lectures have to be given by candlelight. And the students? After their long fight for an independent university, they're not going to be deterred by a few power cuts or a lack of furniture - and certainly not the two friends who receive enrolment numbers 1 and 2: Kubicki and Coper.
column12:
Opening hours:
The outdoor area is freely accessible
column13: The reason Coper and Kubicki are given enrolment numbers 1 and 2 is because their surnames are in the A to K range, the first group to be assigned student numbers. They can't agree on who should get number one, so they flip a coin. Kubicki wins, and he and Coper remain lifelong friends.

column8: The House of One could become the world's first combination of church, mosque and synagogue. But the idea has stirred up controversy
column11:
The world’s great religions come together under one roof
Berlin is full of churches - but from 2019 it will be home to a truly unique place of worship. The House of One is the first interfaith building designed for Christians, Jews and Muslims. This revolutionary idea of a common place of worship for all three monotheistic religions has attracted its fair share of praise and criticism alike. Can such a project really succeed?

Lack of publicity is certainly not a problem for the project's founders. When they first announced their unusual plan for the House of One, they attracted worldwide attention, including reports in the Washington Post and the Arab news channel Al Jazeera. At a time of global religious conflict, the world's first combination of church, mosque and synagogue is causing quite a stir.   

Check out the plans for the House of One online - you'll see a modern brick building divided into separate sections. Each religion has its own space for worship and there is a communal room where worshippers and members of the public can come together and learn more about each other's religions. The Berlin architectural firm Kuehn Malvezzi has pared the traditional characteristics of sacred buildings back to their most elementary forms. It was important to ensure that no one religion was seen to predominate.  

How is it possible to have a communal building where the three religious communities still have their own space? This question is often asked, but Imam Kadir Sanci is confident it will work: "I think our building is like a shared flat. We all live together. Everyone has their own room, but there's a kitchen where we can all meet up. We're not looking to create a new religion or mix them up. We're all different, but we belong together." 

But the project also has its critics. Journalist Maritta Adam-Tkalec has openly addressed the difficulties experienced by Christians and Jews in finding a "strong Muslim partner". Many Berlin Muslims do not accept the Gülen movement, which is now on board, as the sole representative of Islam.  

A wooden hut stands on Petriplatz, where the GDR government once ordered the demolition of Berlin's oldest church. It holds a scale model of the communal room that will be built in the House of One. The success of this 43-million-euro project also depends on the success of the crowdfunding campaign.  

The idea originated in the Protestant community of Father Gregor Hohberg. He remains optimistic: "There's a real desire for religions to co-exist in harmony. Now we have to find a way to turn this desire into donations." The project has funding in place until the foundation stone is laid in 2019.
column12: For more information on this location, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/house-one-planning
column13: Petriplatz is known as the "original centre" of Berlin and its religious life. This is where the city's first church was built 700 years ago. The foundations of numerous Christian buildings have been uncovered during excavation works. They will be integrated into the House of One and opened to the public.

column8: The Fenster zum Klo exhibition takes a creative look at Berlin's gay scene
column11:
From public loo to art gallery
The door opens and stale smoke wafts out. Last night's party is still going. Saw blades hang from the ceiling. These are the lampshades over the flickering light bulbs that bathe the room in a dim light. A black dildo dangles overhead. The walls are covered with graffiti. You're in a public toilet - but two Berliners have given it a new identity. This is the last night before its summer break.

The loo gets a second life 

Zur Klappe - Toilet this way. That's what it says above the entrance. Is that graffiti next to it meant to be a warning? - Not so nice. From the central reservation on the Mehringdamm, on the corner of Yorckstraße, a staircase leads down to a place that is a combination of gallery, bar and club. Behind the entrance to the first room there's a toilet. Until a few years ago, this was the site of a public toilet, a "cottage" - a place where gay men meet for sex. Under the National Socialists, these places offered gay men a modicum of safety and freedom. During the 1980s, gay men in West Berlin also had to resort to cottaging because intercourse between men was still illegal. The cottages became vital elements of homosexual subculture.  

But the toilet in the centre of Kreuzberg is very dilapidated. The council is on the verge of knocking it down, but it is rescued by its current operators, Flint Neiber and Sören van Laak. The young men spend three years trying to get official approval for their plans, never giving up hope until the tenancy agreement is finally in their hands. Then they have a lot of work to do. They have to dry out the rooms, dispose of the waste and connect the water, gas and electricity. Ventilation is vital in underground rooms like these.  

The club's owners deliberately make few changes to the fabric of the building and preserve most of the 1980s graffiti. The original tiles and condom machine in the toilets give the place its special charm.  

Space for creative freedom 

"We make the rooms available to artists. They can exhibit their works there, " says one of the owners. Yet again, they have demonstrated how a little creativity can bring Berlin's abandoned places back to life. Members of Berlin's subculture have always had to fight for their freedom to create.  

The club celebrates its official opening in January 2018. An artist marks the occasion with an exhibition of photos about the location and cottaging in Berlin entitled Fenster zum Klo (Window on the toilet). After its first six months, the club is taking a summer break. Time to let some air in.
column13: Cottages can't be recognised as such from the outside, but inside there are a number of clues. Graffiti, personal ads, and the "glory hole" between the stalls that provides space for anonymous sex. In the 1990s, a company called Wall replaces Berlin's old public toilets with pay toilets.

column8: With its TV Tower, the East German regime scores over the West - a technical masterpiece and a political coup
column11:
Berlin’s socialist city crown
Largely for political reasons, the iconic Berlin TV Tower is constructed in the heart of the city. The East German regime wants to prove something to West Germany and the world - and it does.

If East Germany's Post Services had pushed through its original plans in 1952, you would not visit the TV Tower on Alexanderplatz today, but at the Müggelsee lake.  

In part due to East Germany's bureaucratic and fault-prone command economy, the TV Tower project starts out like a disaster waiting to happen. The project haemorrhages vast amounts of money with never a sign of a building.  

And time is pressing. In the newly-established East Germany, the available TV and radio frequencies in the "Workers' and Peasants' State" are far from ideal. The SED regime's Central Committee fears some GDR citizens might start listening to the free channels from West Germany, and they cannot afford to risk such "media emigration".  

Searching for a landmark site   

Appropriately enough, East Germany's leaders in the 1960s are looking for an impressive symbol of their socialist society's superiority. Ultimately, various political motives speak for the new TV Tower as an architectural demonstration of power in the centre of Berlin.  

Allegedly in 1964, Walter Ulbricht, then East Germany's head of state, personally stands in front of a model of Berlin, gestures at Alexanderplatz and says: "Well, Comrades, you can easily see for yourself - that's where the tower belongs." Certainly, Ulbricht gives the signal for what is, at that time, an unparalleled building project in the GDR. He wants a "socialist city crown" for Berlin.  

Ulbricht is looking for a distinctive landmark - and finds it in the tower's simple yet iconic spherical shape. This design has another advantage. Everyone seeing the tower's sphere recalls the famous Russian satellite Sputnik 1 - the perfect model for socialism's symbolic victory.  

The spiralling costs are kept secret   

From 1965, in just under four-and-a-half years, the world's second highest TV Tower is finished. Berlin's TV Tower is 365 metres high, making it also the third highest freestanding building of its day after Moscow's Ostzankino TV Tower and New York's Empire State Building. When the tower is unveiled in 1969, Walter Ulbricht is not the only one who calls it a sensation. The city's new landmark quickly starts to draw the crowds. 

With the TV Tower, East Germany creates an architectural and design masterpiece outshining anything in West Germany, which has far more economic clout. And over the following years, the GDR enjoys the success of its tower to the full. Yet the East German state is more than coy about the cost. Its citizens are not told the actual price tag of this icon of socialist planning - 132 million Marks, four times the original budget.  

After the Berlin Wall falls in 1989, some critical voices call for demolishing the TV Tower. Fortunately, this radical suggestion is ignored. Today, the TV Tower attracts over one million visitors a year from as many as 86 different countries. The tower has long ceased to be a symbol of the SED dictatorship in East Germany, and firmly become a symbol of a free and modern Berlin.
column12:
Opening hours (TV Tower):
March to October, Daily from 9 a.m. to midnight
November to February, Daily from 10 a.m. to midnight   
Last elevator to the viewing platform: 11:30pm 

For more information on events and tickets, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/berlin-television-tower
column13: Although East Germany systematically discriminated against the Christian Church, the regime's TV Tower unwittingly creates the country's largest and most prominent Christian symbol. When bright sunlight hits the outer shell of the TV Tower's steel sphere, the fall of light creates the shape of a cross - dubbed by locals as the 'Pope's revenge'.

column8: The former death zone is now a place for singing, barbecuing and having fun
column11:
From death zone to outdoor karaoke
The amphitheatre in the Mauerpark is at bursting point. The atmosphere is buzzing. A Babel of languages blends with the sound of music. There are bands on every corner. It's one of the first hot days of the year. The air smells of summer and freedom. The excitement builds. Cheers ring out when Joe Hatchiban rides his converted bike into the amphitheatre and sets up his music system. It's time for karaoke in the Mauerpark.

Right here, where the first singer is getting ready, this was part of the death zone that divided the city until 1989. The area has a colourful history. Once farmland, in the 19th century it was turned into a military parade ground. Berliners called the area "The Lone Poplar" after its solitary poplar tree. Later on, it became the site of a sports facility and a freight station. From 1961 to 1989, the site was part of the no-mans-land between East and West Berlin.  

The area opens up again after the fall of the Wall, and Berliners are quick to claim it as their own. Five years later, it has been transformed into a public space, the Mauerpark. Together with the huge flea market next door, it fast becomes one of the city's most popular attractions.   

In 2009 Joe Hatchiban starts putting on karaoke sessions in the park, and they quickly become world famous. They are not about great singing. Nobody needs to feel embarrassed. You just need the courage to get up and have fun. Right now, an older guy is singing La Bamba. He barely hits a note. But the crowd loves it anyway and thanks him with loud applause. 

In front of the stage, someone is riding a bike dressed as a frog. Two girls are sunbathing topless. A juggler starts warming up. The air smells of barbecued food. You can try your hand at spray painting a section of the Wall - all legal and above board. It's a place for people to have fun and enjoy the freedom that epitomises Berlin. 

But the Mauerpark is not particularly attractive. Where other parks have trees, hedges and benches, the Mauerpark is mainly large swathes of grass, perhaps more brown than green. But what makes the park so attractive is its diverse visitors, their openness and friendliness. Typical Berlin.
column12:
Opening hours:
Park is freely accessible
Flea market: Sunday 9am - 6pm

For more information on this location, please go to https://www.visitberlin.de/en/mauerpark
column13: In January 2018 construction workers make a spectacular discovery. During excavations at the entrance to the Mauerpark, they stumble across an 80-metre-long escape tunnel. This was how East German citizens escaped to the West. Contemporary reports suggest it was one of several escape tunnels.

column8: Functionality and Transparency on Alexanderplatz
column11: The building complex was constructed in the early 1960ies by architect Hermann Henselmann and focuses on functionality and transparency. The congress hall is easily recognisable by its aluminium cupola, which is also its largest function room with seats for a 1000-strong audience. Overall the congress hall has over 30 function rooms and 3000 sqm exhibition space. After a temporary closure in the 1990ies, the listed building was reopened in 2003 after extensive refurbishing under its new name bcc, they foyer of which offers an attractive view of Alexanderplatz. The neighbouring 12-storey ‘Haus des Lehrers’ is a typical example of the post-war box-like architecture, and features with its 125 meters long, the building spanning wall frieze entitled ‘Unser Leben’ (Our Life) by Walter Womacka, one of the largest pieces of art in Europe. Together, the two buildings form one of the well-known landmarks of Alexanderplatz. The two received additional attention during their refurbishment, when the light installation ‘Blinkenlights’ was installed at the ‘Haus des Lehrers’.
column12: Temporarily closed. - The ‘Haus des Lehrers’ and the adjacent congress hall, which today is home to the bcc (Berlin Congress Center), create the immediate neighbourhood of Alexanderplatz.

column8: WAGNER + PARTNER was founded in 2008. It is located in the historic former DDR Interflug Travel Bureau in Strausberger Platz on Karl-Marx-Allee.
column11: The gallery’s international program focuses on contemporary photography, painting, and installations. The focus is on artists who address the relationships of space, time, and identity. In a fruitful relationship to the historic architecture of the Karl-Marx-Allee where the gallery is located, high-quality exhibitions in terms of content and aesthetic are realized here.
column12:
Wed - Sat
13:00 – 18:00
Find further information here
http://www.galerie-wagner-partner.com

column8:
This art and culture ensemble, which is not just architecturally diverse, lies between Potsdamer Platz and the Landwehr Canal.

Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, there may be closures and changed opening hours. Please have a look at the individual houses/institutions.
column11:
The Kulturforum looks back on an extensive evolutionary and architectural history, which is also reflected in the very different architectural styles of the buildings.

At the end of the 1950s, plans existed for a cultural axis across Berlin. They were based on the ideas of the architect Hans Scharoun, who was at that time president of the Akademie der Künste (Academy of Arts). The wall had not yet been built, and the axis was to extend from the Museum Island in the east to Charlottenburg Palace in the west.

The site of the present-day Kulturforum is located in Mitte. As a result of massive planning interventions during the Nazi era and the devastation of the Second World War, the area there lay fallow. A new cultural centre for a burgeoning post-war Berlin was to be built on it.

It was to provide visitors with the opportunity to enjoy art, listen to music, and study scientific writings in future. The impact of the individual institutes would be heightened by concentrating them on one spot – that was the plan.

Then came the building of the Berlin Wall and the Kulturforum, located close to the wall, became an important prestige project for the West. This not only meant it had to hold its own during the ongoing strife with the GDR regime, but also send a clear message to West Germany. The repatriation of the art and literature outsourced to the Federal Republic of Germany went anything but quickly. The construction of suitable buildings aimed to put pressure on bringing them back to West Berlin.

Everything takes time
A start was made in the 1960s and 1970s with three designs by two internationally renowned architects. The Philharmonie by Hans Scharoun marked the beginning of the construction activity at the Kulturforum. It celebrated its opening in 1963. Its unusual tent-like roof and yellow façade contrasted with the strict, functionalist form of the New National Gallery by Ludwig Mies van der Rohe, which opened five years later.

The buildings made St. Matthew’s Church, which has been situated within the complex since the 19th century, seem somewhat antiquated. St. Matthäus-Kirche in the Kulturforum Berlin is a historical centre, a space for contemporary art and a religious place of peace for Berliners and Berlin visitors.

Scharoun's long-standing employee Edgar Wisniewski realised the Kammermusiksaal (Chamber Music Hall) and the Musikinstrumentenmuseum (Musical Instrument Museum) according to his plans. The Museum opened in 1984, and the Kammermusiksaal in 1987 to mark the 750th anniversary of the city of Berlin.

In the 1970s, the Staatsbibliothek was built on the other side of Potsdamer Strasse according to Scharoun's designs. It was opened in 1978, six years after the death of the architect. The neighbouring Ibero-American Institute was also based on one of Scharoun's designs.

The construction of the Staatsbibliothek devoured more money than originally estimated, which led to a delay in starting the construction of the other art houses planned.

Museum architecture in transition
West Berlin had already held an architectural competition in 1965 for the design of the entire Kulturforum. The expectations were high, and the most compelling design was to offer no less than a “structural characterisation of what a museum means for us today”.

In the eyes of the jury, no competitor would be able to achieve this ambitious goal. As a compromise, the responsible parties agreed to award the contract to the Stuttgart architect Rolf Gutbrod.

His designs dated back to a period in which the tasks and functions of museum architecture were questioned. What was the reciprocal relationship between the museums and the collections they housed? Which target groups were to be addressed?

The architect considered his designs to be an alternative to the classical and neo-baroque buildings on the Museum Island. His museums should not be intimidating but encourage people of all social strata to visit.

The Kunstgewerbemuseum (Museum of Decorative Arts) opened in 1985. Based on a 20-year-old design, the concept of the building with its brutalist façade and dominant stairwells had become outdated. And it wasn’t well received by the public: the criticism was so devastating, Gutbrod had to resign. It was initially unclear as to how things should proceed with the Kulturforum.

The Munich architects Heinz Hilmer and Christoph Sattler were awarded the contract to revise Gutbrod’s designs for the Kupferstichkabinett (Gallery of Prints and Drawings) and Kunstbibliothek. They changed numerous details and did away with the envisaged exposed concrete columns in the exhibition hall, for example.
The opening took place in 1994. With its façade clad in concrete and clinker brick, the building today is emphatically reserved.

The Gemäldegalerie was also the work of Hilmer and Sattler and opened in 1998. They needed to adapt their design because the location and entrance had been determined by Gutbrod. The architects abandoned prestigious façades and focussed on the quality of the interior design. Classically cut halls with perfect lighting conditions accentuated the precious collection.

The future of the Kulturforum
The New National Gallery has been closed since 2014 due to renovation work and is planned to reopen in 2020. Furthermore, there has long been insufficient exhibition space to display all the collections from the 20th century.

The Prussian Cultural Heritage Foundation thus held a competition in 2015 for a new museum building: the Nationalgallerie20, the museum of the 20th century.
Developing the open space between the Philharmonie and New National Gallery is to create a stronger spatial link between all the buildings.

The competition’s winning design came from the Swiss architects Herzog & De Meuron. The opening should take place in the mid-2020s.
